• SNP 1.1:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.1:0.2The Snake

SNP 1.1:1.1BJ 25.2PTS-VP-PLI 1When anger surges, they drive it out,SNP 1.1:1.2as with medicine a snake’s spreading venom. SNP 1.1:1.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:1.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:10.1They have not run too far nor run back,SNP 1.1:10.2knowing nothing is what it seems, free of greed. SNP 1.1:10.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:10.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:11.1They have not run too far nor run back,SNP 1.1:11.2knowing nothing is what it seems, free of lust. SNP 1.1:11.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:11.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:12.1They have not run too far nor run back,SNP 1.1:12.2knowing nothing is what it seems, free of hate. SNP 1.1:12.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:12.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:13.1They have not run too far nor run back,SNP 1.1:13.2knowing nothing is what it seems, free of delusion. SNP 1.1:13.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:13.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:14.1They have no underlying tendencies at all,SNP 1.1:14.2and are rid of unskillful roots, SNP 1.1:14.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:14.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:15.1BJ 25.6They have nothing born of distress at all,SNP 1.1:15.2that might cause them to come back to this world. SNP 1.1:15.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:15.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:16.1They have nothing born of entanglement at all,SNP 1.1:16.2that would shackle them to a new life. SNP 1.1:16.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:16.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 3They’ve given up the five hindrances,SNP 1.1:17.2untroubled, rid of doubt, free of thorns. SNP 1.1:17.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:17.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:2.1They’ve cut off greed entirely,SNP 1.1:2.2like a lotus plucked flower and stalk.SNP 1.1:2.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next, SNP 1.1:2.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:3.1They’ve cut off craving entirely,SNP 1.1:3.2drying up that swift-flowing stream.SNP 1.1:3.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next, SNP 1.1:3.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:4.1They’ve swept away greed entirely,SNP 1.1:4.2as a fragile bridge of reeds by a great flood. SNP 1.1:4.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:4.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:5.1In future lives they find no substance,SNP 1.1:5.2as an inspector of fig trees finds no flower. SNP 1.1:5.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:5.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:6.1BJ 25.4They hide no anger within, SNP 1.1:6.2gone beyond any kind of existence. SNP 1.1:6.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:6.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 2Their mental vibrations are cleared away,SNP 1.1:7.2internally clipped off entirely. SNP 1.1:7.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:7.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:8.1They have not run too far nor run back,SNP 1.1:8.2but have gone beyond all this proliferation. SNP 1.1:8.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:8.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

SNP 1.1:9.1They have not run too far nor run back,SNP 1.1:9.2for they know that nothing in the world is what it seems. SNP 1.1:9.3Such a mendicant sheds this world and the next,SNP 1.1:9.4as a snake its old worn-out skin.

  • SNP 1.2:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.2:0.2With Dhaniya the Cowherd

SNP 1.2:1.1“I’ve boiled my rice and drawn my milk,”SNP 1.2:1.2said Dhaniya the cowherd,SNP 1.2:1.3“I stay with my family along the bank of the Mahī. SNP 1.2:1.4My hut is roofed, my fire kindled:SNP 1.2:1.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 5“I have no heifers or sucklings,”SNP 1.2:10.2said the Buddha, SNP 1.2:10.3“no cows in calf or breeding cows.SNP 1.2:10.4I haven’t got a bull, leader of the herd here:SNP 1.2:10.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:11.1“The stakes are driven in, unshakable,”SNP 1.2:11.2said Dhaniya,SNP 1.2:11.3“The grass halters are new and well-woven, SNP 1.2:11.4not even the sucklings can break them:SNP 1.2:11.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:12.1BJ 25.10“Like a bull I broke the bonds,”SNP 1.2:12.2said the Buddha, SNP 1.2:12.3“like an elephant I snapped the vine.SNP 1.2:12.4I will never lie in a womb again:SNP 1.2:12.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:13.1Right then a thundercloud rained down,SNP 1.2:13.2soaking the uplands and valleys. SNP 1.2:13.3Hearing the sky rain down,SNP 1.2:13.4Dhaniya said this:

SNP 1.2:14.1“It is no small gain for usSNP 1.2:14.2that we have seen the Buddha.SNP 1.2:14.3We come to you for refuge, Seer. SNP 1.2:14.4O great sage, please be our Teacher.

SNP 1.2:15.1My wife and I, obedient,SNP 1.2:15.2shall lead the spiritual life under the Holy One SNP 1.2:15.3Gone beyond birth and death,SNP 1.2:15.4we shall make an end of suffering.”

SNP 1.2:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 6“Your children bring you delight!”SNP 1.2:16.2said Māra the Wicked, SNP 1.2:16.3“Your cattle also bring you delight! SNP 1.2:16.4For attachments are a man’s delight; SNP 1.2:16.5without attachments there’s no delight.”

SNP 1.2:17.1“Your children bring you sorrow,”SNP 1.2:17.2said the Buddha,SNP 1.2:17.3“Your cattle also bring you sorrow. SNP 1.2:17.4For attachments are a man’s sorrow; SNP 1.2:17.5without attachments there are no sorrows.”

SNP 1.2:2.1“I boil not with anger and have drawn out hard-heartedness,”SNP 1.2:2.2said the Buddha, SNP 1.2:2.3“I stay for one night along the bank of the Mahī.SNP 1.2:2.4My hut is wide open, my fire is quenched:SNP 1.2:2.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:3.1“No gadflies or mosquitoes are found,”SNP 1.2:3.2said Dhaniya,SNP 1.2:3.3“cows graze on the lush meadow grass. SNP 1.2:3.4They get by even when the rain comes:SNP 1.2:3.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:4.1“I bound a raft and made it well,” SNP 1.2:4.2said the Buddha,SNP 1.2:4.3“and with it I crossed over, went beyond, and dispelled the flood. SNP 1.2:4.4Now I have no need for a raft:SNP 1.2:4.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:5.1BJ 25.8PTS-VP-PLI 4“My wife is obedient, not wanton,”SNP 1.2:5.2said Dhaniya, SNP 1.2:5.3“long have we lived together happily.SNP 1.2:5.4I hear nothing bad about her:SNP 1.2:5.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:6.1“My mind is obedient and freed,”SNP 1.2:6.2said the Buddha,SNP 1.2:6.3“long nurtured and well-tamed. SNP 1.2:6.4Nothing bad is found in me:SNP 1.2:6.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:7.1“I am self-employed,”SNP 1.2:7.2said Dhaniya,SNP 1.2:7.3“and my healthy children likewise. SNP 1.2:7.4I hear nothing bad about them:SNP 1.2:7.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:8.1“I am no-one’s lackey,”SNP 1.2:8.2said the Buddha,SNP 1.2:8.3“with what I have earned I wander the world. SNP 1.2:8.4I have no need for wages:SNP 1.2:8.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

SNP 1.2:9.1“I have heifers and sucklings,”SNP 1.2:9.2said Dhaniya,SNP 1.2:9.3“cows in calf and breeding cows. SNP 1.2:9.4I’ve also got a bull, leader of the herd here:SNP 1.2:9.5so rain, sky, if you wish.”

  • SNP 1.3:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.3:0.2The Rhinoceros Horn

SNP 1.3:1.1BJ 25.12When you've laid down arms toward all creatures,SNP 1.3:1.2not harming even a single one, SNP 1.3:1.3don’t wish for a child, let alone a companion:SNP 1.3:1.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 8Having shed the marks of the home life,SNP 1.3:10.2like the fallen leaves of the Shady Orchid Tree; SNP 1.3:10.3having cut the bonds of the home life, a hero wouldSNP 1.3:10.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:11.1If you find an alert companion, SNP 1.3:11.2a wise and virtuous friend, SNP 1.3:11.3then, overcoming all adversities, SNP 1.3:11.4wander with them, joyful and mindful.

SNP 1.3:12.1If you find no alert companion, SNP 1.3:12.2no wise and virtuous friend, SNP 1.3:12.3then, like a king who flees his conquered realm, SNP 1.3:12.4wander alone like a tusker in the wilds.

SNP 1.3:13.1Clearly we praise the blessing of a friend,SNP 1.3:13.2it’s good to be with friends your equal or better. SNP 1.3:13.3but failing to find them, eating blamelessly,SNP 1.3:13.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:14.1Though made of shining gold, well-finished by a smith,SNP 1.3:14.2when two bracelets share the same arm SNP 1.3:14.3they clash up against each other. Seeing this,SNP 1.3:14.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:15.1Thinking, “So too, if I had a partner, SNP 1.3:15.2there’d be flattery or curses.” SNP 1.3:15.3Seeing this peril in the future, SNP 1.3:15.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:16.1BJ 25.16Sensual pleasures are diverse, sweet, delightful,SNP 1.3:16.2appearing in disguise they disturb the mind. SNP 1.3:16.3Seeing danger in the many kinds of sensual stimulation,SNP 1.3:16.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:17.1This is a calamity, a boil, a disaster,SNP 1.3:17.2an illness, a dart, and a danger for me. SNP 1.3:17.3Seeing this peril in sensuality, SNP 1.3:17.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 9Heat and cold, hunger and thirst,SNP 1.3:18.2wind and sun, flies and snakes: SNP 1.3:18.3having put up with all these things,SNP 1.3:18.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:19.1As a full-grown elephant, lotus-eating, magnificent,SNP 1.3:19.2forsaking the herd, SNP 1.3:19.3stays where it wants in the forest, SNP 1.3:19.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:2.1Those with close relationships have affection,SNP 1.3:2.2following which this pain arises. SNP 1.3:2.3Seeing this danger born of affection,SNP 1.3:2.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:20.1It’s impossible for one who delights in companySNP 1.3:20.2to experience even temporary freedom. SNP 1.3:20.3Heeding the speech of the Kinsman of the Sun,SNP 1.3:20.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:21.1Thinking, “I am one who has left warped views behind,SNP 1.3:21.2has reached the sure way, has gained the path, SNP 1.3:21.3has given rise to knowledge, and needs no-one to guide me”,SNP 1.3:21.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:22.1No greed, no guile, no thirst, no slur,SNP 1.3:22.2dross and delusion is smelted off; SNP 1.3:22.3free of hoping for anything in the world,SNP 1.3:22.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:23.1Avoid a wicked companion, SNP 1.3:23.2blind to the good, habitually immoral. SNP 1.3:23.3One ought not befriend the heedless and hankering, butSNP 1.3:23.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:24.1BJ 25.18PTS-VP-PLI 10Spend time with a learned expert who has memorized the teachings, SNP 1.3:24.2an eloquent and uplifting friend.SNP 1.3:24.3When you understand the meanings and have dispelled doubt, SNP 1.3:24.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:25.1When you realize that worldly fun and gamesSNP 1.3:25.2and pleasure are unsatisfying, disregarding them, SNP 1.3:25.3as one unadorned, a speaker of truth,SNP 1.3:25.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:26.1Children, partner, father, mother,SNP 1.3:26.2wealth and grain and relatives: SNP 1.3:26.3having given up sensual pleasures to this extent,SNP 1.3:26.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:27.1“This is a snare. Here there’s hardly any happiness,SNP 1.3:27.2little gratification, and it’s full of drawbacks. SNP 1.3:27.3It’s a hook.” Knowing this, a thoughtful person wouldSNP 1.3:27.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:28.1Having burst apart the fetters,SNP 1.3:28.2like a fish that tears the net and swims free, SNP 1.3:28.3or a fire not returning to ground it has burned,SNP 1.3:28.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:29.1Eyes downcast, not footloose,SNP 1.3:29.2senses guarded, mind protected,SNP 1.3:29.3uncorrupted, not burning with desire, SNP 1.3:29.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:3.1When feelings for friends and loved onesSNP 1.3:3.2are tied up in selfish love, you miss out on the goal. SNP 1.3:3.3Seeing this peril in intimacy, SNP 1.3:3.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:30.1PTS-VP-PLI 11Having shed the marks of the home life,SNP 1.3:30.2like the fallen leaves of the Shady Orchid Tree, SNP 1.3:30.3and gone forth in the ocher robe,SNP 1.3:30.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:31.1BJ 25.20Not wanton, nor rousing greed for tastes,SNP 1.3:31.2providing for no other, wandering indiscriminately for alms, SNP 1.3:31.3not attached to this family or that,SNP 1.3:31.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:32.1When you’ve given up five mental obstacles,SNP 1.3:32.2and expelled all corruptions, SNP 1.3:32.3and cut off affection and hate, being independent,SNP 1.3:32.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:33.1When you’ve put pleasure and pain behind you,SNP 1.3:33.2and former happiness and sadness, SNP 1.3:33.3and gained equanimity serene and pure,SNP 1.3:33.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:34.1With energy roused to reach the ultimate goal,SNP 1.3:34.2not sluggish in mind or lazy, SNP 1.3:34.3vigorous, strong and powerful,SNP 1.3:34.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:35.1Not neglecting retreat and absorption,SNP 1.3:35.2always living in line with the teachings, SNP 1.3:35.3comprehending the danger in rebirths,SNP 1.3:35.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:36.1One whose aim is the ending of craving—SNP 1.3:36.2diligent, clever, learned, mindful, resolute— SNP 1.3:36.3who has assessed the teaching and is bound for awakening, shouldSNP 1.3:36.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:37.1PTS-VP-PLI 12Like a lion not startled by sounds,SNP 1.3:37.2like wind not caught in a net, SNP 1.3:37.3like water not sticking to a lotus,SNP 1.3:37.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:38.1BJ 25.22Like the fierce-fanged lion, king of beasts,SNP 1.3:38.2who wanders as victor and master, SNP 1.3:38.3you should frequent remote lodgings, andSNP 1.3:38.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:39.1In time, cultivate freedom throughSNP 1.3:39.2love, compassion, rejoicing, and equanimity. SNP 1.3:39.3Not upset by anything in the world,SNP 1.3:39.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 7As a spreading bamboo gets entangled,SNP 1.3:4.2so does concern for partners and children. SNP 1.3:4.3Like a bamboo shoot unimpeded,SNP 1.3:4.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:40.1Having given up greed, hate, and delusion, SNP 1.3:40.2having burst apart the fetters, SNP 1.3:40.3unafraid at the end of life,SNP 1.3:40.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:41.1They befriend you and serve you for their own sake;SNP 1.3:41.2these days it’s hard to find friends lacking ulterior motive. SNP 1.3:41.3Impure folk cleverly profit themselves—SNP 1.3:41.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:5.1As a wild deer loose in the forestSNP 1.3:5.2grazes wherever it wants,SNP 1.3:5.3a smart person looking for freedom would SNP 1.3:5.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:6.1When among friends, whether staying in placeSNP 1.3:6.2or going on a journey, you’re always on call. SNP 1.3:6.3Looking for the uncoveted freedom,SNP 1.3:6.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:7.1Among friends you have fun and games,SNP 1.3:7.2and for children you are full of love. SNP 1.3:7.3Though loathe to depart from those you hold dear,SNP 1.3:7.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:8.1BJ 25.14At ease in any quarter, unresisting,SNP 1.3:8.2content with whatever comes your way; SNP 1.3:8.3prevailing over adversities, dauntless,SNP 1.3:8.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

SNP 1.3:9.1Even some renunciates are hard to please,SNP 1.3:9.2as are some layfolk dwelling at home. SNP 1.3:9.3Don’t worry about others’ children,SNP 1.3:9.4live alone like a rhino’s horn.

  • SNP 1.4:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.4:0.2With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

SNP 1.4:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 13So I have heard. SNP 1.4:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans in the Southern Hills near the brahmin village of Ekanāḷa. SNP 1.4:1.3Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer had harnessed around five hundred plows, it being the season for sowing. SNP 1.4:1.4Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to where Bhāradvāja the Farmer was working. SNP 1.4:1.5Now at that time Bhāradvāja the Farmer was distributing food. SNP 1.4:1.6Then the Buddha went to where the distribution was taking place and stood to one side.

SNP 1.4:10.1Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer filled a large bronze dish with milk-rice and presented it to the Buddha:SNP 1.4:10.2“Eat the milk-rice, Master Gotama, SNP 1.4:10.3you are truly a farmer. SNP 1.4:10.4For Master Gotama does the farming that has the Deathless as its fruit.”

SNP 1.4:11.1BJ 25.26“Food enchanted by a spell isn’t fit for me to eat. SNP 1.4:11.2That’s not the principle of those who see, brahmin. SNP 1.4:11.3The Buddhas reject things enchanted with spells. SNP 1.4:11.4Since there is such a principle, brahmin, that’s how they live.

SNP 1.4:12.1Serve with other food and drink SNP 1.4:12.2the consummate one, the great hermit, SNP 1.4:12.3with defilements ended and remorse stilled. SNP 1.4:12.4For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”

SNP 1.4:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 15“Then, Master Gotama, to whom should I give the milk-rice?” SNP 1.4:13.2“Brahmin, I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who can properly digest this milk-rice, except for the Realized One or one of his disciples. SNP 1.4:13.3Well then, brahmin, throw out the milk-rice where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.”

SNP 1.4:14.1So Bhāradvāja the Farmer dropped the milk-rice in water that had no living creatures. SNP 1.4:14.2And when the milk-rice was placed in the water, it sizzled and hissed, steaming and fuming. SNP 1.4:14.3Suppose there was an iron cauldron that had been heated all day. If you placed it in the water, it would sizzle and hiss, steaming and fuming. SNP 1.4:14.4In the same way, when the milk-rice was placed in the water, it sizzled and hissed, steaming and fuming.

SNP 1.4:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 16Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer, shocked and awestruck, went up to the Buddha, bowed down with his head at the Buddha’s feet, and said, SNP 1.4:15.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! SNP 1.4:15.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways. SNP 1.4:15.4I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. SNP 1.4:15.5Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”

SNP 1.4:16.1BJ 25.28And Bhāradvāja the Farmer received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence. SNP 1.4:16.2Not long after his ordination, Venerable Bhāradvāja, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness. SNP 1.4:16.3He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.” SNP 1.4:16.4And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.

SNP 1.4:2.1BJ 25.24Bhāradvāja the Farmer saw him standing for alms SNP 1.4:2.2and said to him, SNP 1.4:2.3“I plough and sow, ascetic, and then I eat. SNP 1.4:2.4You too should plough and sow, then you may eat.”

SNP 1.4:3.1“I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.” SNP 1.4:3.2“I don’t see Master Gotama with a yoke or plow or plowshare or goad or oxen, yet he says: SNP 1.4:3.4“I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.”

SNP 1.4:4.1Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer addressed the Buddha in verse:

SNP 1.4:5.1“You claim to be a farmer, SNP 1.4:5.2but I don’t see your plough. SNP 1.4:5.3If you’re a farmer, declare to me: SNP 1.4:5.4so that we can recognize a brahmin.”

SNP 1.4:6.1“Faith is my seed, austerity my rain, SNP 1.4:6.2and wisdom is my yoke and plough. SNP 1.4:6.3Conscience is my pole, mind my strap, SNP 1.4:6.4mindfulness my plowshare and goad.

SNP 1.4:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 14Guarded in body and speech, SNP 1.4:7.2I restrict my intake of food. SNP 1.4:7.3I use truth as my scythe, SNP 1.4:7.4and gentleness is my release.

SNP 1.4:8.1Energy is my beast of burden, SNP 1.4:8.2transporting me to a place of sanctuary. SNP 1.4:8.3It goes without turning back SNP 1.4:8.4where there is no sorrow.

SNP 1.4:9.1That’s how to do the farming SNP 1.4:9.2that has the Deathless as its fruit. SNP 1.4:9.3When you finish this farming SNP 1.4:9.4you’re released from all suffering.”

  • SNP 1.5:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.5:0.2With Cunda

SNP 1.5:1.1“I ask the sage abounding in wisdom,”SNP 1.5:1.2said Cunda the smith,SNP 1.5:1.3“the Buddha, master of the teaching, free of craving, SNP 1.5:1.4best of men, excellent charioteer, please tell me this:SNP 1.5:1.5how many ascetics are there in the world?”

SNP 1.5:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 17“There are four ascetics, not a fifth.”SNP 1.5:2.2said the Buddha to Cunda, SNP 1.5:2.3“Being asked to bear witness, I will explain them to you:SNP 1.5:2.4the path-victor, the path-teacher, SNP 1.5:2.5the path-liver, and the path-wrecker.”

SNP 1.5:3.1“Who is a path-victor according to the Buddhas?”SNP 1.5:3.2said Cunda the smith, SNP 1.5:3.3“and how is one an unequaled path-explainer?SNP 1.5:3.4Tell me when asked about one who lives the path, SNP 1.5:3.5then declare the path-wrecker.”

SNP 1.5:4.1BJ 25.30“Rid of doubt, free of thorns,SNP 1.5:4.2delighting in quenching, not fawning, SNP 1.5:4.3a guide for the world with its gods.SNP 1.5:4.4The Buddhas say one such is victor of the path.

SNP 1.5:5.1Knowing the ultimate as ultimate,SNP 1.5:5.2they explain and analyze the teaching right here. SNP 1.5:5.3That sage unstirred, with doubt cut off,SNP 1.5:5.4is the second mendicant, I say, the path-teacher.

SNP 1.5:6.1Living restrained and mindful on the pathSNP 1.5:6.2of the well-taught passages of teaching, SNP 1.5:6.3cultivating blameless states,SNP 1.5:6.4is the third mendicant, I say, the path-liver.

SNP 1.5:7.1Dressed like one true to their vows,SNP 1.5:7.2pushy, rude, a corrupter of families, SNP 1.5:7.3devious, unrestrained, chaff,SNP 1.5:7.4the path-wrecker’s life is a sham.

SNP 1.5:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 18A layperson who gets this,SNP 1.5:8.2a learned, wise noble disciple, SNP 1.5:8.3knows that ‘They are not all like that one’.SNP 1.5:8.4So when they see them they don’t lose their faith. SNP 1.5:8.5For how could one equate them—SNP 1.5:8.6the corrupt with the uncorrupt, the pure with the impure?”

  • SNP 1.6:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.6:0.2Downfalls

SNP 1.6:1.1So I have heard. SNP 1.6:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. SNP 1.6:1.3Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side. SNP 1.6:1.4Standing to one side, that deity addressed the Buddha in verse:

SNP 1.6:10.1“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:10.2this is the fourth downfall. SNP 1.6:10.3Tell us the fifth, Blessed One:SNP 1.6:10.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:11.1“He deceives with liesSNP 1.6:11.2ascetics and brahminsSNP 1.6:11.3and other renunciates, SNP 1.6:11.4and that leads to his downfall.”

SNP 1.6:12.1BJ 25.34“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:12.2this is the fifth downfall. SNP 1.6:12.3Tell us the sixth, Blessed One:SNP 1.6:12.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:13.1“A man with plenty of wealth—SNP 1.6:13.2gold and food—SNP 1.6:13.3eats delicacies alone, SNP 1.6:13.4and that leads to his downfall.”

SNP 1.6:14.1“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:14.2this is the sixth downfall. SNP 1.6:14.3Tell us the seventh, Blessed One:SNP 1.6:14.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:15.1“Vain of caste, wealth,SNP 1.6:15.2and clan, a manSNP 1.6:15.3looks down on his own family, SNP 1.6:15.4and that leads to his downfall.”

SNP 1.6:16.1“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:16.2this is the seventh downfall. SNP 1.6:16.3Tell us the eighth, Blessed One:SNP 1.6:16.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:17.1“In womanizing, drinking, SNP 1.6:17.2and gambling, a manSNP 1.6:17.3wastes all that he has earned, SNP 1.6:17.4and that leads to his downfall.”

SNP 1.6:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 20“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:18.2this is the eighth downfall. SNP 1.6:18.3Tell us the ninth, Blessed One:SNP 1.6:18.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:19.1“Not content with his own partners, SNP 1.6:19.2he debauches himself with prostitutes, SNP 1.6:19.3and with others’ partners,SNP 1.6:19.4and that leads to his downfall.”

SNP 1.6:2.1BJ 25.32“We ask GotamaSNP 1.6:2.2about a man’s downfall. SNP 1.6:2.3We have come to ask you sir:SNP 1.6:2.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:20.1“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:20.2this is the ninth downfall. SNP 1.6:20.3Tell us the tenth, Blessed One:SNP 1.6:20.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:21.1“A man well past his primeSNP 1.6:21.2marries a girl with budding breasts; SNP 1.6:21.3he cannot sleep for jealousy,SNP 1.6:21.4and that leads to his downfall.”

SNP 1.6:22.1“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:22.2this is the tenth downfall. SNP 1.6:22.3Tell us the eleventh, Blessed One:SNP 1.6:22.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:23.1BJ 25.36“He places in authoritySNP 1.6:23.2a woman or a man SNP 1.6:23.3who’s a drunkard and a spender,SNP 1.6:23.4and that leads to his downfall.”

SNP 1.6:24.1“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:24.2this is the eleventh downfall. SNP 1.6:24.3Tell us the twelfth, Blessed One:SNP 1.6:24.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:25.1“A man of little wealth and strong craving,SNP 1.6:25.2born into an aristocratic family, SNP 1.6:25.3sets his sights on kingship,SNP 1.6:25.4and that leads to his downfall.

SNP 1.6:26.1Seeing these downfalls in the world,SNP 1.6:26.2an astute and noble person, SNP 1.6:26.3accomplished in vision, SNP 1.6:26.4will enjoy a world of grace.”

SNP 1.6:3.1“It’s easy to know success,SNP 1.6:3.2and downfall is just as easy.SNP 1.6:3.3One who loves the teaching succeeds, SNP 1.6:3.4but a hater of the teaching meets their downfall.”

SNP 1.6:4.1“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:4.2this is the first downfall. SNP 1.6:4.3Tell us the second, Blessed One: SNP 1.6:4.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:5.1“The bad are dear to him,SNP 1.6:5.2he has no love for the good.SNP 1.6:5.3He believes the teaching of the bad; SNP 1.6:5.4and that leads to his downfall.”

SNP 1.6:6.1“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:6.2this is the second downfall. SNP 1.6:6.3Tell us the third, Blessed One: SNP 1.6:6.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 19“Fond of sleep, fond of company,SNP 1.6:7.2a man who does no work; SNP 1.6:7.3he’s lazy, marked by anger,SNP 1.6:7.4and that leads to his downfall.”

SNP 1.6:8.1“We get what you’re saying,SNP 1.6:8.2this is the third downfall. SNP 1.6:8.3Tell us the fourth, Blessed One: SNP 1.6:8.4what leads to downfall?”

SNP 1.6:9.1“Though able, he does not look after SNP 1.6:9.2his mother and father SNP 1.6:9.3when elderly, past their prime,SNP 1.6:9.4and that leads to his downfall.”

  • SNP 1.7:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.7:0.2The Lowlife

SNP 1.7:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 21So I have heard. SNP 1.7:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. SNP 1.7:1.3Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms. SNP 1.7:1.4Now at that time in the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshipper’s home the sacred flame had been kindled and the oblation prepared.SNP 1.7:1.5Wandering indiscriminately for almsfood in Sāvatthī, the Buddha approached Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper’s house.

SNP 1.7:10.1For his own sake or the sake of another,SNP 1.7:10.2or for the sake of wealth, a man SNP 1.7:10.3tells a lie when asked to bear witness:SNP 1.7:10.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:11.1He is spied among the partnersSNP 1.7:11.2of relatives and friends, SNP 1.7:11.3by force or seduction:SNP 1.7:11.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:12.1Though able, he does not look after SNP 1.7:12.2his mother and father SNP 1.7:12.3when elderly, past their prime:SNP 1.7:12.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:13.1BJ 25.40He hits or verbally abusesSNP 1.7:13.2his mother or father, SNP 1.7:13.3brother, sister, or mother-in-law:SNP 1.7:13.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:14.1When asked about the good,SNP 1.7:14.2he teaches what is bad, SNP 1.7:14.3giving secretive advice:SNP 1.7:14.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:15.1Having done a bad deed, he wishes, SNP 1.7:15.2‘May no-one find me out!’ SNP 1.7:15.3His deeds are underhand:SNP 1.7:15.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:16.1When visiting another familySNP 1.7:16.2he eats their delicious food, SNP 1.7:16.3but does not return the honor:SNP 1.7:16.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:17.1He deceives with liesSNP 1.7:17.2ascetics and brahminsSNP 1.7:17.3and other renunciates: SNP 1.7:17.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 23When time comes to offer a mealSNP 1.7:18.2to brahmins or ascetics, SNP 1.7:18.3he abuses them and does not give:SNP 1.7:18.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:19.1He talks about what never happened,SNP 1.7:19.2being wrapped up in delusion, SNP 1.7:19.3chasing after some item or other:SNP 1.7:19.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:2.1Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper saw the Buddha coming off in the distance SNP 1.7:2.2and said to him, SNP 1.7:2.3“Stop right there, shaveling!SNP 1.7:2.4Right there, fake ascetic!SNP 1.7:2.5Right there, lowlife!”

SNP 1.7:20.1He extols himselfSNP 1.7:20.2and disparages others,SNP 1.7:20.3brought down by his pride: SNP 1.7:20.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:21.1He’s a bully and a miser,SNP 1.7:21.2of wicked desires, stingy, and devious, SNP 1.7:21.3shameless, imprudent:SNP 1.7:21.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:22.1He insults the BuddhaSNP 1.7:22.2or his disciple,SNP 1.7:22.3whether lay or renunciate: SNP 1.7:22.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:23.1He claims to be a perfected one,SNP 1.7:23.2when he really is no such thing. SNP 1.7:23.3In the world with its Brahmās,SNP 1.7:23.4that crook is truly the lowest lowlife.SNP 1.7:23.5These who are called lowlifes SNP 1.7:23.6I have explained to you.

SNP 1.7:24.1BJ 25.42You’re not a lowlife by birth,SNP 1.7:24.2nor by birth are you a brahmin. SNP 1.7:24.3You’re a lowlife by your deeds, SNP 1.7:24.4by deeds you’re a brahmin.

SNP 1.7:25.1And also you should knowSNP 1.7:25.2according to this example. SNP 1.7:25.3Sopaka the outcaste’s sonSNP 1.7:25.4became renowned as Mātaṅga.

SNP 1.7:26.1PTS-VP-PLI 24Mātaṅga achieved the highest fameSNP 1.7:26.2so very hard to find. SNP 1.7:26.3Lots of aristocrats and brahminsSNP 1.7:26.4came to serve him.

SNP 1.7:27.1He ascended the stainless highwaySNP 1.7:27.2that leads to the heavens; SNP 1.7:27.3having discarded sensual desire, SNP 1.7:27.4he was reborn in a Brahmā realm.SNP 1.7:27.5His birth did not prevent him SNP 1.7:27.6from rebirth in the Brahmā realm.

SNP 1.7:28.1Those born in a brahmin familySNP 1.7:28.2who recite as kinsmen of the hymns, SNP 1.7:28.3are often discoveredSNP 1.7:28.4in the midst of wicked deeds.

SNP 1.7:29.1Blameworthy in the present life,SNP 1.7:29.2and in the next, a bad destination. SNP 1.7:29.3Their birth does not prevent themSNP 1.7:29.4from blame or bad destiny.

SNP 1.7:3.1BJ 25.38When he said this, the Buddha said to him, SNP 1.7:3.2“But brahmin, do you know what is a lowlife or what are the qualities that make you a lowlife?”SNP 1.7:3.3“No I do not, Master Gotama.SNP 1.7:3.4Please, Master Gotama, teach me this matter so I can understand what is a lowlife or what are the qualities that make you a lowlife.” SNP 1.7:3.5“Well then, brahmin, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.” SNP 1.7:3.6“Yes sir,” Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper replied. SNP 1.7:3.7The Buddha said this:

SNP 1.7:30.1You’re not a lowlife by birth,SNP 1.7:30.2nor by birth are you a brahmin. SNP 1.7:30.3You’re a lowlife by your deeds, SNP 1.7:30.4by deeds you’re a brahmin.”

SNP 1.7:31.1PTS-VP-PLI 25When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper said to the Buddha, SNP 1.7:31.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! … SNP 1.7:31.3From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

SNP 1.7:4.1“Irritable and hostile,SNP 1.7:4.2wicked and offensive,SNP 1.7:4.3a man deficient in view, deceitful: SNP 1.7:4.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:5.1He harms living creaturesSNP 1.7:5.2born of womb or of egg,SNP 1.7:5.3and has no kindness for creatures: SNP 1.7:5.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 22He destroys and devastatesSNP 1.7:6.2villages and towns, SNP 1.7:6.3a notorious oppressor:SNP 1.7:6.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:7.1Whether in village or wilderness, SNP 1.7:7.2he steals what belongs to others, SNP 1.7:7.3taking what has not been given:SNP 1.7:7.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:8.1Having fallen into debt, SNP 1.7:8.2when pressed to pay up he flees, saying SNP 1.7:8.3‘I don’t owe you anything!’:SNP 1.7:8.4know him as a lowlife.

SNP 1.7:9.1Wanting some item or other,SNP 1.7:9.2he attacks a person in the street SNP 1.7:9.3and takes it:SNP 1.7:9.4know him as a lowlife.

  • SNP 1.8:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.8:0.2The Discourse on Love

SNP 1.8:1.1BJ 25.44This is what should be done by those who are skilled in goodness,SNP 1.8:1.2and have known the state of peace. SNP 1.8:1.3Let them be able and upright, very upright, SNP 1.8:1.4easy to speak to, gentle and humble;

SNP 1.8:10.1Avoiding harmful views,SNP 1.8:10.2virtuous, accomplished in insight, SNP 1.8:10.3with sensual desire dispelled,SNP 1.8:10.4they never come back to a womb again.

SNP 1.8:2.1content and unburdensome,SNP 1.8:2.2unbusied, living lightly, SNP 1.8:2.3alert, with senses calmed,SNP 1.8:2.4courteous, not fawning on families.

SNP 1.8:3.1Let them not do the slightest thingSNP 1.8:3.2that others might blame with reason. SNP 1.8:3.3May they be happy and safe!SNP 1.8:3.4May all beings be happy!

SNP 1.8:4.1Whatever living creatures there areSNP 1.8:4.2with not a one left out— SNP 1.8:4.3frail or firm, long or large,SNP 1.8:4.4medium, small, tiny or round,

SNP 1.8:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 26visible or invisible,SNP 1.8:5.2living far or near, SNP 1.8:5.3those born or to be born:SNP 1.8:5.4May all beings be happy!

SNP 1.8:6.1BJ 25.46Let none turn from another,SNP 1.8:6.2nor look down on anyone anywhere. SNP 1.8:6.3Though provoked or aggrieved,SNP 1.8:6.4let them not wish pain on each other.

SNP 1.8:7.1Even as a mother would protect with her lifeSNP 1.8:7.2her child, her only child, SNP 1.8:7.3so too for all creaturesSNP 1.8:7.4unfold a boundless heart.

SNP 1.8:8.1With love for the whole world,SNP 1.8:8.2unfold a boundless heart. SNP 1.8:8.3Above, below, all round, SNP 1.8:8.4unconstricted, without enemy or foe.

SNP 1.8:9.1When standing, walking, sitting,SNP 1.8:9.2or lying down while yet unweary, SNP 1.8:9.3keep this ever in mind;SNP 1.8:9.4for this, they say, is a holy abiding in this life.

  • SNP 1.9:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.9:0.2With Hemavata

SNP 1.9:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 27“Today is the fifteenth day sabbath,”SNP 1.9:1.2said Sātāgira, the native spirit of mount Sātā, SNP 1.9:1.3“a holy night is at hand.SNP 1.9:1.4Come now, let us see Gotama,SNP 1.9:1.5the Teacher of peerless name.”

SNP 1.9:10.1BJ 25.50“Isn’t he accomplished in knowledge?” SNP 1.9:10.2said Hemavata, SNP 1.9:10.3“And doesn’t he live a pure life?SNP 1.9:10.4Aren’t his defilements all ended? SNP 1.9:10.5Doesn’t he have no future lives?”

SNP 1.9:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 29“He is accomplished in knowledge,” SNP 1.9:11.2said Sātāgira, SNP 1.9:11.3“and he does live a pure life.SNP 1.9:11.4His defilements are all ended, SNP 1.9:11.5there are no future lives for him.”

SNP 1.9:12.1“Accomplished is the sage’s mindSNP 1.9:12.2in action and in speech, SNP 1.9:12.3and he’s accomplished in knowledge and conductSNP 1.9:12.4as per the teaching you praise.”

SNP 1.9:13.1“Accomplished is the sage’s mindSNP 1.9:13.2in action and in speech, SNP 1.9:13.3and he’s accomplished in knowledge and conductSNP 1.9:13.4as per the teaching you rejoice in.

SNP 1.9:14.1Accomplished is the sage’s mindSNP 1.9:14.2in action and in speech, SNP 1.9:14.3and he’s accomplished in knowledge and conduct:SNP 1.9:14.4come now, let us see Gotama.”

SNP 1.9:15.1“The hero so lean, with antelope calves, SNP 1.9:15.2not greedy, eating little, SNP 1.9:15.3the sage meditating alone in the forest,SNP 1.9:15.4come now, let us see Gotama.

SNP 1.9:16.1An elephant, wandering alone like a lion, SNP 1.9:16.2unconcerned for sensual pleasures, SNP 1.9:16.3let’s approach him and ask aboutSNP 1.9:16.4release from the snare of death.”

SNP 1.9:17.1“The communicator, the instructor,SNP 1.9:17.2who has gone beyond all things, SNP 1.9:17.3Awakened, beyond enmity and fear,SNP 1.9:17.4let us ask Gotama.”

SNP 1.9:18.1“What has the world arisen in?”SNP 1.9:18.2said Hemavata, SNP 1.9:18.3What does it get close to? SNP 1.9:18.4By grasping what SNP 1.9:18.5is the world troubled in what?”

SNP 1.9:19.1BJ 25.52PTS-VP-PLI 30“The world’s arisen in six,” SNP 1.9:19.2said the Buddha to Hemavata.SNP 1.9:19.3“It gets close to six. SNP 1.9:19.4By grasping at these six, SNP 1.9:19.5the world’s troubled in six.”

SNP 1.9:2.1“Isn’t his mind well-disposed,”SNP 1.9:2.2said Hemavata, the native spirit of the Himalayas, SNP 1.9:2.3“impartial towards all creatures?SNP 1.9:2.4And aren’t his thoughts under control SNP 1.9:2.5when it comes to likes and dislikes?”

SNP 1.9:20.1“What is that graspingSNP 1.9:20.2by which the world is troubled? SNP 1.9:20.3Tell us the exit when asked:SNP 1.9:20.4how is one released from all suffering?”

SNP 1.9:21.1“There are five kinds of sensual stimulation in the world, SNP 1.9:21.2and the mind is said to be the sixth. SNP 1.9:21.3When you’ve discarded desire for these, SNP 1.9:21.4you’re released from all suffering.

SNP 1.9:22.1This is the exit from the world,SNP 1.9:22.2explained in accord with the truth. SNP 1.9:22.3The way I’ve explained it is howSNP 1.9:22.4you’re released from all suffering.”

SNP 1.9:23.1“Who here crosses the flood, SNP 1.9:23.2Who crosses the deluge? SNP 1.9:23.3Who, not standing and unsupported, SNP 1.9:23.4does not sink in the deep?”

SNP 1.9:24.1“Someone who is always endowed with ethics, SNP 1.9:24.2wise and serene, SNP 1.9:24.3inwardly reflective, mindful,SNP 1.9:24.4crosses the flood so hard to cross.

SNP 1.9:25.1Someone who desists from sensual perception, SNP 1.9:25.2who has escaped all fetters, SNP 1.9:25.3and is finished with relishing of rebirth,SNP 1.9:25.4does not sink in the deep.”

SNP 1.9:26.1“Behold him of wisdom deep who sees the subtle meaning,SNP 1.9:26.2who has nothing, unattached to sensual life, SNP 1.9:26.3everywhere free, SNP 1.9:26.4the great hermit treading the holy road.

SNP 1.9:27.1BJ 25.54PTS-VP-PLI 31Behold him of peerless name who sees the subtle meaning, SNP 1.9:27.2giver of wisdom, unattached to the realm of sensuality: SNP 1.9:27.3see him, the all-knower, so very intelligent, SNP 1.9:27.4the great hermit treading the noble road.”

SNP 1.9:28.1“It was a fine sight for us today,SNP 1.9:28.2a good dawn, a good rising, SNP 1.9:28.3to see the Awakened One,SNP 1.9:28.4the undefiled one who has crossed the flood.

SNP 1.9:29.1These thousand native spiritsSNP 1.9:29.2powerful and glorious, SNP 1.9:29.3all go to your for refuge,SNP 1.9:29.4you are our supreme Teacher.

SNP 1.9:3.1BJ 25.48“His mind is well-disposed,”SNP 1.9:3.2said Sātāgira, SNP 1.9:3.3“impartial towards all creatures.SNP 1.9:3.4His thoughts are under control SNP 1.9:3.5when it comes to his likes and dislikes.”

SNP 1.9:30.1We shall journeySNP 1.9:30.2village to village, peak to peak, SNP 1.9:30.3paying homage to the Buddha,SNP 1.9:30.4and the natural excellence of the teaching!”

SNP 1.9:4.1“Doesn’t he not steal?”SNP 1.9:4.2said Hemavata,SNP 1.9:4.3“And doesn’t he harm not a creature? SNP 1.9:4.4Isn’t he far from negligence?SNP 1.9:4.5And doesn’t he not neglect absorption?”

SNP 1.9:5.1“He does not take what is not given,”SNP 1.9:5.2said Sātāgira, SNP 1.9:5.3“and he harms not a creature.SNP 1.9:5.4He is far from negligence—SNP 1.9:5.5the Buddha does not neglect absorption.”

SNP 1.9:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 28“Doesn’t he avoid lying?”SNP 1.9:6.2said Hemavata, SNP 1.9:6.3“And doesn’t he not speak sharply?SNP 1.9:6.4Doesn’t he avoid divisive speech, SNP 1.9:6.5as well as speaking nonsense?”

SNP 1.9:7.1“He does not lie,”SNP 1.9:7.2said Sātāgira,SNP 1.9:7.3“nor does he speak sharply. SNP 1.9:7.4He avoids divisive speech,SNP 1.9:7.5and speaks words of wise counsel.”

SNP 1.9:8.1“Doesn’t he find sensual pleasures unattractive?”SNP 1.9:8.2said Hemavata, SNP 1.9:8.3“And isn’t his mind unclouded?SNP 1.9:8.4Hasn’t he escaped delusion?SNP 1.9:8.5And isn’t he seer of truths?”

SNP 1.9:9.1“He does not find sensual pleasures attractive,”SNP 1.9:9.2said Sātāgira, SNP 1.9:9.3“and his mind is unclouded.SNP 1.9:9.4He has escaped all delusion—SNP 1.9:9.5the Buddha is seer of truths.”

  • SNP 1.10:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.10:0.2With Āḷavaka

SNP 1.10:1.1So I have heard. SNP 1.10:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Āḷavī in the haunt of the native spirit Āḷavaka. SNP 1.10:1.3Then the native spirit Āḷavaka went up to the Buddha, and said to him: SNP 1.10:1.4“Get out, ascetic!” SNP 1.10:1.5Saying, “All right, sir,” the Buddha went out. SNP 1.10:1.6“Get in, ascetic!” SNP 1.10:1.7Saying, “All right, sir,” the Buddha went in.

SNP 1.10:10.1“How do you get wisdom? SNP 1.10:10.2How do you earn wealth? SNP 1.10:10.3How do you get a good reputation? SNP 1.10:10.4How do you hold on to friends? SNP 1.10:10.5How do the departed not grieve SNP 1.10:10.6when passing from this world to the next?”

SNP 1.10:11.1“One who is diligent and discerning SNP 1.10:11.2gains wisdom by wanting to learn, SNP 1.10:11.3having faith in the perfected ones, SNP 1.10:11.4and the teaching for becoming extinguished.

SNP 1.10:12.1Being responsible, acting appropriately, SNP 1.10:12.2and working hard you earn wealth. SNP 1.10:12.3Truthfulness wins you a good reputation. SNP 1.10:12.4You hold on to friends by giving.

SNP 1.10:13.1A faithful householder SNP 1.10:13.2who has these four qualities SNP 1.10:13.3does not grieve after passing away: SNP 1.10:13.4truth, principle, steadfastness, and generosity.

SNP 1.10:14.1Go ahead, ask others as well, SNP 1.10:14.2there are many ascetics and brahmins. SNP 1.10:14.3See whether anything better is found SNP 1.10:14.4than truth, self-control, generosity, and patience.”

SNP 1.10:15.1“Why now would I question SNP 1.10:15.2the many ascetics and brahmins? SNP 1.10:15.3Today I understand SNP 1.10:15.4what’s good for the next life.

SNP 1.10:16.1It was truly for my benefit SNP 1.10:16.2that the Buddha came to stay at Āḷavī. SNP 1.10:16.3Today I understand SNP 1.10:16.4where a gift is very fruitful.

SNP 1.10:17.1I myself will journey SNP 1.10:17.2village to village, town to town, SNP 1.10:17.3paying homage to the Buddha,SNP 1.10:17.4and the natural excellence of the teaching!”

SNP 1.10:2.1BJ 25.56For a second time … SNP 1.10:2.2And for a third time the native spirit Āḷavaka said to the Buddha, SNP 1.10:2.3“Get out, ascetic!” SNP 1.10:2.4Saying, “All right, sir,” the Buddha went out. SNP 1.10:2.5“Get in, ascetic!” SNP 1.10:2.6Saying, “All right, sir,” the Buddha went in.

SNP 1.10:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 32And for a fourth time the native spirit Āḷavaka said to the Buddha, SNP 1.10:3.2“Get out, ascetic!” SNP 1.10:3.3“No, sir, I won’t get out. SNP 1.10:3.4Do what you must.”

SNP 1.10:4.1“I will ask you a question, ascetic. SNP 1.10:4.2If you don’t answer me, I’ll drive you insane, or explode your heart, or grab you by the feet and throw you to the far shore of the Ganges!”

SNP 1.10:5.1“I don’t see anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans who could do that to me. SNP 1.10:5.2But anyway, ask what you wish.” SNP 1.10:5.3Then the native spirit Āḷavaka addressed the Buddha in verse:

SNP 1.10:6.1“What’s a person’s best wealth? SNP 1.10:6.2What brings happiness when practiced well? SNP 1.10:6.3What’s the sweetest taste of all? SNP 1.10:6.4The one who they say has the best life: how do they live?”

SNP 1.10:7.1“Faith here is a person’s best wealth. SNP 1.10:7.2the teaching brings happiness when practiced well. SNP 1.10:7.3Truth is the sweetest taste of all. SNP 1.10:7.4The one who they say has the best life lives by wisdom.”

SNP 1.10:8.1“How do you cross the flood? SNP 1.10:8.2How do you cross the deluge? SNP 1.10:8.3How do you get over suffering? SNP 1.10:8.4How do you get purified?”

SNP 1.10:9.1BJ 25.58PTS-VP-PLI 33“By faith you cross the flood, SNP 1.10:9.2and by diligence the deluge. SNP 1.10:9.3By energy you get past suffering, SNP 1.10:9.4and you’re purified by wisdom.”

  • SNP 1.11:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.11:0.2Victory

SNP 1.11:1.1BJ 25.60PTS-VP-PLI 34Walking and standing, SNP 1.11:1.2sitting and lying down, SNP 1.11:1.3extending and contracting the limbs:SNP 1.11:1.4these are the movements of the body.

SNP 1.11:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 35A wise mendicant here,SNP 1.11:10.2having heard the Buddha’s words, SNP 1.11:10.3fully understands it,SNP 1.11:10.4for they see it as it is.

SNP 1.11:11.1“As this is, so is that,SNP 1.11:11.2as that is, so is this.” SNP 1.11:11.3They’d reject desire for the bodySNP 1.11:11.4inside and out.

SNP 1.11:12.1That wise mendicant hereSNP 1.11:12.2rid of desire and lust, SNP 1.11:12.3has found the deathless peace,SNP 1.11:12.4extinguishment, the imperishable state.

SNP 1.11:13.1This two-legged body is dirty and stinking,SNP 1.11:13.2full of different carcasses, SNP 1.11:13.3and oozing all over the place—SNP 1.11:13.4but still it is cherished!

SNP 1.11:14.1And if, on account of this body,SNP 1.11:14.2someone prides themselves SNP 1.11:14.3or looks down on others—SNP 1.11:14.4what is that but a failure to see?

SNP 1.11:2.1Linked together by bones and sinews,SNP 1.11:2.2plastered over with flesh and hide, SNP 1.11:2.3and covered by the skin,SNP 1.11:2.4the body is not seen as it is.

SNP 1.11:3.1It’s full of guts and belly,SNP 1.11:3.2liver and bladder, SNP 1.11:3.3heart and lungs,SNP 1.11:3.4kidney and spleen,

SNP 1.11:4.1spit and snot,SNP 1.11:4.2sweat and fat,SNP 1.11:4.3blood and synovial fluid, SNP 1.11:4.4bile and grease.

SNP 1.11:5.1Then in nine streamsSNP 1.11:5.2the filth is always flowing. SNP 1.11:5.3There is muck from the eyes,SNP 1.11:5.4wax from the ears,

SNP 1.11:6.1and snot from the nostrils.SNP 1.11:6.2The mouth sometimes vomits SNP 1.11:6.3bile and sometimes phlegm.SNP 1.11:6.4And from the body, sweat and dirt.

SNP 1.11:7.1Then there is the hollow headSNP 1.11:7.2all filled with brains. SNP 1.11:7.3Governed by ignorance, SNP 1.11:7.4the fool thinks it’s lovely.

SNP 1.11:8.1BJ 25.62And when it lies dead,SNP 1.11:8.2bloated and livid, SNP 1.11:8.3discarded in a charnel ground,SNP 1.11:8.4the relatives forget it.

SNP 1.11:9.1It’s devoured by dogs,SNP 1.11:9.2by jackals, wolves, and worms. SNP 1.11:9.3It’s devoured by crows and vultures,SNP 1.11:9.4and any other creatures there.

  • SNP 1.12:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 1.12:0.2The Sage

SNP 1.12:1.1Peril stems from intimacy,SNP 1.12:1.2dust comes from a home. SNP 1.12:1.3Freedom from home and intimacy:SNP 1.12:1.4that is the sage’s vision.

SNP 1.12:10.1Restrained, they do no evil,SNP 1.12:10.2young or middle-aged, the sage is self-controlled. SNP 1.12:10.3Irreproachable, he does not insult anyone:SNP 1.12:10.4that’s who the wise know as a sage.

SNP 1.12:11.1When one who lives on charity receives alms,SNP 1.12:11.2from the top, the middle, or the leftovers, SNP 1.12:11.3they think it unworthy to praise or put down:SNP 1.12:11.4that’s who the wise know as a sage.

SNP 1.12:12.1The sage lives refraining from sex,SNP 1.12:12.2even when young is not tied down, SNP 1.12:12.3refraining from indulgence and negligence, freed:SNP 1.12:12.4that’s who the wise know as a sage.

SNP 1.12:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 38Understanding the world, the seer of the ultimate goal,SNP 1.12:13.2the poised one who has crossed the flood and the ocean, SNP 1.12:13.3has cut the ties, unattached and undefiled:SNP 1.12:13.4that’s who the wise know as a sage.

SNP 1.12:14.1The two are not the same, far apart in lifestyle and conduct—SNP 1.12:14.2the householder providing for a wife, and the selfless one true to their vows. SNP 1.12:14.3The unrestrained householder kills other creatures,SNP 1.12:14.4while the restrained sage always protects living creatures.

SNP 1.12:15.1As the crested blue-necked peacock flying through the skySNP 1.12:15.2never approaches the speed of the swan, SNP 1.12:15.3so the householder cannot compete with the mendicant,SNP 1.12:15.4the sage meditating secluded in the woods.

SNP 1.12:2.1Having cut down what’s grown, they wouldn’t replant,SNP 1.12:2.2nor would they nurture what’s growing. SNP 1.12:2.3That’s who they call a sage wandering alone,SNP 1.12:2.4the great hermit has seen the state of peace.

SNP 1.12:3.1BJ 25.64PTS-VP-PLI 36Having assessed the fields and measured the seeds, SNP 1.12:3.2they wouldn’t nurture them with moisture.SNP 1.12:3.3Truly that sage sees the utter ending of rebirth; SNP 1.12:3.4when logic’s left behind, judgments no longer apply.

SNP 1.12:4.1Understanding all the planes of rebirth,SNP 1.12:4.2not wanting a single one of them, SNP 1.12:4.3Truly that sage freed of greedSNP 1.12:4.4need not strive, for they have reached the far shore.

SNP 1.12:5.1The champion, all-knower, so very intelligent, SNP 1.12:5.2unsullied in the midst of all things, SNP 1.12:5.3has given up all, freed in the ending of craving:SNP 1.12:5.4that’s who the wise know as a sage.

SNP 1.12:6.1Strong in wisdom, with precepts and observances intact, SNP 1.12:6.2serene, loving absorption, mindful, SNP 1.12:6.3released from chains, kind, undefiled:SNP 1.12:6.4that’s who the wise know as a sage.

SNP 1.12:7.1The diligent sage wandering alone,SNP 1.12:7.2is unaffected by praise and blame— SNP 1.12:7.3like a lion not startled by sounds,SNP 1.12:7.4like wind not caught in a net, SNP 1.12:7.5like water not sticking to a lotus.SNP 1.12:7.6Leader of others, not by others led: SNP 1.12:7.7that’s who the wise know as a sage.

SNP 1.12:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 37Steady as a post in a bathing-placeSNP 1.12:8.2when others speak endlessly against them, SNP 1.12:8.3freed of greed, with senses stilled:SNP 1.12:8.4that’s who the wise know as a sage.

SNP 1.12:9.1BJ 25.66Steadfast, straight as a shuttle,SNP 1.12:9.2horrified by wicked deeds, SNP 1.12:9.3discerning the just and the unjust:SNP 1.12:9.4that’s who the wise know as a sage.

  • SNP 2.1:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.1:0.2Gems

SNP 2.1:1.1BJ 25.68PTS-VP-PLI 39Whatever beings have gathered here, SNP 2.1:1.2on the ground or in the sky:SNP 2.1:1.3may beings all be of happy heart, SNP 2.1:1.4and listen carefully to what is said.

SNP 2.1:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 41When they attain to visionSNP 2.1:10.2they give up three things: SNP 2.1:10.3identity view, doubt, and anySNP 2.1:10.4attachment to precepts and observances.

SNP 2.1:11.1They’re freed from the four places of loss,SNP 2.1:11.2and unable to perform the six grave crimes. SNP 2.1:11.3This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:SNP 2.1:11.4by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:12.1Even if they do a bad deedSNP 2.1:12.2by body, speech, or mind, SNP 2.1:12.3they are unable to conceal it;SNP 2.1:12.4they say this inability applies to one who has seen the truth. SNP 2.1:12.5This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:SNP 2.1:12.6by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:13.1BJ 25.72Like a tall forest tree crowned with flowersSNP 2.1:13.2in the first month of summer; SNP 2.1:13.3that’s how he taught the superb Dhamma,SNP 2.1:13.4leading to quenching, the ultimate benefit. SNP 2.1:13.5This sublime gem is in the Buddha:SNP 2.1:13.6by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:14.1The superb, knower of the superb, giver of the superb, bringer of the superb;SNP 2.1:14.2taught the superb Dhamma supreme. SNP 2.1:14.3This sublime gem is in the Buddha:SNP 2.1:14.4by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 42The old is ended, nothing new is produced.SNP 2.1:15.2their minds have no desire for future rebirth. SNP 2.1:15.3Withered are the seeds, there’s no desire for growth,SNP 2.1:15.4those wise ones are extinguished just like this lamp. SNP 2.1:15.5This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:SNP 2.1:15.6by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:16.1Whatever beings have gathered here,SNP 2.1:16.2on the ground or in the sky: SNP 2.1:16.3the Realized One is honored by gods and humans!SNP 2.1:16.4We bow to the Buddha! May you be safe!

SNP 2.1:17.1Whatever beings have gathered here,SNP 2.1:17.2on the ground or in the sky: SNP 2.1:17.3the Realized One is honored by gods and humans!SNP 2.1:17.4We bow to the Dhamma! May you be safe!

SNP 2.1:18.1Whatever beings have gathered here,SNP 2.1:18.2on the ground or in the sky: SNP 2.1:18.3the Realized One is honored by gods and humans!SNP 2.1:18.4We bow to the Saṅgha! May you be safe!

SNP 2.1:2.1So pay heed, all you beings,SNP 2.1:2.2have love for humankind, SNP 2.1:2.3who day and night bring offerings;SNP 2.1:2.4please protect them diligently.

SNP 2.1:3.1There’s no wealth here or beyond,SNP 2.1:3.2no sublime gem in the heavens, SNP 2.1:3.3that equals the Realized One.SNP 2.1:3.4This sublime gem is in the Buddha: SNP 2.1:3.5by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:4.1Ending, dispassion, the undying, the sublime,SNP 2.1:4.2attained by the Sakyan Sage immersed in samādhi; SNP 2.1:4.3there is nothing equal to that Dhamma.SNP 2.1:4.4This sublime gem is in the Dhamma: SNP 2.1:4.5by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 40The purity praised by the highest BuddhaSNP 2.1:5.2is said to be the “immersion with immediate fruit”; SNP 2.1:5.3no equal to that immersion is found. SNP 2.1:5.4This sublime gem is in the Dhamma: SNP 2.1:5.5by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:6.1The eight individuals praised by the good,SNP 2.1:6.2are the four pairs of the Holy One’s disciples; SNP 2.1:6.3they are worthy of religious donations,SNP 2.1:6.4what’s given to them is very fruitful. SNP 2.1:6.5This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:SNP 2.1:6.6by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:7.1BJ 25.70Dedicated to Gotama’s dispensation,SNP 2.1:7.2strong-minded, free of sense desire, SNP 2.1:7.3they’ve attained the goal, plunged into the deathless,SNP 2.1:7.4and enjoy the quenching they’ve freely gained. SNP 2.1:7.5This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:SNP 2.1:7.6by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:8.1As a well planted boundary-pillarSNP 2.1:8.2is not shaken by the four winds, SNP 2.1:8.3I say a good person is like this,SNP 2.1:8.4who sees the noble truths in experience. SNP 2.1:8.5This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:SNP 2.1:8.6by this truth, may you be well!

SNP 2.1:9.1Those who fathom the noble truths SNP 2.1:9.2taught by the one of deep wisdom, SNP 2.1:9.3do not take an eighth life,SNP 2.1:9.4even if they are hugely negligent. SNP 2.1:9.5This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:SNP 2.1:9.6by this truth, may you be well!

  • SNP 2.2:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.2:0.2Carrion

SNP 2.2:1.1BJ 25.74“The good eat properly obtainedSNP 2.2:1.2millet, wild grains, broomcorn, SNP 2.2:1.3greens, tubers, and squashes.SNP 2.2:1.4They don’t lie to get what they want.

SNP 2.2:10.1Greedy, hostile, aggressive to others,SNP 2.2:10.2and addicted to evil—those beings pass into darkness, SNP 2.2:10.3falling headlong into hell:SNP 2.2:10.4this is carrion, not eating meat.

SNP 2.2:11.1Not fish or flesh or fasting,SNP 2.2:11.2being naked or shaven, or dreadlocks or dirt, SNP 2.2:11.3not rough hides or serving the sacred flame,SNP 2.2:11.4or the many austerities in the world aimed at immortality, SNP 2.2:11.5not hymns or oblations, sacrifices or seasonal observances,SNP 2.2:11.6will cleanse a mortal not free of doubt.

SNP 2.2:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 45Guarding the streams of sense impressions, wander with faculties conquered, SNP 2.2:12.2standing on the teaching, delighting in sincerity and gentleness.SNP 2.2:12.3The wise have escaped their chains and given up all pain; SNP 2.2:12.4they don’t cling to the seen and the heard.”

SNP 2.2:13.1BJ 25.78The Buddha explained this matter to him again and again,SNP 2.2:13.2until the master of hymns understood it. SNP 2.2:13.3It was illustrated with colorful versesSNP 2.2:13.4by the carrion-free sage, unattached, hard to trace.

SNP 2.2:14.1Having heard the fine words of the Buddha,SNP 2.2:14.2that are carrion-free, getting rid of all suffering; SNP 2.2:14.3humbled, he bowed to the Realized One,SNP 2.2:14.4and right away begged to go forth.

SNP 2.2:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 43But what you eat is nicely cooked and prepared,SNP 2.2:2.2delicious food that others have given. SNP 2.2:2.3Enjoying a dish of fine rice,SNP 2.2:2.4Kassapa, you eat carrion.

SNP 2.2:3.1‘Carrion is not appropriate for me’;SNP 2.2:3.2so you said, kinsman of Brahmā. SNP 2.2:3.3Yet here you are enjoying a dish of fine rice,SNP 2.2:3.4nicely cooked with the flesh of fowl. SNP 2.2:3.5I’m asking you this, Kassapa: SNP 2.2:3.6what do you take to be carrion?”

SNP 2.2:4.1“Killing living creatures, mutilation, murder, abduction;SNP 2.2:4.2stealing, lying, cheating and fraud, SNP 2.2:4.3learning crooked spells, adultery:SNP 2.2:4.4this is carrion, not eating meat.

SNP 2.2:5.1People here with unbridled sensuality, SNP 2.2:5.2greedy for tastes, mixed up in impurity, SNP 2.2:5.3nihilists, immoral, intractable:SNP 2.2:5.4this is carrion, not eating meat.

SNP 2.2:6.1Brutal and rough backbiters,SNP 2.2:6.2pitiless and arrogant betrayers of friends, SNP 2.2:6.3misers who never give anything:SNP 2.2:6.4this is carrion, not eating meat.

SNP 2.2:7.1BJ 25.76PTS-VP-PLI 44Anger, vanity, obstinacy, contrariness, SNP 2.2:7.2deceit, jealousy, boastfulness,SNP 2.2:7.3haughtiness, wicked associates: SNP 2.2:7.4this is carrion, not eating meat.

SNP 2.2:8.1The ill-behaved, debt-evaders, slanderers,SNP 2.2:8.2business cheats and con-artists, SNP 2.2:8.3vile men committing depravity:SNP 2.2:8.4this is carrion, not eating meat.

SNP 2.2:9.1People here who can’t stop harming living creatures, SNP 2.2:9.2taking from others, intent on hurting, SNP 2.2:9.3immoral, cruel, harsh, lacking regard for others:SNP 2.2:9.4this is carrion, not eating meat.

  • SNP 2.3:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.3:0.2Conscience

SNP 2.3:1.1Flouting conscience, loathing it,SNP 2.3:1.2saying “I’m on your side”, SNP 2.3:1.3but not following up in deeds,SNP 2.3:1.4you must know that they’re not on your side.

SNP 2.3:2.1Some say nice things to their friendsSNP 2.3:2.2without following it up. SNP 2.3:2.3The wise will recognizeSNP 2.3:2.4one who talks without doing.

SNP 2.3:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 46No true friend relentlesslySNP 2.3:3.2suspects betrayal, looking for fault. SNP 2.3:3.3A true friend is one on whom you can lie like a child at the breast,SNP 2.3:3.4who cannot be turned against you by others.

SNP 2.3:4.1While carrying out their duty,SNP 2.3:4.2one hoping for fruit and profit SNP 2.3:4.3develops the basis for gladness,SNP 2.3:4.4the happiness that attracts praise.

SNP 2.3:5.1Having drunk the nectar of seclusionSNP 2.3:5.2and the nectar of peace, SNP 2.3:5.3free of stress, free of evil,SNP 2.3:5.4one drinks the joyous nectar of Dhamma.

  • SNP 2.4:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.4:0.2Blessings

SNP 2.4:1.1BJ 25.80So I have heard. SNP 2.4:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. SNP 2.4:1.3Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side. SNP 2.4:1.4Standing to one side, that deity addressed the Buddha in verse:

SNP 2.4:10.1BJ 25.82Patience, being easy to admonish,SNP 2.4:10.2the sight of ascetics, SNP 2.4:10.3and timely discussion of the teaching:SNP 2.4:10.4this is the highest blessing.

SNP 2.4:11.1Austerity and celibacy SNP 2.4:11.2seeing the noble truths, SNP 2.4:11.3and realization of extinguishment:SNP 2.4:11.4this is the highest blessing.

SNP 2.4:12.1Though touched by worldly things,SNP 2.4:12.2their mind does not tremble; SNP 2.4:12.3sorrowless, stainless, secure,SNP 2.4:12.4this is the highest blessing.

SNP 2.4:13.1Having completed these things,SNP 2.4:13.2undefeated everywhere; SNP 2.4:13.3everywhere they go in safety:SNP 2.4:13.4this is their highest blessing.”

SNP 2.4:2.1“Many gods and humansSNP 2.4:2.2have thought about blessings SNP 2.4:2.3desiring well-being:SNP 2.4:2.4declare the highest blessing.”

SNP 2.4:3.1“Not to fraternize with fools,SNP 2.4:3.2but to fraternize with the wise, SNP 2.4:3.3and honoring those worthy of honor:SNP 2.4:3.4this is the highest blessing.

SNP 2.4:4.1Living in a suitable region,SNP 2.4:4.2having made merit in the past, SNP 2.4:4.3being rightly resolved in oneself, SNP 2.4:4.4this is the highest blessing.

SNP 2.4:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 47Education and a craft,SNP 2.4:5.2discipline and training, SNP 2.4:5.3and well-spoken speech:SNP 2.4:5.4this is the highest blessing.

SNP 2.4:6.1Caring for mother and father, SNP 2.4:6.2kindness to children and partners, SNP 2.4:6.3and unstressful work:SNP 2.4:6.4this is the highest blessing.

SNP 2.4:7.1Giving and righteous conduct, SNP 2.4:7.2kindness to relatives, SNP 2.4:7.3blameless deeds:SNP 2.4:7.4this is the highest blessing.

SNP 2.4:8.1Desisting and abstaining from evil,SNP 2.4:8.2avoiding alcoholic drinks, SNP 2.4:8.3diligence in good qualities:SNP 2.4:8.4this is the highest blessing.

SNP 2.4:9.1Respect and humility,SNP 2.4:9.2contentment and gratitude,SNP 2.4:9.3and timely listening to the teaching: SNP 2.4:9.4this is the highest blessing.

  • SNP 2.5:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.5:0.2With Spiky

SNP 2.5:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 48So I have heard. SNP 2.5:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Gayā on the cut-stone ledge in the haunt of Spiky the native spirit. SNP 2.5:1.3Now at that time the native spirits Shaggy and Spiky were passing by not far from the Buddha. SNP 2.5:1.4So Shaggy said to Spiky, SNP 2.5:1.5“That’s an ascetic.” SNP 2.5:1.6“That’s no ascetic, he’s a faker! SNP 2.5:1.7I’ll soon find out whether he’s an ascetic or a faker.”

SNP 2.5:2.1Then Spiky went up to the Buddha and leaned up against his body, SNP 2.5:2.2but the Buddha pulled away. SNP 2.5:2.3Then Spiky said to the Buddha, SNP 2.5:2.4“Are you afraid, ascetic?” SNP 2.5:2.5“No, sir, I’m not afraid. SNP 2.5:2.6But your touch is nasty.”

SNP 2.5:3.1“I will ask you a question, ascetic. SNP 2.5:3.2If you don’t answer me, I’ll drive you insane, or explode your heart, or grab you by the feet and throw you to the far shore of the Ganges!”

SNP 2.5:4.1BJ 25.84“I don’t see anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans who could do that to me. SNP 2.5:4.2But anyway, ask what you wish.” SNP 2.5:4.3Then Spiky said to the Buddha,

SNP 2.5:5.1“Where do greed and hate come from? SNP 2.5:5.2From where do discontent, desire, and terror spring? SNP 2.5:5.3Where do the mind’s thoughts originate, SNP 2.5:5.4like a crow let loose by boys.”

SNP 2.5:6.1“Greed and hate come from here; SNP 2.5:6.2from here spring discontent, desire, and terror; SNP 2.5:6.3here’s where the mind’s thoughts originate, SNP 2.5:6.4like a crow let loose by boys.

SNP 2.5:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 49Born of affection, originating in oneself, SNP 2.5:7.2like the shoots from a banyan’s trunk; SNP 2.5:7.3the many kinds of attachment to sensual pleasures SNP 2.5:7.4are like camel’s foot creeper strung through the woods.

SNP 2.5:8.1Those who understand where they come from SNP 2.5:8.2get rid of them—listen up, spirit! SNP 2.5:8.3They cross this flood so hard to cross, SNP 2.5:8.4not crossed before, so as to not be reborn.”

  • SNP 2.6:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.6:0.2A Righteous Life

SNP 2.6:1.1A righteous life, a spiritual life,SNP 2.6:1.2they call this the supreme treasure. SNP 2.6:1.3But if someone goes forthSNP 2.6:1.4from the lay life to homelessness

SNP 2.6:10.1dwell in communion, ever mindful, SNP 2.6:10.2the pure with the pure. SNP 2.6:10.3Then in harmony, alert, SNP 2.6:10.4you’ll make an end to suffering.”

SNP 2.6:2.1who is of scurrilous character,SNP 2.6:2.2a beast and a bully, SNP 2.6:2.3their life gets worse,SNP 2.6:2.4as poison grows inside them.

SNP 2.6:3.1BJ 25.86A mendicant who loves to argue,SNP 2.6:3.2wrapped in delusion, SNP 2.6:3.3doesn’t even know what’s been explainedSNP 2.6:3.4in the Dhamma taught by the Buddha.

SNP 2.6:4.1Harassing those who are evolved,SNP 2.6:4.2governed by ignorance, SNP 2.6:4.3they don’t know that corruptionSNP 2.6:4.4is the path that leads to hell.

SNP 2.6:5.1Entering the underworld,SNP 2.6:5.2passing from womb to womb, from darkness to darkness, SNP 2.6:5.3such a mendicant SNP 2.6:5.4falls into suffering after death.

SNP 2.6:6.1One such as that is SNP 2.6:6.2like a sewerSNP 2.6:6.3brimful with years of filth SNP 2.6:6.4for it’s hard to clean one full of grime.

SNP 2.6:7.1Mendicants, knowing that someone is like this,SNP 2.6:7.2attached to the lay life, SNP 2.6:7.3of wicked desires and wicked intent,SNP 2.6:7.4of bad behavior and alms-resort,

SNP 2.6:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 50then having gathered in harmony, SNP 2.6:8.2you should expel them. SNP 2.6:8.3Throw out the trash! SNP 2.6:8.4Get rid of the rubbish!

SNP 2.6:9.1And sweep away the scraps—SNP 2.6:9.2they’re not ascetics, they just think they are. SNP 2.6:9.3When you’ve thrown out those of wicked desires, SNP 2.6:9.4of bad behavior and alms-resort,

  • SNP 2.7:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.7:0.2Brahmanical Traditions

SNP 2.7:1.1BJ 25.88So I have heard. SNP 2.7:1.10The Buddha said this:

SNP 2.7:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. SNP 2.7:1.3Then several old and well-to-do brahmins of Kosala—elderly and senior, who were advanced in years and had reached the final stage of life—went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. SNP 2.7:1.4When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to the Buddha: SNP 2.7:1.5“Master Gotama, are the ancient traditions of the brahmins seen these days among brahmins?”SNP 2.7:1.6“No brahmins, they are not.”SNP 2.7:1.7“If you wouldn’t mind, Master Gotama, please teach us the ancient traditions of the brahmins.” SNP 2.7:1.8“Well then, brahmins, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.” SNP 2.7:1.9“Yes, sir,” they replied.

SNP 2.7:10.1They praised celibacy and morality,SNP 2.7:10.2integrity, gentleness, and austerity, SNP 2.7:10.3gentleness and harmlessness,SNP 2.7:10.4and also patience.

SNP 2.7:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 52He who was supreme among them,SNP 2.7:11.2godlike, staunchly vigorous, SNP 2.7:11.3did not engage in sexSNP 2.7:11.4even in a dream.

SNP 2.7:12.1Training in line with their duties,SNP 2.7:12.2many smart people here SNP 2.7:12.3praised celibacy and morality,SNP 2.7:12.4and also patience.

SNP 2.7:13.1They begged for rice,SNP 2.7:13.2bedding, clothes, ghee, and oil. SNP 2.7:13.3Having collected them legitimately,SNP 2.7:13.4they arranged a sacrifice.

SNP 2.7:14.1But they slew no cowsSNP 2.7:14.2while serving at the sacrifice. SNP 2.7:14.3Like a mother, father, or brother,SNP 2.7:14.4or some other relative,SNP 2.7:14.5cows are our best friends, SNP 2.7:14.6the fonts of medicine.

SNP 2.7:15.1They give food and health,SNP 2.7:15.2and beauty and happiness. SNP 2.7:15.3Knowing these benefits,SNP 2.7:15.4they slew no cows.

SNP 2.7:16.1The brahmins were delicate and tall,SNP 2.7:16.2beautiful and glorious. SNP 2.7:16.3They were keen on all the dutiesSNP 2.7:16.4required by their own traditions. SNP 2.7:16.5So long as they continued in the world,SNP 2.7:16.6people flourished happily.

SNP 2.7:17.1But perversion crept into them SNP 2.7:17.2little by little when they saw SNP 2.7:17.3the splendor of the kingSNP 2.7:17.4and the ladies in all their finery.

SNP 2.7:18.1Their chariots were harnessed with thoroughbreds,SNP 2.7:18.2well-made with bright canopies, SNP 2.7:18.3and their homes and houses wereSNP 2.7:18.4neatly laid out in measured rows.

SNP 2.7:19.1They were lavished with herds of cattle, SNP 2.7:19.2and furnished with bevies of lovely ladies. SNP 2.7:19.3This extravagant human wealthSNP 2.7:19.4was coveted by the brahmins.

SNP 2.7:2.1“The ancient hermits used to beSNP 2.7:2.2restrained and austere. SNP 2.7:2.3Having given up the five sensual titillations,SNP 2.7:2.4they lived for their own true good.

SNP 2.7:20.1BJ 25.92PTS-VP-PLI 53They compiled hymns to that end, SNP 2.7:20.2approached King Okkāka and said,SNP 2.7:20.3‘You have plenty of wealth and grain. SNP 2.7:20.4Sacrifice! For you have much treasure.SNP 2.7:20.5Sacrifice! For you have much wealth.’

SNP 2.7:21.1Persuaded by the brahmins,SNP 2.7:21.2the king, chief of charioteers, performed SNP 2.7:21.3horse sacrifice, human sacrifice, SNP 2.7:21.4the sacrifices of the ‘stick-casting’, the ‘royal soma drinking’, and the ‘unbarred’. SNP 2.7:21.5When he had carried out these sacrifices,SNP 2.7:21.6he gave riches to the brahmins.

SNP 2.7:22.1There were cattle, bedding, and clothes,SNP 2.7:22.2and ladies in all their finery; SNP 2.7:22.3chariots harnessed with thoroughbreds,SNP 2.7:22.4well-made with bright canopies;

SNP 2.7:23.1and lovely homes, allSNP 2.7:23.2neatly laid out in measured rows. SNP 2.7:23.3Having furnished them with different grains,SNP 2.7:23.4he gave riches to the brahmins.

SNP 2.7:24.1When they got hold of that wealth,SNP 2.7:24.2they arranged to store it up. SNP 2.7:24.3Falling under the sway of desire,SNP 2.7:24.4their craving grew and grew. SNP 2.7:24.5They compiled hymns to that end, SNP 2.7:24.6approached King Okkāka once more and said,

SNP 2.7:25.1‘Like water and earth, SNP 2.7:25.2gold, riches, and grain, SNP 2.7:25.3are cows for humankind,SNP 2.7:25.4as they are essential for creatures. SNP 2.7:25.5Sacrifice! For you have much treasure.SNP 2.7:25.6Sacrifice! For you have much wealth.’

SNP 2.7:26.1Persuaded by the brahmins,SNP 2.7:26.2the king, chief of charioteers, SNP 2.7:26.3had many hundred thousand cowsSNP 2.7:26.4slain at the sacrifice.

SNP 2.7:27.1Neither with feet nor with hornsSNP 2.7:27.2do cows harm anyone at all. SNP 2.7:27.3Cows meek as lambs,SNP 2.7:27.4supply buckets of milk.SNP 2.7:27.5But taking them by the horns, SNP 2.7:27.6the king slew them with a sword.

SNP 2.7:28.1PTS-VP-PLI 54At that the gods and the ancestors,SNP 2.7:28.2with Indra, the titans and monsters, SNP 2.7:28.3roared out: ‘This is a crime against nature!’SNP 2.7:28.4as the sword fell on the cows.

SNP 2.7:29.1There used to be three kinds of illness:SNP 2.7:29.2greed, starvation, and old age. SNP 2.7:29.3But due to the slaughter of cows,SNP 2.7:29.4this grew to be ninety-eight.

SNP 2.7:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 51Brahmins used to own no cattle,SNP 2.7:3.2nor gold or grain. SNP 2.7:3.3Chanting was their wealth and grain,SNP 2.7:3.4which they guarded as a gift from god.

SNP 2.7:30.1This unnatural violenceSNP 2.7:30.2has been passed down as an ancient custom. SNP 2.7:30.3Killing innocent creatures,SNP 2.7:30.4the sacrificers forsake righteousness.

SNP 2.7:31.1BJ 25.94And that is how this petty ancient thingSNP 2.7:31.2is criticized by sensible people SNP 2.7:31.3Wherever they see such a thing,SNP 2.7:31.4folk criticize the sacrificer.

SNP 2.7:32.1With righteousness gone,SNP 2.7:32.2merchants and workers were split, SNP 2.7:32.3as were many aristocrats,SNP 2.7:32.4and wives looked down on their husbands.

SNP 2.7:33.1Aristocrats and Brahmā’s kinsmenSNP 2.7:33.2and others protected by their clan, SNP 2.7:33.3rejecting the doctrine of caste,SNP 2.7:33.4fell under the sway of sensual pleasures.”

SNP 2.7:34.1PTS-VP-PLI 55When he had spoken, those well-to-do brahmins said to the Buddha, SNP 2.7:34.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! … SNP 2.7:34.3From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

SNP 2.7:4.1Food was prepared for themSNP 2.7:4.2and left beside their doors. SNP 2.7:4.3People believed that food prepared in faithSNP 2.7:4.4should be given to them.

SNP 2.7:5.1With colorful clothes,SNP 2.7:5.2clothes and bedding, SNP 2.7:5.3prosperous nations and countriesSNP 2.7:5.4honored those brahmins.

SNP 2.7:6.1Brahmins used to be inviolable andSNP 2.7:6.2invincible, protected by principle. SNP 2.7:6.3No-one ever turned them awaySNP 2.7:6.4from the doors of families.

SNP 2.7:7.1For forty-eight yearsSNP 2.7:7.2they lead the virginal spiritual life. SNP 2.7:7.3The brahmins of old pursuedSNP 2.7:7.4their quest for knowledge and conduct.

SNP 2.7:8.1The brahmins did not marry outside their caste,SNP 2.7:8.2nor did they purchase a wife. SNP 2.7:8.3They lived together in love,SNP 2.7:8.4joining together by mutual consent.

SNP 2.7:9.1BJ 25.90Brahmins never approached their wives for sexSNP 2.7:9.2during the time outside SNP 2.7:9.3the fertile half of the month SNP 2.7:9.4after menstruation.

  • SNP 2.8:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.8:0.2The Boat

SNP 2.8:1.1Honor the person from whom you would learn the teaching,SNP 2.8:1.2as the gods honor Inda. SNP 2.8:1.3Then they will have confidence in you,SNP 2.8:1.4and being learned, they reveal the teaching.

SNP 2.8:2.1Heeding well, a wise pupilSNP 2.8:2.2practicing in line with that teaching SNP 2.8:2.3grows intelligent, discerning, and subtleSNP 2.8:2.4through diligently sticking close to such a person.

SNP 2.8:3.1But associating with a petty foolSNP 2.8:3.2who falls short of the goal, jealous, SNP 2.8:3.3then unable to discern the teaching in this life,SNP 2.8:3.4one proceeds to death still plagued by doubts.

SNP 2.8:4.1BJ 25.96It’s like a man who has plunged into a river,SNP 2.8:4.2a rushing torrent in spate. SNP 2.8:4.3As they are swept away downstream,SNP 2.8:4.4how could they help others across?

SNP 2.8:5.1Just so, one unable to discern the teaching,SNP 2.8:5.2who hasn’t studied the meaning under the learned, SNP 2.8:5.3not knowing it oneself, still plagued by doubts,SNP 2.8:5.4how could they help others to contemplate?

SNP 2.8:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 56But one who has embarked on a strong boatSNP 2.8:6.2equipped with rudder and oar, SNP 2.8:6.3would bring many others across thereSNP 2.8:6.4with skill, care, and intelligence.

SNP 2.8:7.1So too one who understands—a knowledge master, SNP 2.8:7.2evolved, learned, and unflappable— SNP 2.8:7.3can help others to contemplate,SNP 2.8:7.4so long as they are prepared to listen carefully.

SNP 2.8:8.1That’s why you should spend time with a good person,SNP 2.8:8.2intelligent and learned. SNP 2.8:8.3Having understood the meaning, putting it into practice,SNP 2.8:8.4one who has realized the teaching may find happiness.

  • SNP 2.9:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.9:0.2What Morality?

SNP 2.9:1.1“With what morality, what conduct,SNP 2.9:1.2fostering what deeds, SNP 2.9:1.3would a person lay the foundations right,SNP 2.9:1.4and reach the highest goal?”

SNP 2.9:2.1“Honoring elders without jealousy,SNP 2.9:2.2they’d know the time to visit their teachers. SNP 2.9:2.3Treasuring the chance for a Dhamma talk,SNP 2.9:2.4they’d listen carefully to the well-spoken words.

SNP 2.9:3.1BJ 25.98PTS-VP-PLI 57At the right time, they’d humbly enter SNP 2.9:3.2the teachers’ presence, leaving obstinacy behind.SNP 2.9:3.3They’d call to mind and put into practice SNP 2.9:3.4the meaning, the teaching, self-control, and the spiritual life.

SNP 2.9:4.1Delighting in the teaching, enjoying the teaching,SNP 2.9:4.2standing on the teaching, investigating the teaching, SNP 2.9:4.3they’d never say anything that degraded the teaching,SNP 2.9:4.4but would be guided by genuine words well-spoken.

SNP 2.9:5.1Giving up mirth, prayer, weeping, ill will,SNP 2.9:5.2deception, fraud, greed, conceit, SNP 2.9:5.3aggression, crudeness, stains, and indulgence,SNP 2.9:5.4they’d wander free of vanity, steadfast.

SNP 2.9:6.1Understanding is the essence of well-spoken words,SNP 2.9:6.2stillness is the essence of learning and understanding. SNP 2.9:6.3Wisdom and learning do not flourishSNP 2.9:6.4in a hasty and negligent person.

SNP 2.9:7.1Those happy with the teaching proclaimed by the Noble OneSNP 2.9:7.2are supreme in speech, mind, and deed. SNP 2.9:7.3Settled in peace, gentleness, and stillness,SNP 2.9:7.4they’ve realized the essence of learning and wisdom.”

  • SNP 2.10:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.10:0.2Get Up!

SNP 2.10:1.1Get up and meditate!SNP 2.10:1.2What’s the point in your sleeping? SNP 2.10:1.3How can the afflicted slumberSNP 2.10:1.4when injured by an arrow strike?

SNP 2.10:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 58Get up and meditate!SNP 2.10:2.2Train hard for peace! SNP 2.10:2.3The King of Death has caught you heedless—SNP 2.10:2.4don’t let him fool you under his sway.

SNP 2.10:3.1BJ 25.100Needy gods and humans SNP 2.10:3.2are held back by clinging: SNP 2.10:3.3get over it.SNP 2.10:3.4Don’t let the moment pass you by. SNP 2.10:3.5For if you miss your momentSNP 2.10:3.6you’ll grieve when sent to hell.

SNP 2.10:4.1Negligence is always dust;SNP 2.10:4.2dust follows right behind negligence. SNP 2.10:4.3Through diligence and knowledge,SNP 2.10:4.4pluck out the dart from yourself.

  • SNP 2.11:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.11:0.2With Rāhula

SNP 2.11:1.1“Does familiarity breed contempt,SNP 2.11:1.2even for the man of wisdom? SNP 2.11:1.3Do you honor he who holds aloft SNP 2.11:1.4the torch for all humanity?”

SNP 2.11:2.1“Familiarity breeds no contemptSNP 2.11:2.2for the man of wisdom. SNP 2.11:2.3I always honor he who holds aloft SNP 2.11:2.4the torch for all humanity.”

SNP 2.11:3.1“One who’s given up the five sensual stimulations,SNP 2.11:3.2so pleasing and delightful, SNP 2.11:3.3and who’s left the home life out of faith—SNP 2.11:3.4let them make an end to suffering!

SNP 2.11:4.1Mix with spiritual friends,SNP 2.11:4.2stay in remote lodgings, SNP 2.11:4.3secluded and quiet,SNP 2.11:4.4and eat in moderation.

SNP 2.11:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 59Robes, almsfood,SNP 2.11:5.2requisites and lodgings: SNP 2.11:5.3don’t crave such things;SNP 2.11:5.4don’t come back to this world again.

SNP 2.11:6.1Be restrained in the monastic code,SNP 2.11:6.2and the five sense faculties, SNP 2.11:6.3With mindfulness immersed in the body,SNP 2.11:6.4be full of disillusionment.

SNP 2.11:7.1BJ 25.102Turn away from the feature of thingsSNP 2.11:7.2that’s attractive, provoking lust. SNP 2.11:7.3With mind unified and serene,SNP 2.11:7.4meditate on the ugly aspects of the body.

SNP 2.11:8.1Meditate on the signless,SNP 2.11:8.2give up the tendency to conceit; SNP 2.11:8.3and when you comprehend conceit,SNP 2.11:8.4you will live at peace.”

SNP 2.11:9.1That is how the Buddha regularly advised Venerable Rāhula with these verses.

  • SNP 2.12:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.12:0.2Vaṅgīsa and his Mentor Nigrodhakappa

SNP 2.12:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 60So I have heard. SNP 2.12:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Āḷavī, at the Aggāḷava Tree-shrine. SNP 2.12:1.3Now at that time it was not long after Venerable Vaṅgīsa’s mentor, the senior monk named Nigrodhakappa, had become extinguished. SNP 2.12:1.4Then as Vaṅgīsa was in private retreat this thought came to his mind: SNP 2.12:1.5“Has my mentor become extinguished or not?”SNP 2.12:1.6Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Vaṅgīsa came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him: SNP 2.12:1.7“Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind.
