SNP 2.12:1.8‘Has my mentor become extinguished or not?’SNP 2.12:1.9Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and addressed him in verse:

SNP 2.12:10.1BJ 25.106You have entirely abandoned birth and death;SNP 2.12:10.2restrained and pure, I urge you to speak the Dhamma! SNP 2.12:10.3For ordinary people have no wish-maker,SNP 2.12:10.4but Realized Ones have a comprehensibility-maker.

SNP 2.12:11.1Your answer is definitive, and we will adopt it,SNP 2.12:11.2for you have perfect understanding. SNP 2.12:11.3We raise our joined palms one last time,SNP 2.12:11.4one of unrivaled wisdom, don’t deliberately confuse us.

SNP 2.12:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 62Knowing the noble teaching from top to bottom, SNP 2.12:12.2unrivaled hero, don’t deliberately confuse us.SNP 2.12:12.3As a man in the baking summer sun would long for water, SNP 2.12:12.4I long for your voice, so let the sound rain down.

SNP 2.12:13.1Surely Kappāyana did not lead the spiritual life in vain?SNP 2.12:13.2Did he realize quenching, SNP 2.12:13.3or did he still have a remnant of defilement?SNP 2.12:13.4Let us hear what kind of liberation he had!”

SNP 2.12:14.1“He cut off craving for mind and body in this very life,”SNP 2.12:14.2said the Buddha, SNP 2.12:14.3“The river of darkness that had long lain within him.SNP 2.12:14.4He has entirely crossed over birth and death.” SNP 2.12:14.5So declared the Blessed One, the leader of the five.

SNP 2.12:15.1“Now that I have heard your words,SNP 2.12:15.2seventh of sages, I am confident. SNP 2.12:15.3My question, it seems, was not in vain,SNP 2.12:15.4the brahmin did not deceive me.

SNP 2.12:16.1As he said, so he did—SNP 2.12:16.2he was a disciple of the Buddha. SNP 2.12:16.3He cut the net of death the deceiver,SNP 2.12:16.4so extended and strong.

SNP 2.12:17.1Blessed One, Kappāyana sawSNP 2.12:17.2the starting point of grasping. SNP 2.12:17.3He has indeed gone far beyondSNP 2.12:17.4Death’s domain so hard to pass.

SNP 2.12:2.1“I ask the teacher unrivaled in wisdom,SNP 2.12:2.2who has cut off all doubts in this very life— SNP 2.12:2.3has a monk died at Aggāḷava, who wasSNP 2.12:2.4well-known, famous, and quenched?

SNP 2.12:3.1BJ 25.104Nigrodhakappa was his name;SNP 2.12:3.2it was given to that brahmin by you, Blessed One. SNP 2.12:3.3He wandered in your honor, yearning for freedom, SNP 2.12:3.4energetic, a resolute Seer of Truth.

SNP 2.12:4.1O Sakyan, all-seer,SNP 2.12:4.2all of us wish to know about that disciple. SNP 2.12:4.3Our ears are eager to hear,SNP 2.12:4.4for you are truly the most excellent teacher.

SNP 2.12:5.1Cut off our doubt, declare this to us;SNP 2.12:5.2your wisdom is vast, tell us of his quenching! SNP 2.12:5.3All-seer, speak among us,SNP 2.12:5.4like the thousand-eyed Sakka in the midst of the gods!

SNP 2.12:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 61Whatever ties there are, or paths to delusion, SNP 2.12:6.2or things on the side of unknowing, or that are bases of doubtSNP 2.12:6.3vanish on reaching a Realized One, SNP 2.12:6.4for his eye is the best of all people’s.

SNP 2.12:7.1For if no man were ever to disperse corruptions,SNP 2.12:7.2like the wind dispersing a mass of clouds, SNP 2.12:7.3darkness would shroud the whole world;SNP 2.12:7.4not even brilliant men would shine.

SNP 2.12:8.1The wise are makers of light;SNP 2.12:8.2my hero, that is what I think of you. SNP 2.12:8.3We’ve come to you for your discernment and knowledge:SNP 2.12:8.4here in this assembly, declare to us about Kappāyana.

SNP 2.12:9.1Swiftly send forth your graceful voice,SNP 2.12:9.2like a goose stretching its neck, gently honking, SNP 2.12:9.3smooth in sound, with a lovely tone:SNP 2.12:9.4alert, we are all listening to you.

  • SNP 2.13:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.13:0.2The Right Way to Wander

SNP 2.13:1.1BJ 25.108PTS-VP-PLI 63“I ask the sage abounding in wisdom— SNP 2.13:1.2crossed-over, gone beyond, quenched, steadfast:SNP 2.13:1.3when a mendicant has left home, expelling sensuality, SNP 2.13:1.4what’s the right way to wander the world?”

SNP 2.13:10.1Knowing what is suitable for themselves,SNP 2.13:10.2a mendicant would hurt no-one in the world; SNP 2.13:10.3understanding the teaching in accord with reality,SNP 2.13:10.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:11.1They have no underlying tendencies at all,SNP 2.13:11.2and are rid of unskillful roots; SNP 2.13:11.3free of hope, with no need for hope,SNP 2.13:11.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 65Defilements ended, conceit given up, SNP 2.13:12.2beyond all manner of desire;SNP 2.13:12.3tamed, quenched, and steadfast, SNP 2.13:12.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:13.1Faithful, learned, seer of the sure path,SNP 2.13:13.2the wise one takes no side among factions; SNP 2.13:13.3rid of greed, hate, and repulsion,SNP 2.13:13.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:14.1A purified victor with veil drawn back,SNP 2.13:14.2among worldly things master, transcendent, stilled; SNP 2.13:14.3expert in knowledge of conditions’ cessation,SNP 2.13:14.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:15.1BJ 25.112They’re over speculating on the future or past, SNP 2.13:15.2and understand what it means to be pure;SNP 2.13:15.3freed from all the sense fields, SNP 2.13:15.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:16.1The state of peace is understood, the truth is comprehended,SNP 2.13:16.2they’ve openly seen defilements cast off; SNP 2.13:16.3and with the ending of all attachments, SNP 2.13:16.4they’d rightly wander the world.”

SNP 2.13:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 66“Clearly, Blessed One, it is just as you say. SNP 2.13:17.2One who lives like this is a tamed mendicant,SNP 2.13:17.3beyond all fetters and yokes: SNP 2.13:17.4they’d rightly wander the world.”

SNP 2.13:2.1“When they’ve eradicated superstitions,”SNP 2.13:2.2said the Buddha, SNP 2.13:2.3“about celestial portents, dreams, or bodily marks;SNP 2.13:2.4with the stain of superstitions left behind, SNP 2.13:2.5they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:3.1A mendicant ought dispel desireSNP 2.13:3.2for pleasures human or divine; SNP 2.13:3.3with rebirth transcended and truth comprehended,SNP 2.13:3.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:4.1Putting divisiveness behind them,SNP 2.13:4.2a mendicant gives up anger and stinginess; SNP 2.13:4.3with favoring and opposing left behind, SNP 2.13:4.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:5.1When the loved and the unloved are both left behind,SNP 2.13:5.2not grasping or dependent on anything; SNP 2.13:5.3freed from all things that fetter,SNP 2.13:5.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:6.1Finding no substance in attachments,SNP 2.13:6.2rid of desire for things they’ve acquired, SNP 2.13:6.3independent, needing no-one to guide them,SNP 2.13:6.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 64Not hostile in speech, mind, or deed, SNP 2.13:7.2they’ve rightly understood the teaching.SNP 2.13:7.3Aspiring to the state of quenching, SNP 2.13:7.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:8.1BJ 25.110Not pridefully thinking, ‘they bow to me’;SNP 2.13:8.2though reviled, they’d still stay in touch; SNP 2.13:8.3not besotted when getting food from others,SNP 2.13:8.4they’d rightly wander the world.

SNP 2.13:9.1When greed and craving to live again are cast off, SNP 2.13:9.2a mendicant refrains from violence and abduction; SNP 2.13:9.3rid of doubt, free of thorns,SNP 2.13:9.4they’d rightly wander the world.

  • SNP 2.14:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 2.14:0.2With Dhammika

SNP 2.14:1.1So I have heard. SNP 2.14:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. SNP 2.14:1.3Then the lay follower Dhammika, together with five hundred lay followers, went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and addressed him in verse:

SNP 2.14:10.1All these mendicants have gathered,SNP 2.14:10.2and the layfolk too are here to listen. SNP 2.14:10.3Let them hear the teaching the immaculate one discovered,SNP 2.14:10.4like gods listening to the fine words of Vāsava.”

SNP 2.14:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 68“Listen to me, mendicants, I will educate you SNP 2.14:11.2in the cleansing teaching; all bear it in mind.SNP 2.14:11.3An intelligent person, seeing the meaning, SNP 2.14:11.4would adopt the deportment proper to a renunciate.

SNP 2.14:12.1BJ 25.116No way a mendicant would go out at the wrong time; SNP 2.14:12.2at the right time, they’d walk the village for alms.SNP 2.14:12.3For chains bind one who wanders outside the right time, SNP 2.14:12.4which is why the Buddhas avoid it.

SNP 2.14:13.1Sights, sounds, tastes, smells, and touches,SNP 2.14:13.2which drive beings mad— SNP 2.14:13.3dispel desire for such things,SNP 2.14:13.4and enter for the morning meal at the right time.

SNP 2.14:14.1After receiving alms for the day,SNP 2.14:14.2on returning a mendicant would sit in private alone. SNP 2.14:14.3Inwardly reflective, they’d curb their mindSNP 2.14:14.4from outside things, keeping themselves collected.

SNP 2.14:15.1Should they converse with a disciple,SNP 2.14:15.2with anyone else, or with a mendicant, SNP 2.14:15.3they’d bring up only the sublime teaching,SNP 2.14:15.4not dividing or blaming.

SNP 2.14:16.1For some contend in debate,SNP 2.14:16.2but we praise not those of little wisdom. SNP 2.14:16.3In place after place they are bound in chains,SNP 2.14:16.4for they send their mind over there far away.

SNP 2.14:17.1Alms, a dwelling, a bed and seat,SNP 2.14:17.2and water for rinsing the dust from the cloak— SNP 2.14:17.3after hearing the teaching of the Holy One, SNP 2.14:17.4a disciple of splendid wisdom would use these after appraisal.

SNP 2.14:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 69That’s why, when it comes to alms and lodgings, SNP 2.14:18.2and water for rinsing the dust from the cloak,SNP 2.14:18.3a mendicant is unsullied in the midst of these things, SNP 2.14:18.4like a droplet on a lotus-leaf.

SNP 2.14:19.1BJ 25.118Now I shall tell you the householder’s duty,SNP 2.14:19.2doing which one becomes a good disciple. SNP 2.14:19.3For one burdened with possessions does not get to realizeSNP 2.14:19.4the whole of the mendicant’s practice.

SNP 2.14:2.1“I ask you, Gotama, whose wisdom is vast: SNP 2.14:2.2what does one do to become a good disciple, SNP 2.14:2.3both one who has left the home,SNP 2.14:2.4and the lay followers staying at home?

SNP 2.14:20.1They’d not kill any creature, nor have them killed,SNP 2.14:20.2nor grant permission for others to kill. SNP 2.14:20.3They’ve laid aside violence towards all creaturesSNP 2.14:20.4frail or firm that there are in the world.

SNP 2.14:21.1Next, a disciple would avoid knowinglySNP 2.14:21.2taking anything not given at all, SNP 2.14:21.3they’d not get others to do it, nor grant them permission to steal;SNP 2.14:21.4they’d avoid all theft.

SNP 2.14:22.1A sensible person would avoid the unchaste life,SNP 2.14:22.2like a burning pit of coals. SNP 2.14:22.3But if unable to remain chaste,SNP 2.14:22.4they’d not transgress with another’s partner.

SNP 2.14:23.1In a council or assembly, SNP 2.14:23.2or one on one, they would not lie. SNP 2.14:23.3They’d not get others to lie, nor grant them permission to lie;SNP 2.14:23.4they’d avoid all untruths.

SNP 2.14:24.1A householder espousing this teachingSNP 2.14:24.2would not consume liquor or drink. SNP 2.14:24.3They’d not get others to drink, nor grant them permission to drink;SNP 2.14:24.4knowing that ends in intoxication.

SNP 2.14:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 70For drunken fools do bad things, SNP 2.14:25.2and encourage other heedless folk.SNP 2.14:25.3Reject this field of demerit, SNP 2.14:25.4the maddening, deluding frolic of fools.

SNP 2.14:26.1BJ 25.120You shouldn’t kill living creatures, or steal, SNP 2.14:26.2or lie, or drink alcohol. SNP 2.14:26.3Be celibate, refraining from sex, SNP 2.14:26.4and don’t eat at night, the wrong time.

SNP 2.14:27.1Not wearing garlands or applying perfumes, SNP 2.14:27.2you should sleep on a low bed, or a mat on the ground. SNP 2.14:27.3This is the eight-factored sabbath, they say, SNP 2.14:27.4explained by the Buddha, who has gone to suffering’s end.

SNP 2.14:28.1Then having observed the sabbathSNP 2.14:28.2complete in all its eight factors SNP 2.14:28.3on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight,SNP 2.14:28.4as well as on the fortnightly special displays,

SNP 2.14:29.1on the morning after the sabbathSNP 2.14:29.2a clever person, rejoicing with confident heart, SNP 2.14:29.3would distribute food and drink SNP 2.14:29.4to the mendicant Saṅgha as is fitting.

SNP 2.14:3.1For you understand the course and destinySNP 2.14:3.2of the world with all its gods. SNP 2.14:3.3There is no equal to you who sees the subtle meaning, SNP 2.14:3.4for you are the Buddha most excellent, they say.

SNP 2.14:30.1One should rightfully support one’s parents,SNP 2.14:30.2and undertake a legitimate business. SNP 2.14:30.3A diligent layperson observing these dutiesSNP 2.14:30.4ascends to the gods called Self-luminous.”

SNP 2.14:4.1BJ 25.114Having experienced all knowledge,SNP 2.14:4.2you explain the teaching out of compassion for beings. SNP 2.14:4.3All-seer, you have drawn back the veil,SNP 2.14:4.4and immaculate, you shine on the whole world.

SNP 2.14:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 67The dragon king Erāvaṇa, hearing you called ‘Victor’, SNP 2.14:5.2came into your presence.SNP 2.14:5.3He consulted with you then, having heard your words, SNP 2.14:5.4left consoled, saying ‘Excellent!’

SNP 2.14:6.1And King Vessavaṇa Kuvero, too,SNP 2.14:6.2approached to ask about the teaching. SNP 2.14:6.3You also answered him, O wise one,SNP 2.14:6.4and hearing you he too was consoled.

SNP 2.14:7.1Those teachers of other paths given to debate,SNP 2.14:7.2whether Ājīvakas or Jains, SNP 2.14:7.3all fail to overtake you in wisdom,SNP 2.14:7.4like a standing man next to a sprinter.

SNP 2.14:8.1Those brahmins given to debate,SNP 2.14:8.2some of whom are quite senior, SNP 2.14:8.3all end up beholden to you for the meaning,SNP 2.14:8.4and others too who think themselves debaters.

SNP 2.14:9.1So subtle and pleasant is the teachingSNP 2.14:9.2that is well proclaimed by you, Blessed One. SNP 2.14:9.3It’s all we long to hear. So when asked,SNP 2.14:9.4O Best of Buddhas, tell us!

  • SNP 3.1:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.1:0.2Going Forth

SNP 3.1:1.1BJ 25.122PTS-VP-PLI 72“I shall extol going forth SNP 3.1:1.2with the example of the seer,SNP 3.1:1.3the course of inquiry that led to SNP 3.1:1.4his choice to go forth.

SNP 3.1:10.1BJ 25.124PTS-VP-PLI 73Having wandered for alms, SNP 3.1:10.2the sage left the city.SNP 3.1:10.3He betook himself to Mount Paṇḍava, SNP 3.1:10.4thinking, ‘Here is the place I shall stay.’

SNP 3.1:11.1Seeing that’d he arrived at a place to stay,SNP 3.1:11.2the messengers withdrew nearby, SNP 3.1:11.3but one of them returnedSNP 3.1:11.4to inform the king.

SNP 3.1:12.1‘Great king, the mendicantSNP 3.1:12.2is on the east flank of Mount Paṇḍava. SNP 3.1:12.3There he sits, like a tiger or a bull,SNP 3.1:12.4like a lion in a mountain cave.’

SNP 3.1:13.1Hearing the messenger’s report,SNP 3.1:13.2the aristocrat set out SNP 3.1:13.3hurriedly in his fine chariotSNP 3.1:13.4towards Mount Paṇḍava.

SNP 3.1:14.1He went as far as vehicles could go,SNP 3.1:14.2then dismounted from his chariot, SNP 3.1:14.3approached on foot,SNP 3.1:14.4and reaching him, drew near.

SNP 3.1:15.1Seated, the king greeted himSNP 3.1:15.2and made polite conversation. SNP 3.1:15.3When the courtesies were over,SNP 3.1:15.4he said the following:

SNP 3.1:16.1‘You are young, just a youth,SNP 3.1:16.2a lad in the prime of life. SNP 3.1:16.3You are endowed with beauty and stature,SNP 3.1:16.4like an aristocrat of good lineage

SNP 3.1:17.1in glory at the army’s head,SNP 3.1:17.2surrounded by a troop of elephants. SNP 3.1:17.3I shall give you wealth to enjoy.SNP 3.1:17.4But please tell me your lineage by birth.’

SNP 3.1:18.1‘Up north lies a nation, great king,SNP 3.1:18.2on the slope of the Himalayas, SNP 3.1:18.3full of wealth and strength,SNP 3.1:18.4led by one loyal to the Kosalans.

SNP 3.1:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 74They are of the Solar clan, Ādiccas; SNP 3.1:19.2their lineage is the Sakyans.SNP 3.1:19.3I have gone forth from that family— SNP 3.1:19.4I do not yearn for sensual pleasures.

SNP 3.1:2.1‘This life at home is cramped,SNP 3.1:2.2a realm of dirt.’ SNP 3.1:2.3‘The life of one gone forth is like an open space.’SNP 3.1:2.4Seeing this, he went forth.

SNP 3.1:20.1Seeing the danger in sensual pleasures,SNP 3.1:20.2seeing renunciation as sanctuary, SNP 3.1:20.3I shall go on to strive;SNP 3.1:20.4that is where my mind delights.’”

SNP 3.1:3.1Having gone forth, he shunnedSNP 3.1:3.2bad deeds of body. SNP 3.1:3.3And leaving verbal misconduct behind,SNP 3.1:3.4he purified his livelihood.

SNP 3.1:4.1The Buddha went to Rājagaha,SNP 3.1:4.2the Mountainfold of the Magadhans. SNP 3.1:4.3He betook himself for alms,SNP 3.1:4.4replete with auspicious marks.

SNP 3.1:5.1Bimbisāra saw himSNP 3.1:5.2while standing atop his longhouse. SNP 3.1:5.3Noticing that he was endowed with marks,SNP 3.1:5.4he said the following:

SNP 3.1:6.1‘Pay heed, sirs, to this one,SNP 3.1:6.2handsome, majestic, radiant; SNP 3.1:6.3accomplished in deportment,SNP 3.1:6.4he looks just a plough’s length in front.

SNP 3.1:7.1Eyes downcast, mindful,SNP 3.1:7.2unlike one from a low family. SNP 3.1:7.3Let the king’s messengers run out,SNP 3.1:7.4and find where the mendicant will go.’

SNP 3.1:8.1The messengers sent outSNP 3.1:8.2followed right behind, thinking SNP 3.1:8.3‘Where will the mendicant go?SNP 3.1:8.4Where shall he find a place to stay?’

SNP 3.1:9.1Wandering indiscriminately for alms,SNP 3.1:9.2sense-doors guarded and well restrained, SNP 3.1:9.3his bowl was quickly filled,SNP 3.1:9.4aware and mindful.

  • SNP 3.2:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.2:0.2Striving

SNP 3.2:1.1BJ 25.126“During my time of resolute strivingSNP 3.2:1.2on the bank of the Nerañjara River, SNP 3.2:1.3I was meditating very hardSNP 3.2:1.4for the sake of finding sanctuary.

SNP 3.2:10.1And while the blood is drying up,SNP 3.2:10.2the bile and phlegm dry too. SNP 3.2:10.3And as my muscles waste away,SNP 3.2:10.4my mind grows more serene. SNP 3.2:10.5And all the stronger grow mindfulnessSNP 3.2:10.6and wisdom and immersion.

SNP 3.2:11.1BJ 25.128As I meditate like this,SNP 3.2:11.2I have experienced the ultimate feeling. SNP 3.2:11.3My mind has no interest in sensual pleasures:SNP 3.2:11.4behold a being’s purity!

SNP 3.2:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 76Sensual pleasures are your first army, SNP 3.2:12.2the second is called discontent,SNP 3.2:12.3hunger and thirst are the third, SNP 3.2:12.4and the fourth is said to be craving.

SNP 3.2:13.1Your fifth is dullness and drowsiness,SNP 3.2:13.2the sixth is said to be cowardice, SNP 3.2:13.3your seventh is doubt,SNP 3.2:13.4contempt and obstinacy are your eighth.

SNP 3.2:14.1Profit, praise, and honor,SNP 3.2:14.2and misbegotten fame; SNP 3.2:14.3the extolling of oneselfSNP 3.2:14.4while scorning others.

SNP 3.2:15.1This is your army, Namucī,SNP 3.2:15.2the strike force of the Dark One. SNP 3.2:15.3Only a hero can defeat it,SNP 3.2:15.4but in victory there lies bliss.

SNP 3.2:16.1Let me gird myself—SNP 3.2:16.2so what if I die! SNP 3.2:16.3I’d rather die in battleSNP 3.2:16.4than live on in defeat.

SNP 3.2:17.1Here some ascetics and brahminsSNP 3.2:17.2are swallowed up, not to be seen again. SNP 3.2:17.3They do not know the pathSNP 3.2:17.4traveled by those true to their vows.

SNP 3.2:18.1Seeing Māra ready on his mount,SNP 3.2:18.2surrounded by his bannered forces, SNP 3.2:18.3I shall meet them in battle—SNP 3.2:18.4they’ll never make me retreat!

SNP 3.2:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 77That army of yours has never been beaten SNP 3.2:19.2by the world with all its gods.SNP 3.2:19.3Yet I shall smash it with wisdom, SNP 3.2:19.4like an unfired pot with a stone.

SNP 3.2:2.1Namucī came to me,SNP 3.2:2.2speaking words of kindness: SNP 3.2:2.3‘You’re thin, discolored,SNP 3.2:2.4on the verge of death.

SNP 3.2:20.1When my thoughts are under control,SNP 3.2:20.2and mindfulness is well established, SNP 3.2:20.3I shall wander from country to country,SNP 3.2:20.4guiding many disciples.

SNP 3.2:21.1Diligent and resolute,SNP 3.2:21.2following my instructions, SNP 3.2:21.3they will proceed despite your will,SNP 3.2:21.4to where there is no sorrow.”

SNP 3.2:22.1BJ 25.130“For seven years I followed SNP 3.2:22.2step by step behind the Blessed One. SNP 3.2:22.3I found no vulnerabilitySNP 3.2:22.4in the mindful Awakened One.

SNP 3.2:23.1A crow once circled a stone SNP 3.2:23.2that looked like a lump of fat. SNP 3.2:23.3‘Perhaps I’ll find something tender,’ it thought, SNP 3.2:23.4‘perhaps there’s something tasty.’

SNP 3.2:24.1But finding nothing tasty, SNP 3.2:24.2the crow left that place. SNP 3.2:24.3Like the crow that pecked the stone, SNP 3.2:24.4I leave Gotama disappointed.”

SNP 3.2:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 78So stricken with sorrowSNP 3.2:25.2that his harp dropped from his armpit, SNP 3.2:25.3that spirit, downcast, SNP 3.2:25.4vanished right there.

SNP 3.2:3.1Death has a thousand parts of you,SNP 3.2:3.2one fraction is left to life. SNP 3.2:3.3Live sir! Life is better!SNP 3.2:3.4Living, you can make merits.

SNP 3.2:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 75While leading the spiritual lifeSNP 3.2:4.2and serving the sacred flame, SNP 3.2:4.3you can pile up abundant merit—SNP 3.2:4.4so what will striving do for you?

SNP 3.2:5.1Hard to walk is the path of striving,SNP 3.2:5.2hard to do, a hard challenge to win.’” SNP 3.2:5.3These are the verses Māra spokeSNP 3.2:5.4as he stood beside the Buddha.

SNP 3.2:6.1When Māra had spoken in this way,SNP 3.2:6.2the Buddha said this: SNP 3.2:6.3“O Wicked One, kinsman of the negligent, SNP 3.2:6.4you’re here for your own purpose.

SNP 3.2:7.1I have no need for SNP 3.2:7.2the slightest bit of merit. SNP 3.2:7.3Those with need for meritSNP 3.2:7.4are fit for Māra to address.

SNP 3.2:8.1I have faith and energy too,SNP 3.2:8.2and wisdom is found in me. SNP 3.2:8.3When I am so resolute,SNP 3.2:8.4why do you beg me to live?

SNP 3.2:9.1The rivers and streamsSNP 3.2:9.2might be dried by the wind, SNP 3.2:9.3so why, when I am resolute,SNP 3.2:9.4should it not dry up my blood?

  • SNP 3.3:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.3:0.2Well-Spoken Words

SNP 3.3:1.1So I have heard. SNP 3.3:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. SNP 3.3:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, SNP 3.3:1.4“Mendicants!” SNP 3.3:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. SNP 3.3:1.6The Buddha said this:

SNP 3.3:2.1“Mendicants, speech that has four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people. SNP 3.3:2.2What four? SNP 3.3:2.3It’s when a mendicant speaks well, not poorly; they speak on the teaching, not against the teaching; they speak pleasantly, not unpleasantly; and they speak truthfully, not falsely. SNP 3.3:2.4Speech with these four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.” SNP 3.3:2.5That is what the Buddha said. SNP 3.3:2.6Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

SNP 3.3:3.1“Good people say that well-spoken words are foremost; SNP 3.3:3.2second, speak on the teaching, not against it; SNP 3.3:3.3third, speak pleasantly, not unpleasantly; SNP 3.3:3.4and fourth, speak truthfully, not falsely.”

SNP 3.3:4.1BJ 25.132PTS-VP-PLI 79Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said, SNP 3.3:4.2“I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!” SNP 3.3:4.3“Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha. SNP 3.3:4.4Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:

SNP 3.3:5.1“Speak only such wordsSNP 3.3:5.2that do not hurt yourself SNP 3.3:5.3nor harm others;SNP 3.3:5.4such speech is truly well spoken.

SNP 3.3:6.1Speak only pleasing words,SNP 3.3:6.2words gladly welcomed. SNP 3.3:6.3Pleasing words are thoseSNP 3.3:6.4that bring nothing bad to others.

SNP 3.3:7.1Truth itself is the undying word:SNP 3.3:7.2this is an ancient law. SNP 3.3:7.3Good people say that the teaching and its meaningSNP 3.3:7.4are grounded in the truth.

SNP 3.3:8.1The words spoken by the BuddhaSNP 3.3:8.2for realizing the sanctuary, extinguishment, SNP 3.3:8.3for the attainment of vision,SNP 3.3:8.4this really is the best kind of speech.”

  • SNP 3.4:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.4:0.2With Bhāradvāja of Sundarika on the Sacrificial Cake

SNP 3.4:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 80So I have heard. SNP 3.4:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the Kosalan lands on the bank of the Sundarika river. SNP 3.4:1.3Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarika was serving the sacred flame and performing the fire sacrifice on the bank of the river Sundarika. SNP 3.4:1.4Then he looked all around the four directions, wondering, SNP 3.4:1.5“Now who might eat the leftovers of this offering?” SNP 3.4:1.6He saw the Buddha meditating at the root of a certain tree with his robe pulled over his head. SNP 3.4:1.7Taking the leftovers of the offering in his left hand and a pitcher in the right he approached the Buddha.

SNP 3.4:10.1“Then clearly my oblation will be profitable,”SNP 3.4:10.2said the brahmin, SNP 3.4:10.3“since I have met such a knowledge master.SNP 3.4:10.4It’s because I’d never met anyone like you SNP 3.4:10.5that others ate the sacrificial cake.”

SNP 3.4:11.1BJ 25.136“So then, brahmin, since you have approached me SNP 3.4:11.2as a seeker of the good, ask.SNP 3.4:11.3Perhaps you may find here someone intelligent, SNP 3.4:11.4peaceful, unclouded, untroubled, with no need for hope.”

SNP 3.4:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 82“Master Gotama, I like to sacrifice SNP 3.4:12.2and wish to perform a sacrifice. Please advise me,SNP 3.4:12.3for I do not understand SNP 3.4:12.4where an oblation is profitable; tell me this.”

SNP 3.4:13.1“Well then, brahmin, lend an ear, I will teach you the Dhamma.

SNP 3.4:14.1Don’t ask about birth, ask about conduct; SNP 3.4:14.2for any wood can surely generate fire. SNP 3.4:14.3A steadfast sage, even though from a low class family, SNP 3.4:14.4is a thoroughbred checked by conscience.

SNP 3.4:15.1Tamed by truth, fulfilled by taming, SNP 3.4:15.2a complete knowledge master who has completed the spiritual journey— SNP 3.4:15.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.4:15.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.4:16.1Those who have left sensuality behind, wandering homeless,SNP 3.4:16.2self-controlled, straight as a shuttle— SNP 3.4:16.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.4:16.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.4:17.1Those freed of greed, with senses stilled,SNP 3.4:17.2like the moon released from the eclipse— SNP 3.4:17.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.4:17.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.4:18.1They wander the world unimpeded,SNP 3.4:18.2always mindful, calling nothing their own— SNP 3.4:18.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.4:18.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.4:19.1BJ 25.138PTS-VP-PLI 83Having left sensuality behind, wandering triumphant, SNP 3.4:19.2knowing the end of rebirth and death,SNP 3.4:19.3extinguished and cool as a lake: SNP 3.4:19.4the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:2.1BJ 25.134When he heard Sundarika’s footsteps the Buddha uncovered his head. SNP 3.4:2.2Sundarika thought, “This man is shaven, he is shaven!” And he wanted to turn back. SNP 3.4:2.3But he thought, SNP 3.4:2.4“Even some brahmins are shaven. Why don’t I go to him and ask about his birth?” SNP 3.4:2.5Then Sundarika the brahmin went up to the Buddha and said to him, SNP 3.4:2.6“Sir, in what caste were you born?”

SNP 3.4:20.1Good among the good, far from the bad,SNP 3.4:20.2the Realized One has infinite wisdom. SNP 3.4:20.3Unsullied in this world and the next:SNP 3.4:20.4the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:21.1In whom dwells no deceit or conceit,SNP 3.4:21.2rid of greed, unselfish, with no need for hope, SNP 3.4:21.3with anger eliminated, quenched,SNP 3.4:21.4a brahmin rid of sorrow’s stain: SNP 3.4:21.5the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:22.1He has given up the mind’s home,SNP 3.4:22.2and has no possessions at all. SNP 3.4:22.3Not grasping to this world or the next:SNP 3.4:22.4the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:23.1Serene, he has crossed the flood,SNP 3.4:23.2and has understood the teaching with ultimate view. SNP 3.4:23.3With defilements ended, bearing his final body: SNP 3.4:23.4the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:24.1In whom desire to be reborn, and caustic speechSNP 3.4:24.2are cleared and ended, they are no more; SNP 3.4:24.3that knowledge master, everywhere free:SNP 3.4:24.4the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 84They’ve escaped their chains, they’re chained no more, SNP 3.4:25.2among those caught in conceit he is free of conceit;SNP 3.4:25.3he has fully understood suffering with its field and ground: SNP 3.4:25.4the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:26.1BJ 25.140Not relying on hope, seeing seclusion,SNP 3.4:26.2well past the views proclaimed by others. SNP 3.4:26.3In him there are no supporting conditions at all:SNP 3.4:26.4the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:27.1He has comprehended all things, high and low, SNP 3.4:27.2cleared them and ended them, so they are no more. SNP 3.4:27.3Peaceful, freed in the ending of grasping: SNP 3.4:27.4the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:28.1He sees the utter ending of rebirth’s fetter,SNP 3.4:28.2and has swept away all manner of desire. SNP 3.4:28.3Pure, stainless, immaculate, flawless:SNP 3.4:28.4the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:29.1Not seeing himself in terms of a self,SNP 3.4:29.2he is stilled, upright, and steadfast. SNP 3.4:29.3Imperturbable, kind, wishless:SNP 3.4:29.4the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

SNP 3.4:3.1Then the Buddha addressed Sundarika in verse:

SNP 3.4:30.1He harbors no delusions within at all,SNP 3.4:30.2he has insight into all things. SNP 3.4:30.3He bears his final body, SNP 3.4:30.4attained to the state of grace, the supreme awakening. SNP 3.4:30.5That’s how the purity of a spirit is defined:SNP 3.4:30.6the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.”

SNP 3.4:31.1PTS-VP-PLI 85“Let my oblation be a true offering, SNP 3.4:31.2since I have found such a knowledge master! SNP 3.4:31.3I see Brahmā in person! Accept my offering, Blessed One: SNP 3.4:31.4please eat my sacrificial cake.”

SNP 3.4:32.1BJ 25.142“Food enchanted by a spell isn’t fit for me to eat. SNP 3.4:32.2That’s not the principle of those who see, brahmin. SNP 3.4:32.3The Buddhas reject things enchanted with spells. SNP 3.4:32.4Since there is such a principle, brahmin, that’s how they live.

SNP 3.4:33.1Serve with other food and drink SNP 3.4:33.2the consummate one, the great hermit, SNP 3.4:33.3with defilements ended and remorse stilled. SNP 3.4:33.4For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”

SNP 3.4:34.1“Please, Blessed One, help me understand:SNP 3.4:34.2now that I have encountered your teaching, SNP 3.4:34.3when I look for someone during a sacrifice,SNP 3.4:34.4who should eat the religious donation of one like me?”

SNP 3.4:35.1“One who is rid of aggression,SNP 3.4:35.2whose mind is unclouded, SNP 3.4:35.3who is liberated from sensual pleasures,SNP 3.4:35.4and who has dispelled dullness.

SNP 3.4:36.1One who has erased boundaries and limits,SNP 3.4:36.2expert in birth and death, SNP 3.4:36.3a sage, blessed with sagacity.SNP 3.4:36.4When such a person comes to the sacrifice,

SNP 3.4:37.1get rid of your scowl!SNP 3.4:37.2Honor them with joined palms, SNP 3.4:37.3and venerate them with food and drink,SNP 3.4:37.4and in this way your religious donation will succeed.”

SNP 3.4:38.1PTS-VP-PLI 86“The Buddha is worthy of the sacrificial cake, SNP 3.4:38.2he is the supreme field of merit,SNP 3.4:38.3Recipient of gifts from the whole world, SNP 3.4:38.4what’s given to the worthy one is very fruitful.”

SNP 3.4:39.1Then Sundarika the brahmin said to the Buddha, SNP 3.4:39.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! SNP 3.4:39.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways. SNP 3.4:39.4I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. SNP 3.4:39.5Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?” SNP 3.4:39.6And the brahmin Sundarika Bhāradvāja received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence. SNP 3.4:39.7And soon after, he became one of the perfected.

SNP 3.4:4.1“I am no brahmin, nor am I a prince,SNP 3.4:4.2nor merchant nor anything else. SNP 3.4:4.3Fully understanding the clan of ordinary people,SNP 3.4:4.4I wander in the world owning nothing, reflective.

SNP 3.4:5.1Clad in my cloak, I wander without home,SNP 3.4:5.2my hair shorn, quenched. SNP 3.4:5.3Since I’m unburdened by youngsters,SNP 3.4:5.4it’s inappropriate to ask me about clan.”

SNP 3.4:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 81“Actually sir, when brahmins meet they politely SNP 3.4:6.2ask each other whether they are brahmins.”

SNP 3.4:7.1“Well, if you say that you’re a brahmin,SNP 3.4:7.2and that I am not, SNP 3.4:7.3I shall question you on the Gāyatrī Mantra,SNP 3.4:7.4with its three lines and twenty-four syllables.”

SNP 3.4:8.1“On what grounds have hermits and men,SNP 3.4:8.2aristocrats and brahmins here in the world SNP 3.4:8.3performed so many different sacrifices to the gods?”

SNP 3.4:9.1“During a sacrifice, should a past master, a knowledge master, SNP 3.4:9.2receive an oblation, it profits the donor, I say.”

  • SNP 3.5:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.5:0.2With Māgha

SNP 3.5:1.1BJ 25.144PTS-VP-PLI 87So I have heard. SNP 3.5:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain. SNP 3.5:1.3Then the brahmin student Māgha approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him. SNP 3.5:1.4When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, SNP 3.5:1.5and said to the Buddha:

SNP 3.5:10.1Having given up greed, hate, and delusion, SNP 3.5:10.2with defilements ended, the spiritual journey completed: SNP 3.5:10.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:10.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:11.1Those in whom dwells no deceit or conceit,SNP 3.5:11.2with defilements ended, the spiritual journey completed: SNP 3.5:11.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:11.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 89Those rid of greed, unselfish, with no need for hope, SNP 3.5:12.2with defilements ended, the spiritual journey completed:SNP 3.5:12.3that is where a brahmin seeking merit SNP 3.5:12.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:13.1Those not fallen prey to cravings,SNP 3.5:13.2who, having crossed the flood, live unselfishly: SNP 3.5:13.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:13.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:14.1Those with no craving at all in the worldSNP 3.5:14.2to any form of existence in this life or the next: SNP 3.5:14.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:14.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:15.1BJ 25.148Those who have left sensuality behind, wandering homeless, SNP 3.5:15.2self-controlled, straight as a shuttle:SNP 3.5:15.3that is where a brahmin seeking merit SNP 3.5:15.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:16.1Those freed of greed, with senses stilled,SNP 3.5:16.2like the moon released from the eclipse: SNP 3.5:16.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:16.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:17.1Those peaceful ones free of greed and anger,SNP 3.5:17.2for whom there are no destinies, being rid of them in this life: SNP 3.5:17.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:17.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:18.1They’ve given up rebirth and death completely,SNP 3.5:18.2and have gone beyond all doubt: SNP 3.5:18.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:18.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:19.1Those who live as their own island,SNP 3.5:19.2everywhere free, owning nothing: SNP 3.5:19.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:19.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:2.1“I’m a giver, Master Gotama, a donor; I am bountiful and committed to charity.SNP 3.5:2.2I seek wealth in a principled manner, SNP 3.5:2.3and with that legitimate wealth I give to one person, to two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred people or even more.SNP 3.5:2.4Giving and sacrificing like this, Master Gotama, do I accrue much merit?”

SNP 3.5:20.1Those here who know this to be true:SNP 3.5:20.2‘This is my last life, there are no future lives’: SNP 3.5:20.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:20.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:21.1PTS-VP-PLI 90A knowledge master, loving absorption, mindful, SNP 3.5:21.2who has reached awakening and is a refuge for many:SNP 3.5:21.3that is where a brahmin seeking merit SNP 3.5:21.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.”

SNP 3.5:22.1BJ 25.150“Clearly my questions were not in vain!” SNP 3.5:22.2said Māgha,SNP 3.5:22.3“The Buddha has explained to me who is worthy of donations. SNP 3.5:22.4You are the one here who knows this to be true,SNP 3.5:22.5for truly you understand this matter.

SNP 3.5:23.1Suppose a lay donor who is committed to charitySNP 3.5:23.2makes a sacrifice seeking merit, looking for merit, SNP 3.5:23.3giving food and drink to others here:SNP 3.5:23.4explain to me how to accomplish the sacrifice.”

SNP 3.5:24.1“Sacrifice, and while doing so,”SNP 3.5:24.2replied the Buddha, SNP 3.5:24.3“be clear and confident in every way.SNP 3.5:24.4Sacrifice is the ground standing upon which SNP 3.5:24.5the sacrificer sheds their flaws.

SNP 3.5:25.1One free of greed, rid of anger,SNP 3.5:25.2developing a heart of limitless love, SNP 3.5:25.3spreads that limitlessness in every direction,SNP 3.5:25.4ever diligent day and night.”

SNP 3.5:26.1PTS-VP-PLI 91“Who is purified, freed, awake? SNP 3.5:26.2How can one go to the Brahmā realm oneself?SNP 3.5:26.3I do not know, so please tell me when asked, SNP 3.5:26.4for the Buddha is the Brahmā I see in person today!SNP 3.5:26.5To us you are truly the equal of Brahmā. SNP 3.5:26.6Splendid One, how is one reborn in the Brahmā realm?”

SNP 3.5:27.1“One who accomplishes the sacrifice with three modes,” SNP 3.5:27.2replied the Buddha, SNP 3.5:27.3“such a one would succeed due to those who are worthy of donations.SNP 3.5:27.4Sacrificing like this, one rightly committed to charity SNP 3.5:27.5is reborn in the Brahmā realm, I say.”

SNP 3.5:28.1When he had spoken, the student Māgha said to the Buddha, SNP 3.5:28.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! … SNP 3.5:28.3From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

SNP 3.5:3.1“Indeed you do, student.SNP 3.5:3.2A giver or donor who is bountiful and committed to charity,SNP 3.5:3.3who seeks wealth in a principled manner, SNP 3.5:3.4and with that legitimate wealth gives to one person, or up to a hundred people or even more, accrues much merit.”SNP 3.5:3.5Then Māgha addressed the Buddha in verse:

SNP 3.5:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 88“I ask the bountiful Gotama,” SNP 3.5:4.2said Māgha,SNP 3.5:4.3“wearing an ochre robe, wandering homeless. SNP 3.5:4.4Suppose a lay donor who is committed to charitySNP 3.5:4.5makes a sacrifice seeking merit, looking for merit. SNP 3.5:4.6Giving food and drink to others here,SNP 3.5:4.7how is their offering purifed?”

SNP 3.5:5.1“Suppose a lay donor who is committed to charity,”SNP 3.5:5.2replied the Buddha, SNP 3.5:5.3“makes a sacrifice seeking merit, looking for merit,SNP 3.5:5.4giving food and drink to others here: SNP 3.5:5.5such a one would succeed due to those who are worthy of donations.”

SNP 3.5:6.1BJ 25.146“Suppose a lay donor who is committed to charity,” SNP 3.5:6.2said Māgha,SNP 3.5:6.3“makes a sacrifice seeking merit, looking for merit, SNP 3.5:6.4giving food and drink to others here:SNP 3.5:6.5explain to me who is worthy of donations.”

SNP 3.5:7.1“Those who wander the world unattached,SNP 3.5:7.2consummate, restrained, owning nothing: SNP 3.5:7.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:7.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:8.1Those who have cut off all fetters and bonds,SNP 3.5:8.2tamed, liberated, untroubled, with no need for hope: SNP 3.5:8.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:8.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

SNP 3.5:9.1Those who are released from all fetters,SNP 3.5:9.2tamed, liberated, untroubled, with no need for hope: SNP 3.5:9.3that is where a brahmin seeking meritSNP 3.5:9.4should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

  • SNP 3.6:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.6:0.2With Sabhiya

SNP 3.6:1.1BJ 25.152So I have heard. SNP 3.6:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground. SNP 3.6:1.3Now at that time the wanderer Sabhiya had been presented with a question by a deity who was a former relative, saying:SNP 3.6:1.4“Sabhiya, you should practice the spiritual life with whatever ascetic or brahmin answers this question.”

SNP 3.6:10.1Ask me your question, Sabhiya, SNP 3.6:10.2whatever you want. SNP 3.6:10.3I’ll solve each and every SNP 3.6:10.4question you have.”

SNP 3.6:11.1Then Sabhiya thought,SNP 3.6:11.2“It’s incredible, it’s amazing! SNP 3.6:11.3Where those other ascetics and brahmins didn’t even give me a chance, the Buddha has invited me.”SNP 3.6:11.4Uplifted and elated, full of rapture and happiness, he asked this question.

SNP 3.6:12.1BJ 25.156“What must one attain to be called a mendicant?” SNP 3.6:12.2said Sabhiya,SNP 3.6:12.3“How is one ‘sweet’, how said to be ‘tamed’? SNP 3.6:12.4How is one declared to be ‘awakened’? SNP 3.6:12.5May the Buddha please answer my question.”

SNP 3.6:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 95“When by the path they have walked themselves,” SNP 3.6:13.2said the Buddha to Sabhiya,SNP 3.6:13.3“they reach quenching, with doubt overcome; SNP 3.6:13.4giving up desire to continue existence or to end it,SNP 3.6:13.5their journey complete, their rebirths ended: that is a mendicant.

SNP 3.6:14.1Equanimous towards everything, mindful,SNP 3.6:14.2they don’t harm anyone in the world. SNP 3.6:14.3An ascetic who has crossed over, unclouded,SNP 3.6:14.4not full of themselves, is sweet-natured.

SNP 3.6:15.1Their faculties have been developedSNP 3.6:15.2inside and out in the whole world. SNP 3.6:15.3Having pierced through this world and the next,SNP 3.6:15.4tamed, they bide their time.

SNP 3.6:16.1They have examined the aeons in their entirety,SNP 3.6:16.2and both sides of transmigration—passing away and rebirth. SNP 3.6:16.3Rid of dust, unblemished, purified:SNP 3.6:16.4the one they call ‘awakened’ has attained the end of rebirth.”

SNP 3.6:17.1And then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, uplifted and elated, full of rapture and happiness, Sabhiya asked another question:

SNP 3.6:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 96“What must one attain to be called ‘brahmin’?” SNP 3.6:18.2said Sabhiya.SNP 3.6:18.3“Why is one an ‘ascetic’, and how a ‘bathed initiate’? SNP 3.6:18.4How is one declared to be a ‘giant’? SNP 3.6:18.5May the Buddha please answer my question.”

SNP 3.6:19.1BJ 25.158“Having banished all bad things,”SNP 3.6:19.2said the Buddha to Sabhiya, SNP 3.6:19.3“immaculate, well-composed, steadfast, SNP 3.6:19.4consummate, they’ve left transmigration behind: SNP 3.6:19.5such an unattached one is called ‘brahmin’.

SNP 3.6:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 92Then Sabhiya, after learning that question in the presence of that deity, approached those ascetics and brahmins who led an order and a community, and taught a community, who were well-known and famous religious founders, regarded as holy by many people. That is, SNP 3.6:2.2Pūraṇa Kassapa, Makkhali Gosāla, Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, Pakudha Kaccāyana, and Ajita Kesakambala. SNP 3.6:2.3And he asked them that question,SNP 3.6:2.4by they were stumped by it,SNP 3.6:2.5Displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness,SNP 3.6:2.6they questioned Sabiya in return.

SNP 3.6:20.1A peaceful one who has given up good and evil,SNP 3.6:20.2stainless, understanding this world and the next, SNP 3.6:20.3gone beyond rebirth and death:SNP 3.6:20.4such an one is rightly called ‘ascetic’.

SNP 3.6:21.1Having washed off all bad thingsSNP 3.6:21.2inside and out in the whole world, SNP 3.6:21.3among gods and humans bound to creations,SNP 3.6:21.4the one they call ‘washed’ does not return to creation.

SNP 3.6:22.1They do nothing monstrous at all in the world,SNP 3.6:22.2discarding all fetters and bonds, SNP 3.6:22.3everywhere not stuck, freed:SNP 3.6:22.4such an one is rightly called ‘giant’.”

SNP 3.6:23.1And then Sabhiya asked another question:

SNP 3.6:24.1PTS-VP-PLI 97“Who is a ‘field-victor’ according to the Buddhas?” SNP 3.6:24.2said Sabhiya,SNP 3.6:24.3“Why is one ‘skillful’, and how ‘a wise scholar’? SNP 3.6:24.4How is one declared to be a ‘sage’? SNP 3.6:24.5May the Buddha please answer my question.”

SNP 3.6:25.1“They are victorious over the fields of deeds in their entirety,”SNP 3.6:25.2said the Buddha to Sabhiya, SNP 3.6:25.3“the fields of gods, humans, and Brahmas;SNP 3.6:25.4released from the root bondage to all fields: SNP 3.6:25.5such an one is rightly called ‘field-victor’.

SNP 3.6:26.1They have examined the stockpiles of deeds in their entirety,SNP 3.6:26.2the stockpiles of gods, humans, and Brahmas; SNP 3.6:26.3released from the root bondage to all stockpiles:SNP 3.6:26.4such an one is rightly called ‘skillful’.

SNP 3.6:27.1BJ 25.160They have examined whiteness SNP 3.6:27.2both inside and out; understanding purity, SNP 3.6:27.3they have left dark and bright behind:SNP 3.6:27.4such an one is rightly called ‘a wise scholar’.”

SNP 3.6:28.1Understanding the nature of the bad and the goodSNP 3.6:28.2inside and out in the whole world; SNP 3.6:28.3one worthy of honor by gods and humans,SNP 3.6:28.4who has escaped from the net and the snare: that is a sage.”

SNP 3.6:29.1And then Sabhiya asked another question:

SNP 3.6:3.1Then Sabhiya thought,SNP 3.6:3.2“Those famous ascetics and brahminsSNP 3.6:3.4were stumped by my question. SNP 3.6:3.5Displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness,SNP 3.6:3.6they questioned me in return on that matter.SNP 3.6:3.7Why don’t I return to a lesser life so I can enjoy sensual pleasures?”

SNP 3.6:30.1PTS-VP-PLI 98“What must one attain to be called ‘knowledge master’?” SNP 3.6:30.2said Sabhiya,SNP 3.6:30.3“Why is one ‘studied’, and how is one ‘heroic’? SNP 3.6:30.4How to gain the name ‘thoroughbred’?SNP 3.6:30.5May the Buddha please answer my question.”

SNP 3.6:31.1“They have examined knowledges in their entirety,”SNP 3.6:31.2said the Buddha to Sabhiya, SNP 3.6:31.3“those that are current among ascetics and brahmins;SNP 3.6:31.4rid of greed for all feelings, SNP 3.6:31.5having left all knowledges behind: that is a knowledge master.

SNP 3.6:32.1Having studied proliferation and name & formSNP 3.6:32.2inside and out—the root of disease; SNP 3.6:32.3released from the root bondage to all disease:SNP 3.6:32.4such an one is rightly called ‘studied’.

SNP 3.6:33.1Refraining from all evil here,SNP 3.6:33.2heroic, he escapes from the suffering of hell; SNP 3.6:33.3he is heroic and energetic:SNP 3.6:33.4such an one is rightly called ‘hero’.

SNP 3.6:34.1Whoever’s bonds are cut,SNP 3.6:34.2the root of clinging inside and out; SNP 3.6:34.3released from the root bondage to all clinging:SNP 3.6:34.4such an one is rightly called ‘thoroughbred’.”

SNP 3.6:35.1And then Sabhiya asked another question:

SNP 3.6:36.1BJ 25.162PTS-VP-PLI 99“What must one attain to be called ‘scholar’?” SNP 3.6:36.2said Sabhiya,SNP 3.6:36.3“Why is one ‘noble’, and how is one ‘well conducted’? SNP 3.6:36.4How to gain the name ‘wanderer’?SNP 3.6:36.5May the Buddha please answer my question.”

SNP 3.6:37.1“One who has learned every teaching,”SNP 3.6:37.2said the Buddha to Sabhiya, SNP 3.6:37.3“and has known for themselves whatever is blameworthy and blameless in the world;SNP 3.6:37.4a champion, decided, liberated, SNP 3.6:37.5untroubled everywhere: they call them ‘scholar’.

SNP 3.6:38.1Having cut off defilements and attachments, SNP 3.6:38.2being wise, they enter no womb. SNP 3.6:38.3They’ve expelled the bog of the three perceptions,SNP 3.6:38.4the one they call ‘noble’ does not return to creation.

SNP 3.6:39.1One here who is accomplished and skillful in all forms of good conduct;SNP 3.6:39.2always understanding the teaching, SNP 3.6:39.3everywhere not stuck, freed in mind,SNP 3.6:39.4who has no repulsion: they are ‘well-conducted’.

SNP 3.6:4.1Then Sabhiya thought,SNP 3.6:4.2“This ascetic Gotama also leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, regarded as holy by many people. SNP 3.6:4.3Why don’t I ask him this question?”

SNP 3.6:40.1Avoiding any deed that results in suffering—SNP 3.6:40.2above, below, all round, between: SNP 3.6:40.3deceit and conceit, as well as greed and anger,SNP 3.6:40.4they live full of wisdom. SNP 3.6:40.5They have made a limit on name & form;SNP 3.6:40.6the one they call a ‘wanderer’ has reached their destination.”

SNP 3.6:41.1PTS-VP-PLI 100And then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, uplifted and elated, full of rapture and happiness, Sabhiya got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:

SNP 3.6:42.1BJ 25.164“O one of vast wisdom, there are three & sixty opinions SNP 3.6:42.2based on the doctrines of ascetics:SNP 3.6:42.3they are expressions of perception, based on perception. SNP 3.6:42.4Having dispelled them all, you passed over the dark flood.

SNP 3.6:43.1You have gone to the end, gone beyond suffering, SNP 3.6:43.2you are perfected, a fully awakened Buddha; I think you have ended defilements. SNP 3.6:43.3Splendid, intelligent, abounding in wisdom,SNP 3.6:43.4ender of suffering—you brought me across!

SNP 3.6:44.1When you understood my uncertainty,SNP 3.6:44.2you brought me beyond doubt—homage to you! SNP 3.6:44.3A sage, accomplished in the ways of sagacity,SNP 3.6:44.4you are gentle, not hardhearted, O Kinsman of the Sun.

SNP 3.6:45.1PTS-VP-PLI 101Any doubts that I once had, SNP 3.6:45.2you have answered for me, O Seer.SNP 3.6:45.3Clearly you are a sage, an Awakened One, SNP 3.6:45.4there are no hindrances in you.

SNP 3.6:46.1All your distressSNP 3.6:46.2is blown away and mown down. SNP 3.6:46.3Cooled, tamed, steadfast:SNP 3.6:46.4truth is your strength.

SNP 3.6:47.1O giant among giants, O great hero,SNP 3.6:47.2when you are speaking SNP 3.6:47.3all the gods rejoice,SNP 3.6:47.4including both Nārada and Pabbata.

SNP 3.6:48.1Homage to you, O thoroughbred! SNP 3.6:48.2Homage to you, supreme among men! SNP 3.6:48.3In the world with its gods, SNP 3.6:48.4you have no counterpart.

SNP 3.6:49.1You are the Buddha, you are the Teacher,SNP 3.6:49.2you are the sage who has overcome Māra; SNP 3.6:49.3you have cut off the underlying tendencies,SNP 3.6:49.4you’ve crossed over, and you bring humanity across.

SNP 3.6:5.1BJ 25.154PTS-VP-PLI 93Then he thought,SNP 3.6:5.2“Even those ascetics and brahmins who elderly and senior, who are advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; who are senior, long standing, long gone forth; who lead an order and a community, and teach a community; who are well-known and famous religious founders, regarded as holy by many people—that isSNP 3.6:5.3Pūraṇa Kassapa and the rest—SNP 3.6:5.4were stumped by my question. SNP 3.6:5.5They displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness, and even questioned me in return.SNP 3.6:5.6How can the ascetic Gotama possibly answer my question,SNP 3.6:5.7since he is so young in age and newly gone forth?”

SNP 3.6:50.1You have transcended attachments,SNP 3.6:50.2your defilements are shattered; SNP 3.6:50.3you are a lion, free of grasping,SNP 3.6:50.4with fear and dread given up.

SNP 3.6:51.1Like a graceful lotusSNP 3.6:51.2to which water does not stick, SNP 3.6:51.3so both good and evilSNP 3.6:51.4do not stick to you. SNP 3.6:51.5Stretch out your feet, great hero:SNP 3.6:51.6Sabhiya bows to the Teacher.”

SNP 3.6:52.1BJ 25.166PTS-VP-PLI 102Then the wanderer Sabhiya bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet and said, SNP 3.6:52.2“Excellent, sir! Excellent! … SNP 3.6:52.3I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. SNP 3.6:52.4Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”

SNP 3.6:53.1“Seniya, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood. SNP 3.6:53.2However, I have recognized individual differences in this matter.”

SNP 3.6:54.1“Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.” SNP 3.6:54.2And the wanderer Sabhiya received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence. SNP 3.6:54.3And Venerable Sabhiya became one of the perfected.

SNP 3.6:6.1Then he thought,SNP 3.6:6.2“An ascetic should not be looked down upon or disparaged because they are young. SNP 3.6:6.3Though young, the ascetic Gotama has great psychic power and might. Why don’t I ask him this question?”

SNP 3.6:7.1Then Sabhiya set out for Rājagaha. SNP 3.6:7.2Traveling stage by stage, he came to Rājagaha, the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground. He went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him. SNP 3.6:7.3When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, SNP 3.6:7.4and addressed the Buddha in verse:

SNP 3.6:8.1“I’ve come full of doubts and uncertainties,”SNP 3.6:8.2said Sabhiya, SNP 3.6:8.3“wishing to ask a question.SNP 3.6:8.4Please solve them for me. SNP 3.6:8.5Answer my questions in turn, in accordance with the truth.”

SNP 3.6:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 94“You have come from afar, Sabhiya,” SNP 3.6:9.2said the Buddha,SNP 3.6:9.3“wishing to ask a question. SNP 3.6:9.4I shall solve them for you,SNP 3.6:9.5answering your questions in turn, in accordance with the truth.

  • SNP 3.7:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.7:0.2With Sela

SNP 3.7:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 103So I have heard. SNP 3.7:1.2At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Northern Āpaṇas together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Northern Āpaṇas named Āpaṇa. SNP 3.7:1.3The matted-hair ascetic Keṇiya heard: SNP 3.7:1.4“It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants. SNP 3.7:1.5He has this good reputation: SNP 3.7:1.6‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ SNP 3.7:1.7He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others. SNP 3.7:1.8He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. SNP 3.7:1.9It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

SNP 3.7:10.1Then Sela went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. SNP 3.7:10.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. SNP 3.7:10.3and scrutinized the Buddha’s body for the thirty-two marks of a great man. SNP 3.7:10.4He saw all of them except for two, SNP 3.7:10.5which he has doubts about: SNP 3.7:10.6whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.

SNP 3.7:11.1BJ 25.174PTS-VP-PLI 108Then it occurred to the Buddha, SNP 3.7:11.2“Sela sees all the marks except for two, SNP 3.7:11.3which he has doubts about: SNP 3.7:11.4whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.” SNP 3.7:11.5The Buddha used his psychic power to will that Sela would see his private parts covered in a foreskin. SNP 3.7:11.6And he stuck out his tongue and stroked back and forth on his ear holes and nostrils, and covered his entire forehead with his tongue.

SNP 3.7:12.1Then Sela thought, SNP 3.7:12.2“The ascetic Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks completely, lacking none. SNP 3.7:12.3But I don’t know whether or not he is an awakened one. SNP 3.7:12.4I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the teachers of teachers, said, SNP 3.7:12.5‘Those who are perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas reveal themselves when praised.’ SNP 3.7:12.6Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?” SNP 3.7:12.7Then Sela extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:

SNP 3.7:13.1“O Blessed One, your body’s perfect,SNP 3.7:13.2you’re radiant, handsome, lovely to behold; SNP 3.7:13.3golden colored,SNP 3.7:13.4with teeth so white; you’re strong.

SNP 3.7:14.1The characteristicsSNP 3.7:14.2of a handsome man, SNP 3.7:14.3the marks of a great man,SNP 3.7:14.4are all found on your body.

SNP 3.7:15.1Your eyes are clear, your face is fair,SNP 3.7:15.2you’re formidable, upright, majestic. SNP 3.7:15.3In the midst of the Saṅgha of ascetics,SNP 3.7:15.4you shine like the sun.

SNP 3.7:16.1You’re a mendicant fine to see, SNP 3.7:16.2with skin of golden sheen. SNP 3.7:16.3But with such excellent appearance,SNP 3.7:16.4what do you want with the ascetic life?

SNP 3.7:17.1BJ 25.176You’re fit to be a king,SNP 3.7:17.2a wheel-turning monarch, chief of charioteers, SNP 3.7:17.3victorious in the four directions,SNP 3.7:17.4lord of all India.

SNP 3.7:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 109Aristocrats, nobles, and kings SNP 3.7:18.2ought follow your rule. SNP 3.7:18.3Gotama, you should reign SNP 3.7:18.4as king of kings, lord of men!”

SNP 3.7:19.1“I am a king, Sela”,SNP 3.7:19.2said the Buddha, SNP 3.7:19.3“the supreme king of the teaching.SNP 3.7:19.4By the teaching I roll forth the wheel SNP 3.7:19.5which cannot be rolled back.”

SNP 3.7:2.1BJ 25.168PTS-VP-PLI 104So Keṇiya approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him. SNP 3.7:2.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. SNP 3.7:2.3The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk. SNP 3.7:2.4Then he said to the Buddha, SNP 3.7:2.5“Would Master Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?” SNP 3.7:2.6When he said this, the Buddha said to him, SNP 3.7:2.7“The Saṅgha is large, Keṇiya; there are 1,250 mendicants. And you are devoted to the brahmins.”

SNP 3.7:20.1“You claim to be awakened,”SNP 3.7:20.2said Sela the brahmin, SNP 3.7:20.3“the supreme king of the teaching.SNP 3.7:20.4‘I roll forth the teaching’: SNP 3.7:20.5so you say, Gotama.

SNP 3.7:21.1Then who is your general,SNP 3.7:21.2the disciple who follows the Teacher’s way? SNP 3.7:21.3Who keeps rolling the wheel SNP 3.7:21.4of the teaching you rolled forth?”

SNP 3.7:22.1“By me the wheel was rolled forth,”SNP 3.7:22.2said the Buddha, SNP 3.7:22.3“the supreme wheel of the teaching.SNP 3.7:22.4Sāriputta, taking after the Realized One, SNP 3.7:22.5keeps it rolling on.

SNP 3.7:23.1I have known what should be known, SNP 3.7:23.2and developed what should be developed, SNP 3.7:23.3and given up what should be given up: SNP 3.7:23.4and so, brahmin, I am a Buddha.

SNP 3.7:24.1Dispel your doubt in me—SNP 3.7:24.2make up your mind, brahmin! SNP 3.7:24.3The sight of a BuddhaSNP 3.7:24.4is hard to find again.

SNP 3.7:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 110I am a Buddha, brahmin, SNP 3.7:25.2the supreme surgeon,SNP 3.7:25.3one of those whose appearance in the world SNP 3.7:25.4is hard to find again.

SNP 3.7:26.1Holy, unequaled,SNP 3.7:26.2crusher of Māra’s army; SNP 3.7:26.3having subdued all my opponents,SNP 3.7:26.4I rejoice, fearing nothing from any quarter.”

SNP 3.7:27.1“Pay heed, sirs, to what SNP 3.7:27.2is spoken by the seer. SNP 3.7:27.3The surgeon, the great hero,SNP 3.7:27.4roars like a lion in the jungle.

SNP 3.7:28.1BJ 25.178Holy, unequaled,SNP 3.7:28.2crusher of Māra’s army; SNP 3.7:28.3who would not be inspired by him,SNP 3.7:28.4even one whose nature is dark?

SNP 3.7:29.1Those who wish may follow me;SNP 3.7:29.2those who don’t may go. SNP 3.7:29.3Right here, I’ll go forth in his presence,SNP 3.7:29.4the one of such splendid wisdom.”

SNP 3.7:3.1For a second time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering. SNP 3.7:3.2“Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and that I am devoted to the brahmins.SNP 3.7:3.3Would Master Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?” SNP 3.7:3.4And for a second time, the Buddha gave the same reply.

SNP 3.7:30.1“Sir, if you likeSNP 3.7:30.2in the teaching of the Buddha, SNP 3.7:30.3we’ll also go forth in his presence,SNP 3.7:30.4the one of such splendid wisdom.”

SNP 3.7:31.1“These three hundred brahminsSNP 3.7:31.2with joined palms held up, ask: SNP 3.7:31.3‘May we lead the spiritual lifeSNP 3.7:31.4in your presence, Blessed One?’”

SNP 3.7:32.1“The spiritual life is well explained,”SNP 3.7:32.2said the Buddha, SNP 3.7:32.3“visible in this very life, immediately effective.SNP 3.7:32.4Here the going forth isn’t in vain SNP 3.7:32.5for one who trains with diligence.”

SNP 3.7:33.1PTS-VP-PLI 111And the brahmin Sela together with his assembly received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence. SNP 3.7:33.2And when the night had passed Keṇiya had a variety of delicious foods prepared in his own home. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying, SNP 3.7:33.3“Itʼs time, Master Gotama, the meal is ready.” SNP 3.7:33.4Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Keṇiya’s hermitage, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.

SNP 3.7:34.1Then Keṇiya served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods. SNP 3.7:34.2When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Keṇiya took a low seat and sat to one side. SNP 3.7:34.3The Buddha expressed his appreciation with these verses:

SNP 3.7:35.1“The foremost of sacrifices is offering to the sacred flame; SNP 3.7:35.2the Gāyatrī Mantra is the foremost of poetic meters; SNP 3.7:35.3of humans, the king is the foremost; SNP 3.7:35.4the ocean’s the foremost of rivers;

SNP 3.7:36.1the foremost of stars is the moon; SNP 3.7:36.2the sun is the foremost of lights; SNP 3.7:36.3for those who sacrifice seeking merit, SNP 3.7:36.4the Saṅgha is the foremost.”

SNP 3.7:37.1BJ 25.180PTS-VP-PLI 112When the Buddha had expressed his appreciation to Keṇiya the matted-hair ascetic with these verses, he got up from his seat and left. SNP 3.7:37.2Then Venerable Sela and his assembly, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. They lived having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness. SNP 3.7:37.3And Venerable Sela together with his assembly became perfected.

SNP 3.7:38.1Then Sela with his assembly went to see the Buddha. He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

SNP 3.7:39.1“This is the eighth day sinceSNP 3.7:39.2we went for refuge, O seer. SNP 3.7:39.3In these seven days, Blessed One,SNP 3.7:39.4we’ve become tamed in your teaching.

SNP 3.7:4.1For a third time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering. SNP 3.7:4.10Meanwhile, Keṇiya set up the pavilion himself.

SNP 3.7:4.2“Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and that I am devoted to the brahmins.SNP 3.7:4.3Would Master Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?” SNP 3.7:4.4The Buddha consented in silence. SNP 3.7:4.5Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Keṇiya got up from his seat and went to his own hermitage. There he addressed his friends and colleagues, relatives and family members, SNP 3.7:4.6“Gentlemen, please listen. SNP 3.7:4.7The ascetic Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal. SNP 3.7:4.8Please help me with the preparations.” SNP 3.7:4.9“Yes, sir,” they replied. Some dug ovens, some chopped wood, some washed dishes, some set out a water jar, and some spread out seats.

SNP 3.7:40.1You are the Buddha, you are the Teacher,SNP 3.7:40.2you are the sage who has overcome Māra; SNP 3.7:40.3you have cut off the underlying tendencies,SNP 3.7:40.4you’ve crossed over, and you bring humanity across.

SNP 3.7:41.1You have transcended attachments,SNP 3.7:41.2your defilements are shattered; SNP 3.7:41.3you are a lion, free of grasping,SNP 3.7:41.4with fear and dread given up.

SNP 3.7:42.1These three hundred mendicantsSNP 3.7:42.2stand with joined palms raised. SNP 3.7:42.3Stretch out your feet, great hero:SNP 3.7:42.4let these giants bow to the Teacher.”

SNP 3.7:5.1BJ 25.170PTS-VP-PLI 105Now at that time the brahmin Sela was residing in Āpaṇa. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies, ritual, phonology and etymology, and the testament as fifth. He knew philology and grammar, and was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. And he was teaching three hundred students to recite the hymns.

SNP 3.7:6.1And at that time Keṇiya was devoted to Sela. SNP 3.7:6.2Then Sela, while going for a walk escorted by the three hundred students, approached Keṇiya’s hermitage. SNP 3.7:6.3He saw the preparations going on, SNP 3.7:6.4and said to Keṇiya, SNP 3.7:6.5“Keṇiya, is your son or daughter being married? Or are you setting up a big sacrifice? Or has King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha been invited for tomorrow’s meal?”

SNP 3.7:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 106“There is no marriage, Sela, and the king is not coming. SNP 3.7:7.10“I said ‘the awakened one’.”

SNP 3.7:7.2Rather, I am setting up a big sacrifice. SNP 3.7:7.3The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants. SNP 3.7:7.4He has this good reputation: SNP 3.7:7.5‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ SNP 3.7:7.6He has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal together with the mendicant Saṅgha.” SNP 3.7:7.7“Mister Keṇiya, did you say ‘the awakened one’?” SNP 3.7:7.8“I said ‘the awakened one’.” SNP 3.7:7.9“Mister Keṇiya, did you say ‘the awakened one’?”

SNP 3.7:8.1BJ 25.172Then Sela thought, SNP 3.7:8.10“But Keṇiya, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

SNP 3.7:8.2“It’s hard to even find the word ‘awakened one’ in the world. SNP 3.7:8.3The thirty-two marks of a great man have been handed down in our hymns. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other. SNP 3.7:8.4If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures. SNP 3.7:8.5He has the following seven treasures: SNP 3.7:8.6the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the treasurer, and the counselor as the seventh treasure. SNP 3.7:8.7He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies. SNP 3.7:8.8After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword. SNP 3.7:8.9But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.

SNP 3.7:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 107When he said this, Keṇiya pointed with his right arm and said, SNP 3.7:9.2“There, Mister Sela, at that line of blue forest.” SNP 3.7:9.3Then Sela, together with his students, approached the Buddha. SNP 3.7:9.4He said to his students, SNP 3.7:9.5“Come quietly, gentlemen, tread gently. SNP 3.7:9.6For the Buddhas are intimidating, like a lion living alone. SNP 3.7:9.7When I’m consulting with the ascetic Gotama, don’t interrupt. SNP 3.7:9.8Wait until I’ve finished speaking.”

  • SNP 3.8:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.8:0.2The Dart

SNP 3.8:1.1BJ 25.182Unforeseen and unknownSNP 3.8:1.2is the extent of this mortal life— SNP 3.8:1.3hard and shortSNP 3.8:1.4and bound to pain.

SNP 3.8:10.1If a bewildered person,SNP 3.8:10.2lamenting and self-harming, SNP 3.8:10.3could extract any good from that,SNP 3.8:10.4then those who see clearly would do the same.

SNP 3.8:11.1BJ 25.184For not by weeping and wailing SNP 3.8:11.2will you find peace of heart.SNP 3.8:11.3It just gives rise to more suffering, SNP 3.8:11.4and distresses your body.

SNP 3.8:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 114Growing thin and pale, SNP 3.8:12.2you hurt yourself.SNP 3.8:12.3It does nothing to help the dead: SNP 3.8:12.4your lamentation is in vain.

SNP 3.8:13.1Unless a person gives up grief,SNP 3.8:13.2they fall into suffering all the more. SNP 3.8:13.3Bewailing those whose time has come,SNP 3.8:13.4you fall under the sway of grief.

SNP 3.8:14.1See, too, other folk departingSNP 3.8:14.2to fare after their deeds; SNP 3.8:14.3fallen under the sway of death,SNP 3.8:14.4beings flounder while still here.

SNP 3.8:15.1For whatever you imagine it is, SNP 3.8:15.2it turns out to be something else. SNP 3.8:15.3Such is separation:SNP 3.8:15.4see the way of the world!

SNP 3.8:16.1Even if a human lives SNP 3.8:16.2a hundred years or more, SNP 3.8:16.3they are parted from their family circle,SNP 3.8:16.4they leave this life behind.

SNP 3.8:17.1Therefore, having learned from the Perfected One,SNP 3.8:17.2dispel lamentation. SNP 3.8:17.3Seeing the dead and departed, think:SNP 3.8:17.4“I cannot escape this.”

SNP 3.8:18.1As one would extinguishSNP 3.8:18.2a blazing refuge with water, SNP 3.8:18.3so too a sage—a wise,SNP 3.8:18.4astute, and skilled person— SNP 3.8:18.5would swiftly blow away grief that comes up,SNP 3.8:18.6like the wind a tuft of cotton.

SNP 3.8:19.1One who seeks their own happinessSNP 3.8:19.2would pluck out the dart from themselves— SNP 3.8:19.3the wailing and moaning,SNP 3.8:19.4and sadness inside.

SNP 3.8:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 113There is no way that SNP 3.8:2.2those born will not die. SNP 3.8:2.3On reaching old age death follows: SNP 3.8:2.4such is the nature of living creatures.

SNP 3.8:20.1With dart plucked out, unattached,SNP 3.8:20.2having found peace of mind, SNP 3.8:20.3overcoming all sorrow,SNP 3.8:20.4one is sorrowless and extinguished.”

SNP 3.8:3.1As ripe fruitSNP 3.8:3.2are always in danger of falling, SNP 3.8:3.3so mortals once bornSNP 3.8:3.4are always in danger of death.

SNP 3.8:4.1As clay pots SNP 3.8:4.2made by a potter SNP 3.8:4.3all end up being broken,SNP 3.8:4.4so is the life of mortals.

SNP 3.8:5.1Young and old,SNP 3.8:5.2foolish and wise— SNP 3.8:5.3all go under the sway of death;SNP 3.8:5.4all are destined to die.

SNP 3.8:6.1When those overcome by deathSNP 3.8:6.2leave this world for the next, SNP 3.8:6.3a father cannot protect his son,SNP 3.8:6.4nor relatives their kin.

SNP 3.8:7.1See how, while relatives look on,SNP 3.8:7.2wailing profusely, SNP 3.8:7.3mortals are led away one by one,SNP 3.8:7.4like a cow to the slaughter.

SNP 3.8:8.1And so the world is strickenSNP 3.8:8.2by old age and by death. SNP 3.8:8.3That is why the wise do not grieve,SNP 3.8:8.4for they understand the way of the world.

SNP 3.8:9.1For one whose path you do not know—SNP 3.8:9.2not whence they came nor where they went— SNP 3.8:9.3you lament in vain,SNP 3.8:9.4seeing neither end.

  • SNP 3.9:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.9:0.2With Vāseṭṭha

SNP 3.9:1.1BJ 25.186PTS-VP-PLI 115So I have heard. SNP 3.9:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala. SNP 3.9:1.3Now at that time several very well-known well-to-do brahmins were residing in Icchānaṅgala. They included SNP 3.9:1.4the brahmins Caṅkī, Tārukkha, Pokkharasāti, Jāṇussoṇi, Todeyya, and others. SNP 3.9:1.5Then as the brahmin students Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja were going for a walk they began to discuss the question:SNP 3.9:1.6“How do you become a brahmin?”

SNP 3.9:10.1As people honor with joined palms SNP 3.9:10.2the moon on the cusp of waxing, SNP 3.9:10.3bowing, they revere SNP 3.9:10.4Gotama in the world.

SNP 3.9:11.1We ask this of Gotama, SNP 3.9:11.2the eye arisen in the world: SNP 3.9:11.3is one a brahmin due to birth, SNP 3.9:11.4or else because of actions? SNP 3.9:11.5We don’t know, please tell us, SNP 3.9:11.6so that we can recognize a brahmin.”

SNP 3.9:12.1“I shall explain to you,” SNP 3.9:12.2said the Buddha, SNP 3.9:12.3“accurately and in sequence, SNP 3.9:12.4the taxonomy of living creatures, SNP 3.9:12.5for species are indeed diverse.

SNP 3.9:13.1Know the grass and trees, SNP 3.9:13.2though they lack self-awareness. SNP 3.9:13.3They’re defined by birth, SNP 3.9:13.4for species are indeed diverse.

SNP 3.9:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 118Next there are bugs and moths, SNP 3.9:14.2and so on, to ants and termites. SNP 3.9:14.3They’re defined by birth, SNP 3.9:14.4for species are indeed diverse.

SNP 3.9:15.1Know the quadrupeds, too, SNP 3.9:15.2both small and large. SNP 3.9:15.3They’re defined by birth, SNP 3.9:15.4for species are indeed diverse.

SNP 3.9:16.1BJ 25.190Know, too, the long-backed snakes, SNP 3.9:16.2crawling on their bellies. SNP 3.9:16.3They’re defined by birth, SNP 3.9:16.4for species are indeed diverse.

SNP 3.9:17.1Next know the fish, SNP 3.9:17.2whose habitat is the water. SNP 3.9:17.3They’re defined by birth, SNP 3.9:17.4for species are indeed diverse.

SNP 3.9:18.1Next know the birds, SNP 3.9:18.2flying with wings as chariots. SNP 3.9:18.3They’re defined by birth, SNP 3.9:18.4for species are indeed diverse.

SNP 3.9:19.1While the differences between these species SNP 3.9:19.2are defined by birth, SNP 3.9:19.3the differences between humans SNP 3.9:19.4are not defined by birth.

SNP 3.9:2.1Bhāradvāja said this: SNP 3.9:2.2“When you’re well born on both your mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, irrefutable and impeccable in questions of ancestry back to the seventh paternal generation—

SNP 3.9:2.3then you’re a brahmin.”

SNP 3.9:20.1Not by hair nor by head, SNP 3.9:20.2not by ear nor by eye, SNP 3.9:20.3not by mouth nor by nose, SNP 3.9:20.4not by lips nor by eyebrow,

SNP 3.9:21.1not by shoulder nor by neck, SNP 3.9:21.2not by belly nor by back, SNP 3.9:21.3not by buttocks nor by breast, SNP 3.9:21.4not by groin nor by genitals,

SNP 3.9:22.1not by hands nor by feet, SNP 3.9:22.2not by fingers nor by nails, SNP 3.9:22.3not by knees nor by thighs, SNP 3.9:22.4not by color nor by voice: SNP 3.9:22.5none of these are defined by birth SNP 3.9:22.6as it is for other species.

SNP 3.9:23.1PTS-VP-PLI 119In individual human bodies SNP 3.9:23.2you can’t find such distinctions. SNP 3.9:23.3The distinctions among humans SNP 3.9:23.4are spoken of by convention.

SNP 3.9:24.1Anyone among humans SNP 3.9:24.2who lives off keeping cattle: SNP 3.9:24.3know them, Vāseṭṭha, SNP 3.9:24.4as a farmer, not a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:25.1Anyone among humans SNP 3.9:25.2who lives off various professions: SNP 3.9:25.3know them, Vāseṭṭha, SNP 3.9:25.4as a professional, not a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:26.1Anyone among humans SNP 3.9:26.2who lives off trade: SNP 3.9:26.3know them, Vāseṭṭha, SNP 3.9:26.4as a trader, not a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:27.1BJ 25.192Anyone among humans SNP 3.9:27.2who lives off serving others: SNP 3.9:27.3know them, Vāseṭṭha, SNP 3.9:27.4as an employee, not a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:28.1Anyone among humans SNP 3.9:28.2who lives off stealing: SNP 3.9:28.3know them, Vāseṭṭha, SNP 3.9:28.4as a bandit, not a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:29.1Anyone among humans SNP 3.9:29.2who lives off archery: SNP 3.9:29.3know them, Vāseṭṭha, SNP 3.9:29.4as a soldier, not a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 116Vāseṭṭha said this: SNP 3.9:3.2“When you’re ethical and accomplished in doing your duties—SNP 3.9:3.3then you’re a brahmin.” SNP 3.9:3.4But neither was able to persuade the other.

SNP 3.9:30.1Anyone among humans SNP 3.9:30.2who lives off priesthood: SNP 3.9:30.3know them, Vāseṭṭha, SNP 3.9:30.4as a sacrificer, not a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:31.1Anyone among humans SNP 3.9:31.2who taxes village and nation, SNP 3.9:31.3know them, Vāseṭṭha, SNP 3.9:31.4as a ruler, not a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:32.1I don’t call someone a brahmin SNP 3.9:32.2after the mother or womb they came from. SNP 3.9:32.3If they still have attachments, SNP 3.9:32.4they’re just someone who says ‘sir’. SNP 3.9:32.5Having nothing, taking nothing: SNP 3.9:32.6that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:33.1Having cut off all fetters SNP 3.9:33.2they have no anxiety; SNP 3.9:33.3they’ve got over clinging, and are detached: SNP 3.9:33.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:34.1PTS-VP-PLI 120They’ve cut the strap and harness, SNP 3.9:34.2the reins and bridle too;SNP 3.9:34.3with cross-bar lifted, they’re awakened: SNP 3.9:34.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:35.1Abuse, killing, caging: SNP 3.9:35.2they endure these without anger. SNP 3.9:35.3Patience is their powerful army: SNP 3.9:35.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:36.1Not irritable or stuck up, SNP 3.9:36.2dutiful in precepts and observances, SNP 3.9:36.3tamed, bearing their final body: SNP 3.9:36.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:37.1BJ 25.194Like water from a lotus leaf, SNP 3.9:37.2like a mustard seed off a pin-point,SNP 3.9:37.3sensual pleasures slip off them: SNP 3.9:37.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:38.1They understand for themselves SNP 3.9:38.2the end of suffering in this life; SNP 3.9:38.3with burden put down, detached: SNP 3.9:38.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:39.1Deep in wisdom, intelligent, SNP 3.9:39.2expert in the variety of paths; SNP 3.9:39.3arrived at the highest goal: SNP 3.9:39.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:4.1So Vāseṭṭha said to Bhāradvāja, SNP 3.9:4.2“Master Bhāradvāja, the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—is staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala. SNP 3.9:4.3He has this good reputation: SNP 3.9:4.4‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ SNP 3.9:4.5Come, let’s go to see him and ask him about this matter. SNP 3.9:4.6As he answers, so we’ll remember it.” SNP 3.9:4.7“Yes, sir,” replied Bhāradvāja.

SNP 3.9:40.1Socializing with neither SNP 3.9:40.2householders nor the homeless; SNP 3.9:40.3a migrant with no shelter, few in wishes: SNP 3.9:40.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:41.1They’ve laid aside violence SNP 3.9:41.2against creatures firm and frail; SNP 3.9:41.3not killing or making others kill: SNP 3.9:41.4that’s who I call a brahmin.
