SNP 3.9:42.1Not fighting among those who fight, SNP 3.9:42.2extinguished among those who are armed, SNP 3.9:42.3not taking among those who take: SNP 3.9:42.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:43.1They’ve discarded greed and hate, SNP 3.9:43.2along with conceit and contempt, SNP 3.9:43.3like a mustard seed off the point of a pin: SNP 3.9:43.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:44.1PTS-VP-PLI 121The words they utter SNP 3.9:44.2are sweet, informative, and true, SNP 3.9:44.3and don’t offend anyone: SNP 3.9:44.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:45.1They don’t steal anything in the world, SNP 3.9:45.2long or short, SNP 3.9:45.3fine or coarse, beautiful or ugly: SNP 3.9:45.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:46.1BJ 25.196They have no hope SNP 3.9:46.2in this world and the next. SNP 3.9:46.3with no need for hope, detached: SNP 3.9:46.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:47.1They have no clinging, SNP 3.9:47.2knowledge has freed them of indecision, SNP 3.9:47.3they’ve plunged right into the deathless: SNP 3.9:47.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:48.1They’ve escaped clinging SNP 3.9:48.2to both good and bad deeds; SNP 3.9:48.3sorrowless, stainless, pure: SNP 3.9:48.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:49.1Pure as the spotless moon, SNP 3.9:49.2clear and undisturbed, SNP 3.9:49.3they’ve ended desire to be reborn: SNP 3.9:49.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:5.1So they went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him. SNP 3.9:5.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side, SNP 3.9:5.3and Vāseṭṭha addressed the Buddha in verse:

SNP 3.9:50.1They’ve got past this grueling swamp SNP 3.9:50.2of delusion, transmigration. SNP 3.9:50.3They’ve crossed over to the far shore, SNP 3.9:50.4stilled and free of indecision. SNP 3.9:50.5They’re extinguished by not grasping: SNP 3.9:50.6that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:51.1They’ve given up sensual stimulations, SNP 3.9:51.2and have gone forth from lay life; SNP 3.9:51.3they’ve ended rebirth in the sensual realm: SNP 3.9:51.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:52.1They’ve given up craving, SNP 3.9:52.2and have gone forth from lay life; SNP 3.9:52.3they’ve ended craving to be reborn: SNP 3.9:52.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:53.1They’ve given up human bonds, SNP 3.9:53.2and gone beyond heavenly bonds; SNP 3.9:53.3detached from all attachments: SNP 3.9:53.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:54.1Giving up discontent and desire, SNP 3.9:54.2they’re cooled and free of attachments; SNP 3.9:54.3a hero, master of the whole world: SNP 3.9:54.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:55.1BJ 25.198PTS-VP-PLI 122They know the passing away SNP 3.9:55.2and rebirth of all beings; SNP 3.9:55.3unattached, holy, awakened: SNP 3.9:55.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:56.1Gods, fairies, and humans SNP 3.9:56.2don’t know their destiny; SNP 3.9:56.3the perfected ones with defilements ended: SNP 3.9:56.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:57.1They have nothing before or after, SNP 3.9:57.2or even in between. SNP 3.9:57.3Having nothing, taking nothing: SNP 3.9:57.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:58.1Leader of the herd, excellent hero, SNP 3.9:58.2great hermit and victor; SNP 3.9:58.3unstirred, washed, awakened: SNP 3.9:58.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:59.1They know their past lives, SNP 3.9:59.2and sees heaven and places of loss, SNP 3.9:59.3and has attained the ending of rebirth, SNP 3.9:59.4that’s who I call a brahmin.

SNP 3.9:6.1BJ 25.188“We’re both authorized masters SNP 3.9:6.2of the three Vedas. SNP 3.9:6.3I’m a student of Pokkharasāti, SNP 3.9:6.4and he of Tārukkha.

SNP 3.9:60.1For name and clan are formulated SNP 3.9:60.2as mere convention in the world. SNP 3.9:60.3Produced by mutual agreement, SNP 3.9:60.4they’re formulated for each individual.

SNP 3.9:61.1For a long time this misconception SNP 3.9:61.2has prejudiced those who don’t understand. SNP 3.9:61.3Ignorant, they declare SNP 3.9:61.4that one is a brahmin by birth.

SNP 3.9:62.1You’re not a brahmin by birth, SNP 3.9:62.2nor by birth a non-brahmin. SNP 3.9:62.3You’re a brahmin by your deeds, SNP 3.9:62.4and by deeds a non-brahmin.

SNP 3.9:63.1You’re a farmer by your deeds, SNP 3.9:63.2by deeds you’re a professional; SNP 3.9:63.3you’re a trader by your deeds, SNP 3.9:63.4by deeds are you an employee;

SNP 3.9:64.1you’re a bandit by your deeds, SNP 3.9:64.2by deeds you’re a soldier; SNP 3.9:64.3you’re a sacrificer by your deeds, SNP 3.9:64.4by deeds you’re a ruler.

SNP 3.9:65.1BJ 25.200PTS-VP-PLI 123In this way the astute regard deeds SNP 3.9:65.2in accord with truth.SNP 3.9:65.3Seeing dependent origination, SNP 3.9:65.4they’re expert in deeds and their results.

SNP 3.9:66.1Deeds make the world go on, SNP 3.9:66.2deeds make people go on; SNP 3.9:66.3sentient beings are bound by deeds, SNP 3.9:66.4like a moving chariot’s linchpin.

SNP 3.9:67.1By austerity and spiritual practice, SNP 3.9:67.2by restraint and by self-control: SNP 3.9:67.3that’s how to become a brahmin,SNP 3.9:67.4this is the supreme brahmin.

SNP 3.9:68.1Accomplished in the three knowledges, SNP 3.9:68.2peaceful, with rebirth ended, SNP 3.9:68.3know them, Vāseṭṭha, SNP 3.9:68.4as Brahmā and Sakka to the wise.”

SNP 3.9:69.1When he had spoken, Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja said to him, SNP 3.9:69.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! … SNP 3.9:69.3From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

SNP 3.9:7.1We’re fully qualified SNP 3.9:7.2in all the Vedic experts teach. SNP 3.9:7.3As philologists and grammarians, SNP 3.9:7.4we match our teachers in recitation.

SNP 3.9:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 117We have a dispute SNP 3.9:8.2regarding the question of ancestry. SNP 3.9:8.3For Bhāradvāja says that SNP 3.9:8.4one is a brahmin due to birth, SNP 3.9:8.5but I declare it’s because of one’s actions. SNP 3.9:8.6Oh seer, know this as our debate.

SNP 3.9:9.1Since neither of us was able SNP 3.9:9.2to convince the other, SNP 3.9:9.3we’ve come to ask you, sir, SNP 3.9:9.4renowned as the awakened one.

  • SNP 3.10:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.10:0.2With Kokālika

SNP 3.10:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 124So I have heard. SNP 3.10:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. SNP 3.10:1.3Then the mendicant Kokālika went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him, SNP 3.10:1.4“Sir, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have wicked desires. They’ve fallen under the sway of wicked desires.”

SNP 3.10:10.1When you praise someone worthy of criticism, SNP 3.10:10.2or criticize someone worthy of praise, SNP 3.10:10.3you choose bad luck with your own mouth: SNP 3.10:10.4you’ll never find happiness that way.

SNP 3.10:11.1Bad luck at dice is a trivial thing, SNP 3.10:11.2if all you lose is your money SNP 3.10:11.3and all you own, even yourself. SNP 3.10:11.4What’s really terrible luck SNP 3.10:11.5is to hate the holy ones.

SNP 3.10:12.1For more than two quinquadecillion years, SNP 3.10:12.2and another five quattuordecillion years, SNP 3.10:12.3a slanderer of noble ones goes to hell, SNP 3.10:12.4having aimed bad words and thoughts at them.

SNP 3.10:13.1A liar goes to hell, SNP 3.10:13.2as does one who denies what they did. SNP 3.10:13.3Both are equal in the hereafter,SNP 3.10:13.4those men of base deeds.

SNP 3.10:14.1Whoever wrongs a man who has done no wrong, SNP 3.10:14.2a pure man who has not a blemish, SNP 3.10:14.3the evil backfires on the fool, SNP 3.10:14.4like fine dust thrown upwind.

SNP 3.10:15.1BJ 25.208PTS-VP-PLI 128One addicted to the way of greed, SNP 3.10:15.2abuses others with their speech,SNP 3.10:15.3faithless, miserly, uncharitable, SNP 3.10:15.4stingy, addicted to backbiting.

SNP 3.10:16.1Foul-mouthed, divisive, ignoble,SNP 3.10:16.2a life-destroyer, wicked, wrongdoer, SNP 3.10:16.3worst of men, cursed, base-born—SNP 3.10:16.4quiet now, for you are bound for hell.

SNP 3.10:17.1You stir up dust, causing harm,SNP 3.10:17.2when you, evildoer, malign the good. SNP 3.10:17.3Having done many bad deeds,SNP 3.10:17.4you’ll go to the pit for a long time.

SNP 3.10:18.1For no-one’s deeds are ever lost,SNP 3.10:18.2they return to their owner. SNP 3.10:18.3In the next life that stupid evildoer SNP 3.10:18.4sees suffering in themselves.

SNP 3.10:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 129They approach the place of impalement, SNP 3.10:19.2with its iron spikes, sharp blades, and iron stakes.SNP 3.10:19.3Then there is the food, which appropriately, SNP 3.10:19.4is like a red-hot iron ball.

SNP 3.10:2.1BJ 25.202When this was said, the Buddha said to Kokālika, SNP 3.10:2.2“Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika! SNP 3.10:2.3Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna, SNP 3.10:2.4they’re good monks.”

SNP 3.10:20.1For the speakers speak not sweetly,SNP 3.10:20.2they don’t hurry there, or find shelter. SNP 3.10:20.3They lie upon a spread of coals,SNP 3.10:20.4they enter a blazing mass of fire.

SNP 3.10:21.1Wrapping them in a net,SNP 3.10:21.2they strike them there with iron hammers. SNP 3.10:21.3They come to blinding darkness,SNP 3.10:21.4which spreads about them like a fog.

SNP 3.10:22.1BJ 25.210Next they enter a copper pot,SNP 3.10:22.2a blazing mass of fire. SNP 3.10:22.3There they roast for a long time,SNP 3.10:22.4writhing in the masses of fire.

SNP 3.10:23.1PTS-VP-PLI 130Then the evildoer roasts there SNP 3.10:23.2in a mixture of pus and blood.SNP 3.10:23.3No matter where they settle, SNP 3.10:23.4everything they touch there hurts them.

SNP 3.10:24.1The evildoer roasts in SNP 3.10:24.2worm-infested water. SNP 3.10:24.3There’s not even a shore to go to,SNP 3.10:24.4for all around are the same kind of pots.

SNP 3.10:25.1They enter the Wood of Sword-Leaves,SNP 3.10:25.2so sharp they cut their body to pieces. SNP 3.10:25.3Having grabbed the tongue with a hook,SNP 3.10:25.4they stab it, slashing back and forth.

SNP 3.10:26.1Then they approach the impassable Vetaraṇi River,SNP 3.10:26.2with its sharp blades, its razor blades. SNP 3.10:26.3Idiots fall into it,SNP 3.10:26.4the wicked who have done wicked deeds.

SNP 3.10:27.1PTS-VP-PLI 131There dogs all brown and spotted, SNP 3.10:27.2and raven flocks, and greedy jackalsSNP 3.10:27.3devour them as they wail, SNP 3.10:27.4while hawks and crows attack them.

SNP 3.10:28.1Hard, alas, is the life hereSNP 3.10:28.2that evildoers endure. SNP 3.10:28.3That’s why for the rest of this lifeSNP 3.10:28.4a person ought do their duty without fail.

SNP 3.10:29.1BJ 25.212Experts have counted the loads of sesame SNP 3.10:29.2as compared to the Pink Lotus Hell.SNP 3.10:29.3They amount to 50,000,000 times 10,000, SNP 3.10:29.4plus another 12,000,000,000.

SNP 3.10:3.1For a second time … SNP 3.10:3.2For a third time Kokālika said to the Buddha, SNP 3.10:3.3“Despite my faith and trust in the Buddha, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have wicked desires. They’ve fallen under the sway of wicked desires.” SNP 3.10:3.4For a third time, the Buddha said to Kokālika, SNP 3.10:3.5“Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika! SNP 3.10:3.6Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna, SNP 3.10:3.7they’re good monks.”

SNP 3.10:30.1As painful as life is said to be in hell,SNP 3.10:30.2that’s how long one must dwell there. SNP 3.10:30.3That’s why, for those who are pure, well-behaved, full of good qualities,SNP 3.10:30.4one should always guard one’s speech and mind.

SNP 3.10:4.1BJ 25.204PTS-VP-PLI 125Then Kokālika got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving. SNP 3.10:4.2Not long after he left his body erupted with boils the size of mustard seeds. SNP 3.10:4.3The boils grew to the size of mung beans, then chickpeas, then jujube seeds, then jujubes, then myrobalans, then unripe wood apples, then ripe wood apples. Finally they burst open, and pus and blood oozed out. SNP 3.10:4.4Then the mendicant Kokālika died of that illness. SNP 3.10:4.5He was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

SNP 3.10:5.1Then, late at night, the beautiful Brahmā Sahampati, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him, SNP 3.10:5.2“Sir, the mendicant Kokālika has passed away. SNP 3.10:5.3He was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.” SNP 3.10:5.4That’s what Brahmā Sahampati said. SNP 3.10:5.5Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.

SNP 3.10:6.1Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.

SNP 3.10:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 126When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha, SNP 3.10:7.2“Sir, how long is the life span in the Pink Lotus hell?” SNP 3.10:7.3“It’s long, mendicant. SNP 3.10:7.4It’s not easy to calculate how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.” SNP 3.10:7.5“But sir, is it possible to give a simile?” SNP 3.10:7.6“It’s possible,” said the Buddha.

SNP 3.10:8.1BJ 25.206“Suppose there was a Kosalan cartload of twenty bushels of sesame seed. And at the end of every hundred years someone would remove a single seed from it. SNP 3.10:8.10Twenty lifetimes in the Blue Water Lily hell equal one lifetime in the White Lotus hell. SNP 3.10:8.11Twenty lifetimes in the White Lotus hell equal one lifetime in the Pink Lotus hell. SNP 3.10:8.12The mendicant Kokālika has been reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.” SNP 3.10:8.13That is what the Buddha said. SNP 3.10:8.14Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

SNP 3.10:8.2By this means the Kosalan cartload of twenty bushels of sesame seed would run out faster than a single lifetime in the Abbuda hell. SNP 3.10:8.3Now, twenty lifetimes in the Abbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Nirabbuda hell. SNP 3.10:8.4Twenty lifetimes in the Nirabbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Ababa hell. SNP 3.10:8.5Twenty lifetimes in the Ababa hell equal one lifetime in the Aṭaṭa hell. SNP 3.10:8.6Twenty lifetimes in the Aṭaṭa hell equal one lifetime in the Ahaha hell. SNP 3.10:8.7Twenty lifetimes in the Ahaha hell equal one lifetime in the Yellow Lotus hell. SNP 3.10:8.8Twenty lifetimes in the Yellow Lotus hell equal one lifetime in the Sweet-Smelling hell. SNP 3.10:8.9Twenty lifetimes in the Sweet-Smelling hell equal one lifetime in the Blue Water Lily hell.

SNP 3.10:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 127“A person is born SNP 3.10:9.2with an axe in their mouth. SNP 3.10:9.3A fool cuts themselves with it SNP 3.10:9.4when they say bad words.

  • SNP 3.11:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.11:0.2About Nālaka

SNP 3.11:1.1The hermit Asita in his daily meditationSNP 3.11:1.2saw the bright-clad gods of the Thirty-Three SNP 3.11:1.3and their lord Sakka joyfully celebrating,SNP 3.11:1.4waving streamers in exuberant exaltation.

SNP 3.11:10.1The celestials held up a parasol in the sky,SNP 3.11:10.2many-ribbed and thousand-circled; SNP 3.11:10.3and golden-handled chowries waved—SNP 3.11:10.4but none could see who held the chowries or the parasols.

SNP 3.11:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 134When the dreadlocked hermit who they called “Dark Splendor” SNP 3.11:11.2had seen the boy like a gold nugget on a cream rugSNP 3.11:11.3with a white parasol held over his head, SNP 3.11:11.4he received him, elated and happy.

SNP 3.11:12.1BJ 25.216Having received the Sakyan bull, SNP 3.11:12.2the seeker, master of marks and hymns,SNP 3.11:12.3lifted up his voice with confident heart: SNP 3.11:12.4“He is supreme, the best of men!”

SNP 3.11:13.1But then, remembering he would depart this world,SNP 3.11:13.2his spirits fell and his tears flowed. SNP 3.11:13.3Seeing the weeping hermit, the Sakyans said,SNP 3.11:13.4“Surely there will be no threat to the boy?”

SNP 3.11:14.1Seeing the crestfallen Sakyans, the hermit said,SNP 3.11:14.2“I do not forsee harm befall the boy, SNP 3.11:14.3and there will be no threat to him,SNP 3.11:14.4not in the least; set your minds at ease.

SNP 3.11:15.1This boy shall reach the highest awakening.SNP 3.11:15.2As one of perfectly purified vision, compassionate for the welfare of the many, SNP 3.11:15.3he shall roll forth the wheel of the teaching;SNP 3.11:15.4his spiritual path will become widespread.

SNP 3.11:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 135But I have not long left in this life, SNP 3.11:16.2I shall die before then.SNP 3.11:16.3I will never hear the teaching of the one who bore the unequaled burden. SNP 3.11:16.4That’s why I’m so upset and distraught—it’s a disaster for me!”

SNP 3.11:17.1Having brought abundant happiness to the Sakyans,SNP 3.11:17.2the spiritual seeker left the royal compound. SNP 3.11:17.3He had a nephew; and out of compassionSNP 3.11:17.4he encouraged him in the teaching of the one who bore the unequaled burden.

SNP 3.11:18.1“When you hear the voice of another saying ‘Buddha’—SNP 3.11:18.2one who has attained awakening and who reveals the foremost teaching— SNP 3.11:18.3go there and ask about his breakthrough;SNP 3.11:18.4lead the spiritual life under that Blessed One.”

SNP 3.11:19.1BJ 25.218Now, that Nālaka had a store of accumulated merit; SNP 3.11:19.2so when instructed by one of such kindly intent,SNP 3.11:19.3with perfectly purified vision of the future, SNP 3.11:19.4he waited in hope for the Victor, guarding his senses.

SNP 3.11:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 132Seeing the gods rejoicing, elated, SNP 3.11:2.2he paid respects and said this there:SNP 3.11:2.3“Why is the community of gods in such excellent spirits? SNP 3.11:2.4Why take up streamers and whirl them about?

SNP 3.11:20.1PTS-VP-PLI 136When he heard of the Victor rolling forth the excellent wheel he went to him, SNP 3.11:20.2and seeing the leading hermit, he became confident.SNP 3.11:20.3The time of Asita’s instruction had arrived; SNP 3.11:20.4so he asked the excellent sage about the highest sagacity.

SNP 3.11:20.5The introductory verses are finished.

SNP 3.11:21.1“I now know that Asita’s predictionSNP 3.11:21.2has turned out to be true. SNP 3.11:21.3I ask you this, Gotama,SNP 3.11:21.4who has gone beyond all things:

SNP 3.11:22.1For one who has entered the homeless life, SNP 3.11:22.2seeking food on alms round, SNP 3.11:22.3when questioned, O sage, please tell meSNP 3.11:22.4of sagacity, the ultimate state.”

SNP 3.11:23.1“I shall school you in sagacity,”SNP 3.11:23.2said the Buddha, SNP 3.11:23.3“so difficult and challenging.SNP 3.11:23.4Come, I shall tell you all about it. SNP 3.11:23.5Brace yourself; stay strong!

SNP 3.11:24.1In the village, keep the same attitudeSNP 3.11:24.2no matter if reviled or praised. SNP 3.11:24.3Guard against ill-tempered thoughts,SNP 3.11:24.4wander peaceful, not frantic.

SNP 3.11:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 137Many different things come up, SNP 3.11:25.2like tongues of fire in a forest.SNP 3.11:25.3Women try to seduce a sage— SNP 3.11:25.4let them not seduce you!

SNP 3.11:26.1Refraining from sex, SNP 3.11:26.2having left behind sensual pleasures high and low, SNP 3.11:26.3don’t be hostile or attachedSNP 3.11:26.4to living creatures firm or frail.

SNP 3.11:27.1BJ 25.220‘As am I, so are they; SNP 3.11:27.2as are they, so am I’—SNP 3.11:27.3Treating others like oneself, SNP 3.11:27.4neither kill nor incite to kill.

SNP 3.11:28.1Leaving behind desire and greedSNP 3.11:28.2for what ordinary people are attached to, SNP 3.11:28.3a seer would set out to practice,SNP 3.11:28.4they’d cross over this abyss.

SNP 3.11:29.1With empty stomach, taking limited food,SNP 3.11:29.2few in wishes, not greedy; SNP 3.11:29.3truly hungerless regarding all desires,SNP 3.11:29.4desireless, one is quenched.

SNP 3.11:3.1Even in the war with the demons,SNP 3.11:3.2when gods were victorious and demons defeated, SNP 3.11:3.3there was no such excitement.SNP 3.11:3.4What marvel have the celestials seen that they so rejoice?

SNP 3.11:30.1Having wandered for alms,SNP 3.11:30.2they’d take themselves into the forest; SNP 3.11:30.3and nearing the foot of a tree,SNP 3.11:30.4the sage would take their seat.

SNP 3.11:31.1That wise one intent on absorption,SNP 3.11:31.2would delight within the forest. SNP 3.11:31.3They’d practice absorption at the foot of a tree,SNP 3.11:31.4filling themselves with bliss.

SNP 3.11:32.1Then, at the end of the night,SNP 3.11:32.2they’d take themselves into a village. SNP 3.11:32.3They’d not welcome being called,SNP 3.11:32.4nor offerings brought from the village.

SNP 3.11:33.1A sage who has come to a villageSNP 3.11:33.2would not walk hastily among the families. SNP 3.11:33.3They’d not discuss their search for food,SNP 3.11:33.4nor would they speak suggestively.

SNP 3.11:34.1‘I got something, that’s good.SNP 3.11:34.2I got nothing, that’s fine.’ SNP 3.11:34.3Impartial in both cases,SNP 3.11:34.4they return right to the tree.

SNP 3.11:35.1PTS-VP-PLI 138Wandering with bowl in hand, SNP 3.11:35.2not dumb, but thought to be dumb,SNP 3.11:35.3they wouldn’t scorn a tiny gift, SNP 3.11:35.4nor look down upon the giver.

SNP 3.11:36.1BJ 25.222For the practice has many aspects, SNP 3.11:36.2as explained by the Ascetic.SNP 3.11:36.3They do not go to the far shore twice, SNP 3.11:36.4nor having gone once do they fall away.

SNP 3.11:37.1When a mendicant has no creeping,SNP 3.11:37.2and has cut the stream of craving, SNP 3.11:37.3and given up all the various duties,SNP 3.11:37.4no fever is found in them.

SNP 3.11:38.1I shall school you in sagacity.SNP 3.11:38.2Practice as if you were licking a razor’s edge. SNP 3.11:38.3With tongue pressed to the roof of your mouth,SNP 3.11:38.4be restrained regarding your stomach.

SNP 3.11:39.1Don’t be sluggish in mind,SNP 3.11:39.2nor think overly much. SNP 3.11:39.3Be carrion-free and unattached,SNP 3.11:39.4committed to the spiritual life.

SNP 3.11:4.1Shouting and singing and playing music, SNP 3.11:4.2they clap their hands and dance. SNP 3.11:4.3I ask you, dwellers on Mount Meru’s peak,SNP 3.11:4.4quickly dispel my doubt, good sirs!”

SNP 3.11:40.1Train in a lonely seat,SNP 3.11:40.2attending closely to ascetics; SNP 3.11:40.3solitude is sagacity, they say.SNP 3.11:40.4If you welcome solitude, SNP 3.11:40.5you’ll light up the ten directions.

SNP 3.11:41.1Having heard the words of the wise,SNP 3.11:41.2the meditators who’ve given up sensual desires, SNP 3.11:41.3a follower of mine would developSNP 3.11:41.4conscience and faith all the more.

SNP 3.11:42.1PTS-VP-PLI 139Understand this by the way streams move SNP 3.11:42.2in clefts and crevices:SNP 3.11:42.3the little creeks flow on babbling, SNP 3.11:42.4while silent flow the great rivers.

SNP 3.11:43.1What is lacking, babbles;SNP 3.11:43.2what is full is at peace. SNP 3.11:43.3The fool is like a half-full pot;SNP 3.11:43.4the wise like a brimfull lake.

SNP 3.11:44.1When the Ascetic speaks muchSNP 3.11:44.2it is relevant and meaningful: SNP 3.11:44.3knowing, he teaches the Dhamma;SNP 3.11:44.4knowing, he speaks much.

SNP 3.11:45.1But one who, knowing, is restrained,SNP 3.11:45.2knowing, does not speak much; SNP 3.11:45.3that sage is worthy of sagacity,SNP 3.11:45.4that sage has achieved sagacity.”

SNP 3.11:5.1BJ 25.214“The being intent on awakening, a peerless gem, SNP 3.11:5.2has been born in the human realm for the sake of welfare and happiness,SNP 3.11:5.3in Lumbinī, a village in the Sakyan land. SNP 3.11:5.4That’s why we’re so happy, in such excellent spirits.

SNP 3.11:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 133He is supreme among all beings, the best of people, SNP 3.11:6.2a bull among men, supreme among all creatures.SNP 3.11:6.3He will roll forth the wheel in the grove of the hermits, SNP 3.11:6.4roaring like a mighty lion, lord of beasts.”

SNP 3.11:7.1Hearing this, he swiftly descendedSNP 3.11:7.2and right away approached Suddhodana’s home. SNP 3.11:7.3Seated there he said this to the Sakyans,SNP 3.11:7.4“Where is the boy? I too wish to see him!”

SNP 3.11:8.1Then the Sakyans showed their son to the one named Asita—SNP 3.11:8.2the boy shone like burning gold SNP 3.11:8.3well-wrought in the forge;SNP 3.11:8.4resplendent with glory, of peerless beauty.

SNP 3.11:9.1The boy beamed like crested flame,SNP 3.11:9.2pure as the moon, lord of stars traversing the sky, SNP 3.11:9.3blazing like the sun freed from the clouds after the rains;SNP 3.11:9.4seeing him, he was joyful, brimming with happiness.

  • SNP 3.12:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 3.12:0.23.12 Contemplating Pairs

SNP 3.12:1.1BJ 25.224PTS-VP-PLI 140So I have heard. SNP 3.12:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother. SNP 3.12:1.3Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks. SNP 3.12:1.4Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of monks, who were so very silent. He addressed them:

SNP 3.12:10.1“Attachment is the source of sufferingSNP 3.12:10.2in all its countless forms in the world. SNP 3.12:10.3When an ignorant person builds up attachments,SNP 3.12:10.4that idiot returns to suffering again and again. SNP 3.12:10.5So let one who understands not build up attachments,SNP 3.12:10.6contemplating the birth and origin of suffering.”

SNP 3.12:11.1“Suppose, mendicants, they questioned you thus: ‘Could there be another way to contemplate the pairs?’ SNP 3.12:11.2You should say, ‘There could.’SNP 3.12:11.3And how could there be?SNP 3.12:11.4‘All the suffering that originates is caused by ignorance’: this is one contemplation. SNP 3.12:11.5‘With the utter cessation of ignorance there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:11.6When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:11.7Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:12.1BJ 25.228PTS-VP-PLI 142“Those who journey again and again, SNP 3.12:12.2transmigrating through birth and death;SNP 3.12:12.3they go from this state to another, SNP 3.12:12.4destined only for ignorance.

SNP 3.12:13.1For ignorance is the great delusionSNP 3.12:13.2because of which we have long transmigrated. SNP 3.12:13.3Those beings who have arrived at knowledgeSNP 3.12:13.4do not proceed to a future life.”

SNP 3.12:14.1“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:14.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:14.3‘All the suffering that originates is caused by choices’: this is one contemplation.SNP 3.12:14.4‘With the utter cessation of choices there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:14.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:14.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:15.1“All the suffering that originatesSNP 3.12:15.2is caused by ignorance. SNP 3.12:15.3With the cessation of choices, SNP 3.12:15.4there is no origination of suffering.

SNP 3.12:16.1Knowing this danger,SNP 3.12:16.2that suffering is caused by choices; SNP 3.12:16.3through the stilling of all choices,SNP 3.12:16.4and the stopping of perceptions, SNP 3.12:16.5this is the way suffering ends.SNP 3.12:16.6For those who truly know this,

SNP 3.12:17.1rightly seeing, knowledge masters,SNP 3.12:17.2the astute, understanding rightly, SNP 3.12:17.3having overcome Māra’s bonds,SNP 3.12:17.4do not proceed to a future life.”

SNP 3.12:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 143“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:18.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:18.3‘All the suffering that originates is caused by consciousness’: this is one contemplation.SNP 3.12:18.4‘With the utter cessation of consciousness there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:18.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:18.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:19.1“All the suffering that originatesSNP 3.12:19.2is caused by consciousness. SNP 3.12:19.3With the cessation of consciousness, SNP 3.12:19.4there is no origination of suffering.

SNP 3.12:2.1“Suppose, mendicants, they questioned you thus: ‘There are skillful teachings that are noble, emancipating, and lead to awakening. What is the real reason for listening to such teachings?’ You should answer:SNP 3.12:2.2‘Only so as to truly know the pairs of teachings.’SNP 3.12:2.3And what pairs do they speak of?

SNP 3.12:20.1BJ 25.230Knowing this danger, SNP 3.12:20.2that suffering is caused by consciousness,SNP 3.12:20.3with the stilling of consciousness a mendicant SNP 3.12:20.4is hungerless, extinguished.”

SNP 3.12:21.1“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:21.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:21.3‘All the suffering that originates is caused by contact’: this is one contemplation.SNP 3.12:21.4‘With the utter cessation of contact there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:21.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:21.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:22.1“Those mired in contact,SNP 3.12:22.2swept down the stream of rebirths, SNP 3.12:22.3practicing the wrong way,SNP 3.12:22.4are far from the ending of fetters.

SNP 3.12:23.1But those who completely understand contact, SNP 3.12:23.2who, understanding, delight in peace; SNP 3.12:23.3by comprehending contactSNP 3.12:23.4they are hungerless, extinguished.”

SNP 3.12:24.1“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:24.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:24.3‘All the suffering that originates is caused by feeling’: this is one contemplation.SNP 3.12:24.4‘With the utter cessation of feeling there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:24.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:24.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 144“Whatever is felt SNP 3.12:25.2internally and externally—SNP 3.12:25.3whether pleasure or pain SNP 3.12:25.4as well as what’s neutral—

SNP 3.12:26.1having known this as suffering, SNP 3.12:26.2deceptive, falling apart, SNP 3.12:26.3one sees them vanish as they’re experienced again and again: SNP 3.12:26.4that’s how to understand them. SNP 3.12:26.5With the ending of feelings, a mendicant SNP 3.12:26.6is hungerless, extinguished.”

SNP 3.12:27.1“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:27.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:27.3‘All the suffering that originates is caused by craving’: this is one contemplation.SNP 3.12:27.4‘With the utter cessation of craving there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:27.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:27.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:28.1BJ 25.232“Craving is a person’s partner SNP 3.12:28.2as they transmigrate on this long journey. SNP 3.12:28.3They go from this state to another, SNP 3.12:28.4but don’t escape transmigration.

SNP 3.12:29.1Knowing this danger,SNP 3.12:29.2that craving is the cause of suffering— SNP 3.12:29.3rid of craving, free of grasping,SNP 3.12:29.4a mendicant would wander mindful.”

SNP 3.12:3.1‘This is suffering; this is the origin of suffering’: this is the first contemplation.SNP 3.12:3.2‘This is the cessation of suffering; this is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:3.3When a mendicant meditates rightly contemplating a pair of teachings in this way—diligent, keen, and resolute—they can expect one of two results: SNP 3.12:3.4enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

SNP 3.12:30.1“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:30.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:30.3‘All the suffering that originates is caused by grasping’: this is one contemplation.SNP 3.12:30.4‘With the utter cessation of grasping there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:30.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:30.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:31.1“Grasping is the cause of continued existence; SNP 3.12:31.2one who exists falls into suffering. SNP 3.12:31.3Death comes to those who are born—SNP 3.12:31.4this is the origination of suffering.

SNP 3.12:32.1That’s why with the end of grasping, SNP 3.12:32.2the astute, understanding rightly, SNP 3.12:32.3having directly known the end of rebirth,SNP 3.12:32.4do not proceed to a future life.”

SNP 3.12:33.1PTS-VP-PLI 145“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:33.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:33.3‘All the suffering that originates is caused by instigating karma’: this is one contemplation. SNP 3.12:33.4‘With the utter cessation of instigation there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:33.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:33.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:34.1“All the suffering that originatesSNP 3.12:34.2is caused by instigating karma. SNP 3.12:34.3With the cessation of instigation, SNP 3.12:34.4there is no origination of suffering.

SNP 3.12:35.1Knowing this danger,SNP 3.12:35.2that suffering is caused by instigating karma, SNP 3.12:35.3having given up all instigation,SNP 3.12:35.4one is freed with respects to instigation.

SNP 3.12:36.1For the mendicant with peaceful mind,SNP 3.12:36.2who has cut off craving for continued existence, SNP 3.12:36.3transmigration through births is finished;SNP 3.12:36.4there are no future lives for them.”

SNP 3.12:37.1BJ 25.234“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:37.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:37.3‘All the suffering that originates is caused by sustenance’: this is one contemplation. SNP 3.12:37.4‘With the utter cessation of sustenance there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:37.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:37.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:38.1“All the suffering that originatesSNP 3.12:38.2is caused by sustenance. SNP 3.12:38.3With the cessation of sustenance, SNP 3.12:38.4there is no origination of suffering.

SNP 3.12:39.1Knowing this danger,SNP 3.12:39.2that suffering is caused by sustenance, SNP 3.12:39.3completely understanding all sustenance, SNP 3.12:39.4one is independent of all sustenance.

SNP 3.12:4.1That is what the Buddha said. SNP 3.12:4.2Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

SNP 3.12:40.1PTS-VP-PLI 146Having rightly understood the state of health, SNP 3.12:40.2through the ending of defilements, SNP 3.12:40.3using after reflection, firm in principle, SNP 3.12:40.4a knowledge master cannot be reckoned.”

SNP 3.12:41.1“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:41.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:41.3‘All the suffering that originates is caused by perturbation’: this is one contemplation.SNP 3.12:41.4‘With the utter cessation of perturbation there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:41.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:41.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:42.1“All the suffering that originatesSNP 3.12:42.2is caused by perturbation. SNP 3.12:42.3With the cessation of perturbation, SNP 3.12:42.4there is no origination of suffering.

SNP 3.12:43.1Knowing this danger,SNP 3.12:43.2that suffering is caused by perturbation, SNP 3.12:43.3that’s why, having relinquished perturbation,SNP 3.12:43.4and stopped making karmic choices, SNP 3.12:43.5imperturbable, free of grasping,SNP 3.12:43.6a mendicant would wander mindful.”

SNP 3.12:44.1“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:44.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:44.3‘For the dependent there is agitation’: this is the first contemplation.SNP 3.12:44.4‘For the independent there’s no agitation’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:44.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:44.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:45.1“For the independent there’s no agitation.SNP 3.12:45.2The dependent, grasping, SNP 3.12:45.3goes from this state to another, SNP 3.12:45.4without escaping transmigration.

SNP 3.12:46.1BJ 25.236Knowing this danger,SNP 3.12:46.2the great fear in dependencies, SNP 3.12:46.3independent, free of grasping,SNP 3.12:46.4a mendicant would wander mindful.”

SNP 3.12:47.1PTS-VP-PLI 147“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:47.2And how could there be?SNP 3.12:47.3‘Formless states are more peaceful than states of form’: this is the first contemplation. SNP 3.12:47.4‘Cessation is more peaceful than formless states’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:47.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:47.6Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

SNP 3.12:48.1“There are beings in the realm of luminous form, SNP 3.12:48.2and others stuck in the formless. SNP 3.12:48.3Not understanding cessation, SNP 3.12:48.4they return in future lives.

SNP 3.12:49.1But the people who completely understand form, SNP 3.12:49.2not stuck in the formless, SNP 3.12:49.3released in cessation—SNP 3.12:49.4they are destroyers of death.”

SNP 3.12:5.1“There are those who don’t understand suffering SNP 3.12:5.2and suffering’s cause, SNP 3.12:5.3and where all suffering SNP 3.12:5.4ceases with nothing left over. SNP 3.12:5.5And they don’t know the path SNP 3.12:5.6that leads to the stilling of suffering.

SNP 3.12:50.1“‘Could there be another way?’ …SNP 3.12:50.2And how could there be? SNP 3.12:50.3‘What this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—focuses on as true, the noble ones have clearly seen with right wisdom to be actually false’: this is the first contemplation.SNP 3.12:50.4‘What this world focuses on as false, the noble ones have clearly seen with right wisdom to be actually true’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:50.5When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:50.6Then the Teacher went on to say:

SNP 3.12:51.1“See how the world with its godsSNP 3.12:51.2imagines not-self to be self; SNP 3.12:51.3habituated to name and form,SNP 3.12:51.4imagining this is truth.

SNP 3.12:52.1For whatever you imagine it is, SNP 3.12:52.2it turns out to be something else. SNP 3.12:52.3And that is what is false in it,SNP 3.12:52.4for the ephemeral is deceptive by nature.

SNP 3.12:53.1BJ 25.238PTS-VP-PLI 148Extinguishment has an undeceptive nature, SNP 3.12:53.2the noble ones know it as truth. SNP 3.12:53.3Having comprehended the truth, SNP 3.12:53.4they are hungerless, extinguished.”

SNP 3.12:54.1“Suppose, mendicants, they questioned you thus: ‘Could there be another way to contemplate the pairs?’ SNP 3.12:54.2You should say, ‘There could.’SNP 3.12:54.3And how could there be?SNP 3.12:54.4‘What this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—focuses on as happiness, the noble ones have clearly seen with right wisdom to be actually suffering’: this is the first contemplation.SNP 3.12:54.5‘What this world focuses on as suffering, the noble ones have clearly seen with right wisdom to be actually happiness’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:54.6When a mendicant meditates rightly contemplating a pair of teachings in this way—diligent, keen, and resolute—they can expect one of two results: SNP 3.12:54.7enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return. SNP 3.12:54.8That is what the Buddha said. SNP 3.12:54.9Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

SNP 3.12:55.1“Sights, sounds, tastes, smells, SNP 3.12:55.2touches, and thoughts, the lot of them— SNP 3.12:55.3they’re likable, desirable, and pleasurable SNP 3.12:55.4as long as you can say that they exist.

SNP 3.12:56.1For all the world with its gods, SNP 3.12:56.2this is what they agree is happiness. SNP 3.12:56.3And where they cease SNP 3.12:56.4is agreed on as suffering for them.

SNP 3.12:57.1The noble ones have seen as happinessSNP 3.12:57.2the ceasing of identity. SNP 3.12:57.3This insight by those who seeSNP 3.12:57.4contradicts the whole world.

SNP 3.12:58.1PTS-VP-PLI 149What others say is happiness SNP 3.12:58.2the noble ones say is suffering. SNP 3.12:58.3What others say is suffering SNP 3.12:58.4the noble ones know as happiness.

SNP 3.12:59.1BJ 25.240See, this teaching is hard to understand, SNP 3.12:59.2it confuses the ignorant. SNP 3.12:59.3There is darkness for the shrouded; SNP 3.12:59.4blackness for those who don’t see.

SNP 3.12:6.1BJ 25.226They lack the heart’s release, SNP 3.12:6.2as well as the release by wisdom. SNP 3.12:6.3Unable to make an end, SNP 3.12:6.4they continue to be reborn and grow old.

SNP 3.12:60.1But the good are open; SNP 3.12:60.2like light for those who see. SNP 3.12:60.3Though close, they do not understand,SNP 3.12:60.4those fools inexpert in the teaching.

SNP 3.12:61.1They’re mired in desire to be reborn, SNP 3.12:61.2flowing along the stream of lives, SNP 3.12:61.3mired in Māra’s sway: SNP 3.12:61.4this teaching isn’t easy for them to understand.

SNP 3.12:62.1Who, apart from the noble ones, SNP 3.12:62.2is qualified to understand this state? SNP 3.12:62.3When they’ve rightly understood it, SNP 3.12:62.4they become extinguished without defilements.”

SNP 3.12:63.1That is what the Buddha said. SNP 3.12:63.2Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said. SNP 3.12:63.3And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty mendicants were freed from defilements by not grasping.

SNP 3.12:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 141But there are those who understand suffering SNP 3.12:7.2and suffering’s cause, SNP 3.12:7.3and where all suffering SNP 3.12:7.4ceases with nothing left over. SNP 3.12:7.5And they understand the path SNP 3.12:7.6that leads to the stilling of suffering.

SNP 3.12:8.1They’re endowed with the heart’s release, SNP 3.12:8.2as well as the release by wisdom. SNP 3.12:8.3Able to make an end, SNP 3.12:8.4they don’t continue to be reborn and grow old.”

SNP 3.12:9.1“Suppose, mendicants, they questioned you thus: ‘Could there be another way to contemplate the pairs?’ SNP 3.12:9.2You should say, ‘There could.’SNP 3.12:9.3And how could there be?SNP 3.12:9.4‘All the suffering that originates is caused by attachment’: this is one contemplation.SNP 3.12:9.5‘With the utter cessation of attachment there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.SNP 3.12:9.6When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”SNP 3.12:9.7Then the Teacher went on to say:

  • SNP 4.1:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.1:0.2Sensual Pleasures

SNP 4.1:1.1BJ 25.242PTS-VP-PLI 151If a mortal desires sensual pleasure SNP 4.1:1.2and their desire succeeds,SNP 4.1:1.3they definitely become elated, SNP 4.1:1.4having got what they want.

SNP 4.1:2.1But for that person in the throes of pleasure,SNP 4.1:2.2aroused by desire, SNP 4.1:2.3if those pleasures fade,SNP 4.1:2.4it hurts like an arrow’s strike.

SNP 4.1:3.1One who, being mindful,SNP 4.1:3.2avoids sensual pleasures SNP 4.1:3.3like side-stepping a snake’s head,SNP 4.1:3.4transcends attachment to the world.

SNP 4.1:4.1There are many objects of sensual desire:SNP 4.1:4.2fields, lands, and gold; cattle and horses; SNP 4.1:4.3slaves and servants; women and relatives.SNP 4.1:4.4When a man lusts over these,

SNP 4.1:5.1the weak overpower himSNP 4.1:5.2and adversities crush him. SNP 4.1:5.3Suffering follows himSNP 4.1:5.4like water in a leaky boat.

SNP 4.1:6.1That’s why a person, ever mindful, SNP 4.1:6.2should avoid sensual pleasures. SNP 4.1:6.3Give them up and cross the flood,SNP 4.1:6.4as a bailed-out boat reaches the far shore.

  • SNP 4.2:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.2:0.2Eight on the Cave

SNP 4.2:1.1BJ 25.244PTS-VP-PLI 152Trapped in a cave, thickly overspread, SNP 4.2:1.2sunk in delusion they stay.SNP 4.2:1.3A person like this is far from seclusion, SNP 4.2:1.4for sensual pleasures in the world are not easy to give up.

SNP 4.2:2.1The chains of desire, the bonds of life’s pleasuresSNP 4.2:2.2are hard to escape, for one cannot free another. SNP 4.2:2.3Looking to the past or the future,SNP 4.2:2.4they pray for these pleasures or former ones.

SNP 4.2:3.1Greedy, fixated, infatuated by sensual pleasures, SNP 4.2:3.2they are incorrigible, habitually immoral. SNP 4.2:3.3When led to suffering they lament,SNP 4.2:3.4“What will become of us when we pass away from here?”

SNP 4.2:4.1That’s why a person should train in this life:SNP 4.2:4.2should you know that anything in the world is wrong, SNP 4.2:4.3don’t act wrongly on account of that;SNP 4.2:4.4for the wise say this life is short.

SNP 4.2:5.1I see the world’s population floundering,SNP 4.2:5.2given to craving for future lives. SNP 4.2:5.3Base men wail in the jaws of death,SNP 4.2:5.4not rid of craving for life after life.

SNP 4.2:6.1See them flounder over belongings,SNP 4.2:6.2like fish in puddles of a dried-up stream. SNP 4.2:6.3Seeing this, live unselfishly,SNP 4.2:6.4forming no attachment to future lives.

SNP 4.2:7.1BJ 25.246Rid of desire for both ends, SNP 4.2:7.2having completely understand contact, free of greed,SNP 4.2:7.3doing nothing for which they’d blame themselves, SNP 4.2:7.4the wise don’t cling to the seen and the heard.

SNP 4.2:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 153Having understood perception and crossed the flood, SNP 4.2:8.2the sage, not clinging to possessions,SNP 4.2:8.3with dart plucked out, living diligently, SNP 4.2:8.4does not long for this world or the next.

  • SNP 4.3:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.3:0.2Eight on Malice

SNP 4.3:1.1Some speak with malicious intent,SNP 4.3:1.2while other speak set on truth. SNP 4.3:1.3When disputes come up a sage does not get involved,SNP 4.3:1.4which is why they’ve no barrenness at all.

SNP 4.3:2.1How can you transcend your own viewSNP 4.3:2.2when you’re led by preference, dogmatic in belief? SNP 4.3:2.3Inventing your own undertakings,SNP 4.3:2.4you’d speak according to your notion.

SNP 4.3:3.1Some, unasked, tell others SNP 4.3:3.2of their own precepts and vows. SNP 4.3:3.3They have an ignoble nature, say the experts,SNP 4.3:3.4since they speak about themselves of their own accord.

SNP 4.3:4.1A mendicant, peaceful, quenched,SNP 4.3:4.2never boasts “thus am I” of their precepts. SNP 4.3:4.3They have a noble nature, say the experts,SNP 4.3:4.4not proud of anything in the world.

SNP 4.3:5.1BJ 25.248PTS-VP-PLI 154For one who formulates and creates teachings, SNP 4.3:5.2and promotes them despite their defects,SNP 4.3:5.3if they see an advantage for themselves, SNP 4.3:5.4they become dependent on that, relying on unstable peace.

SNP 4.3:6.1It’s not easy to get over dogmatic viewsSNP 4.3:6.2adopted after judging among the teachings. SNP 4.3:6.3That’s why, among all these dogmas, a personSNP 4.3:6.4rejects one teaching and takes up another.

SNP 4.3:7.1The cleansed one has no formulated viewSNP 4.3:7.2at all in the world about the different realms. SNP 4.3:7.3Having given up illusion and conceit,SNP 4.3:7.4by what path would they go? They are not involved.

SNP 4.3:8.1For one who is involved gets embroiled in disputes about teachings— SNP 4.3:8.2but how to dispute with the uninvolved? About what?SNP 4.3:8.3For picking up and putting down is not what they do; SNP 4.3:8.4they have shaken off all views in this very life.

  • SNP 4.4:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.4:0.2Eight on the Pure

SNP 4.4:1.1“I see a pure being of ultimate wellness;SNP 4.4:1.2it is vision that grants a person purity.” SNP 4.4:1.3Recalling this notion of the ultimate,SNP 4.4:1.4they believe in the notion that there is one who observes purity.

SNP 4.4:2.1BJ 25.250PTS-VP-PLI 155If a person were granted purity through vision, SNP 4.4:2.2or if by a notion they could give up suffering,SNP 4.4:2.3then one with attachments is purified by another: SNP 4.4:2.4their view betrays them as one who asserts thus.

SNP 4.4:3.1The brahmin speaks not of purity from anotherSNP 4.4:3.2in terms of what is seen, heard, or thought; or by precepts or vows. SNP 4.4:3.3They are unsullied in the midst of good and evil,SNP 4.4:3.4letting go what was picked up, without creating anything new here.

SNP 4.4:4.1Having let go the last they lay hold of the next;SNP 4.4:4.2following impulse, they don’t get past the snare. SNP 4.4:4.3They grab on and let go like a monkeySNP 4.4:4.4grabbing and releasing a branch.

SNP 4.4:5.1Having undertaken their own vows, a personSNP 4.4:5.2visits various teachers, being attached to perception. SNP 4.4:5.3One who knows, having comprehended the truth through the knowledges,SNP 4.4:5.4does not visit various teachers, being of vast wisdom.

SNP 4.4:6.1They are remote from all thingsSNP 4.4:6.2seen, heard, or thought. SNP 4.4:6.3Seeing them living openly,SNP 4.4:6.4how could anyone in this world judge them?

SNP 4.4:7.1BJ 25.252PTS-VP-PLI 156They don’t make things up or promote them, SNP 4.4:7.2or speak of the uttermost purity.SNP 4.4:7.3After untying the tight knot of grasping SNP 4.4:7.4they long for nothing in the world.

SNP 4.4:8.1The brahmin has stepped over the boundary;SNP 4.4:8.2knowing and seeing, they adopt nothing. SNP 4.4:8.3Neither in love with passion nor besotted by dispassion,SNP 4.4:8.4there is nothing here they adopt as the ultimate.

  • SNP 4.5:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.5:0.2Eight on the Ultimate

SNP 4.5:1.1If, maintaining that theirs is the “ultimate” view, SNP 4.5:1.2a person makes it out to be highest in the world; SNP 4.5:1.3then they declare all others are “lesser”;SNP 4.5:1.4that’s why they’re not over disputes.

SNP 4.5:2.1If they see an advantage for themselvesSNP 4.5:2.2in what’s seen, heard, or thought; or in precepts or vows, SNP 4.5:2.3in that case, having adopted that one alone,SNP 4.5:2.4they see all others as inferior.

SNP 4.5:3.1Experts say that, too, is a knot,SNP 4.5:3.2relying on which people see others as lesser. SNP 4.5:3.3That’s why a mendicant ought not rely SNP 4.5:3.4on what’s seen, heard, or thought, or on precepts and vows.

SNP 4.5:4.1BJ 25.254PTS-VP-PLI 157Nor would they form a view about the world SNP 4.5:4.2through a notion or through precepts and vows.SNP 4.5:4.3They would never represent themselves as “equal”, SNP 4.5:4.4nor conceive themselves “worse” or “better”.

SNP 4.5:5.1What was picked up has been set down and is not grasped again; SNP 4.5:5.2they form no dependency even on notions.SNP 4.5:5.3They follow no side among the factions, SNP 4.5:5.4and believe in no view at all.

SNP 4.5:6.1One here who has no wish for either end—SNP 4.5:6.2for any form of existence in this life or the next— SNP 4.5:6.3has adopted no dogma at allSNP 4.5:6.4after judging among the teachings.

SNP 4.5:7.1For them not even the tiniest idea is formulated hereSNP 4.5:7.2regarding what is seen, heard, or thought. SNP 4.5:7.3That brahmin does not grasp any view—SNP 4.5:7.4how could anyone in this world judge them?

SNP 4.5:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 158They don’t make things up or promote them, SNP 4.5:8.2and don’t subscribe to any of the doctrines.SNP 4.5:8.3The brahmin has no need to be led by precept or vow; SNP 4.5:8.4gone to the far shore, one such does not return.

  • SNP 4.6:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.6:0.2Old Age

SNP 4.6:1.1Short, alas, is this life;SNP 4.6:1.2you die before a hundred years. SNP 4.6:1.3Even if you live a little longer, SNP 4.6:1.4you still die of old age.

SNP 4.6:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 160For the one who is cleansed does not conceive SNP 4.6:10.2in terms of things seen, heard, or thought.SNP 4.6:10.3They do not wish to be purified by another; SNP 4.6:10.4they are neither passionate nor growing dispassioned.

SNP 4.6:2.1BJ 25.256People grieve over belongings, SNP 4.6:2.2yet there is no such thing as permanent possessions.SNP 4.6:2.3Separation is a fact of life; when you see this, SNP 4.6:2.4you wouldn’t stay living at home.

SNP 4.6:3.1Whatever a person thinks of as belonging to them,SNP 4.6:3.2that too is given up when they die. SNP 4.6:3.3Knowing this, an astute follower of mineSNP 4.6:3.4would not be bent on ownership.

SNP 4.6:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 159Just as, upon awakening, a person does not see SNP 4.6:4.2what they encountered in a dream;SNP 4.6:4.3so too you do not see your loved ones SNP 4.6:4.4when they are dead and gone.

SNP 4.6:5.1You used to see and hear those folk,SNP 4.6:5.2and call them by their name. SNP 4.6:5.3Yet the name is all that’s left to tellSNP 4.6:5.4of a person when they’re gone.

SNP 4.6:6.1Those who are greedy for belongingsSNP 4.6:6.2don’t give up sorrow, lamentation, and stinginess. SNP 4.6:6.3That’s why the sages, seers of sanctuary,SNP 4.6:6.4left possessions behind and wandered.

SNP 4.6:7.1For a mendicant who lives withdrawn,SNP 4.6:7.2frequenting a secluded seat, SNP 4.6:7.3they say it’s fittingSNP 4.6:7.4to not show themselves in a home.

SNP 4.6:8.1The sage is independent everywhere,SNP 4.6:8.2they don’t form likes or dislikes. SNP 4.6:8.3Lamentation and stinginessSNP 4.6:8.4slip off them like water from a leaf.

SNP 4.6:9.1BJ 25.258Like a droplet slips from a lotus-leaf, SNP 4.6:9.2like water from a lotus flower;SNP 4.6:9.3the sage doesn’t cling to that SNP 4.6:9.4which is seen or heard or thought.

  • SNP 4.7:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.7:0.2With Tissametteyya

SNP 4.7:1.1“When someone indulges in sex,”SNP 4.7:1.2said Venerable Tissametteyya, SNP 4.7:1.3“tell us, sir: what trouble befalls them?SNP 4.7:1.4After hearing your instruction, SNP 4.7:1.5we shall train in seclusion.”

SNP 4.7:10.1People tied to sensual pleasures envy them:SNP 4.7:10.2the isolated, wandering sage SNP 4.7:10.3who has crossed the flood,SNP 4.7:10.4unconcerned for sensual pleasures.

SNP 4.7:2.1“When someone indulges in sex,”SNP 4.7:2.2replied the Buddha, SNP 4.7:2.3“they forget their instructionsSNP 4.7:2.4and go the wrong way— SNP 4.7:2.5that is something ignoble in them.

SNP 4.7:3.1Someone who formerly lived aloneSNP 4.7:3.2and then resorts to sex SNP 4.7:3.3is like a chariot careening off-track;SNP 4.7:3.4in the world they call them a low, ordinary person.

SNP 4.7:4.1Their former fame and reputationSNP 4.7:4.2also fall away. SNP 4.7:4.3Seeing this, they’d train SNP 4.7:4.4to give up sex.

SNP 4.7:5.1Oppressed by thoughts,SNP 4.7:5.2they brood like a wretch. SNP 4.7:5.3When they hear what others are saying,SNP 4.7:5.4such a person is embarrassed.

SNP 4.7:6.1BJ 25.260Then they lash out with verbal daggers SNP 4.7:6.2when reproached by others.SNP 4.7:6.3This is their great blind spot; SNP 4.7:6.4they sink to lies.

SNP 4.7:7.1They once were considered astute, SNP 4.7:7.2committed to the solitary life. SNP 4.7:7.3But then they indulged in sex,SNP 4.7:7.4dragged along by desire like an idiot.

SNP 4.7:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 161Knowing this danger SNP 4.7:8.2in falling from a former state here,SNP 4.7:8.3a sage would firmly resolve to wander alone, SNP 4.7:8.4and would not resort to sex.

SNP 4.7:9.1They’d train themselves only in seclusion;SNP 4.7:9.2this, for the noble ones, is highest. SNP 4.7:9.3One who wouldn’t conceive themselves “best” due to that—SNP 4.7:9.4they have truly drawn near to extinguishment.

  • SNP 4.8:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.8:0.2With Pasūra

SNP 4.8:1.1“Here alone is purity,” they say,SNP 4.8:1.2denying that there is purification in other teachings. SNP 4.8:1.3Speaking of the beauty in that which they depend on,SNP 4.8:1.4each one is dogmatic about their own idiosyncratic interpretation.

SNP 4.8:10.1There are those who live far from the crowd, SNP 4.8:10.2not countering views with view.SNP 4.8:10.3Who is there to argue with you, Pasūra, SNP 4.8:10.4among those who grasp nothing here as the highest?

SNP 4.8:11.1And so you come along speculating,SNP 4.8:11.2thinking up theories in your mind. SNP 4.8:11.3Now that you’ve challenged someone who’s cleansed,SNP 4.8:11.4you’ll not be able to respond.

SNP 4.8:2.1BJ 25.262Desiring debate, they plunge into an assembly, SNP 4.8:2.2where each takes the other as a fool.SNP 4.8:2.3Relying on others they state their contention, SNP 4.8:2.4desiring praise while claiming to be experts.

SNP 4.8:3.1Addicted to debating in the midst of the assembly, SNP 4.8:3.2their need for praise makes them nervous.SNP 4.8:3.3But when they’re repudiated they get embarrassed; SNP 4.8:3.4upset at criticism, they find fault in others.

SNP 4.8:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 162If their doctrine is said to be weak, SNP 4.8:4.2and judges declare it repudiated,SNP 4.8:4.3the loser weeps and wails, SNP 4.8:4.4moaning, “They beat me.”

SNP 4.8:5.1When these arguments come up among ascetics,SNP 4.8:5.2they get excited or dejected. SNP 4.8:5.3Seeing this, refrain from contention,SNP 4.8:5.4for the only purpose is praise and profit.

SNP 4.8:6.1But if, having declared their doctrine, SNP 4.8:6.2they are praised there in the midst of the assembly, SNP 4.8:6.3they laugh and proudly show off because of it,SNP 4.8:6.4having got what they wanted.

SNP 4.8:7.1Their pride is their downfall,SNP 4.8:7.2yet they speak from conceit and arrogance. SNP 4.8:7.3Seeing this, one ought not get into arguments,SNP 4.8:7.4for experts say this is no way to purity.

SNP 4.8:8.1As a warrior, after feasting on royal food,SNP 4.8:8.2goes roaring, wanting an opponent— SNP 4.8:8.3go off and find an opponent, Sūra,SNP 4.8:8.4for here, as before, there is no-one to fight.

SNP 4.8:9.1BJ 25.264PTS-VP-PLI 163When someone argues about a view they have adopted, SNP 4.8:9.2saying, “This is the only truth,”SNP 4.8:9.3say to them, “Here you’ll have no adversary SNP 4.8:9.4when a dispute has come up.”

  • SNP 4.9:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.9:0.2With Māgaṇḍiya

SNP 4.9:1.1“Even when I saw the sirens Craving, Delight, and Lust, SNP 4.9:1.2I had no desire for sex.SNP 4.9:1.3What is this body full of piss and shit? SNP 4.9:1.4I wouldn’t even want to touch it with my foot.”

SNP 4.9:10.1BJ 25.268After leaving shelter to migrate unsettled, SNP 4.9:10.2a sage doesn’t get close to anyone in town. SNP 4.9:10.3Rid of sensual pleasures, expecting nothing, SNP 4.9:10.4they wouldn’t get in arguments with people.

SNP 4.9:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 166A spiritual giant would not take up for argument SNP 4.9:11.2the things in the world from which they live secluded.SNP 4.9:11.3As a prickly lotus born in the water SNP 4.9:11.4is unsullied by water and mud,SNP 4.9:11.5so the greedless sage, proponent of peace, SNP 4.9:11.6is unsmeared by sensuality and the world.

SNP 4.9:12.1A knowledge master does not become conceited SNP 4.9:12.2due to view or thought, for they do not identify with that. SNP 4.9:12.3They’ve no need for deeds or learning,SNP 4.9:12.4they’re not indoctrinated in dogmas.

SNP 4.9:13.1There are no ties for one detached from ideas; SNP 4.9:13.2there are no delusions for one freed by wisdom.SNP 4.9:13.3But those who have adopted ideas and views SNP 4.9:13.4wander the world causing conflict.”

SNP 4.9:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 164“If you do not want a gem such as this, SNP 4.9:2.2a lady desired by many rulers of men,SNP 4.9:2.3then what kind of theory, precepts and vows, livelihood, SNP 4.9:2.4and rebirth in a new life do you assert?”

SNP 4.9:3.1“After judging among the teachings,”SNP 4.9:3.2said the Buddha to Māgaṇḍiya, SNP 4.9:3.3“none have been adopted thinking, ‘I assert this.’SNP 4.9:3.4Seeing views without adopting any, SNP 4.9:3.5searching, I saw inner peace.”

SNP 4.9:4.1BJ 25.266“O sage, you speak of judgments you have formed,” SNP 4.9:4.2said Māgaṇḍiya,SNP 4.9:4.3“without having adopted any of those views. SNP 4.9:4.4As to that matter of ‘inner peace’—SNP 4.9:4.5how is that described by the wise?”

SNP 4.9:5.1“Purity is neither spoken of in terms of view,” SNP 4.9:5.2said the Buddha to Māgaṇḍiya,SNP 4.9:5.3“oral transmission, notion, and precepts and vows; SNP 4.9:5.4nor in terms of that without view, oral transmission, SNP 4.9:5.5notion, and precepts and vows. SNP 4.9:5.6Having relinquished these, not adopting them,SNP 4.9:5.7peaceful, independent, one would not pray to be reborn.”

SNP 4.9:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 165“It seems purity is neither spoken of in terms of view,” SNP 4.9:6.2said Māgaṇḍiya,SNP 4.9:6.3“oral transmission, notion, and precepts and vows; SNP 4.9:6.4nor in terms of that without view, oral transmission, SNP 4.9:6.5notion, and precepts and vows. SNP 4.9:6.6If so, I think this teaching is sheer confusion;SNP 4.9:6.7for some believe in purity in terms of view.”

SNP 4.9:7.1“Continuing to question while relying on a view,” SNP 4.9:7.2said the Buddha to Māgaṇḍiya,SNP 4.9:7.3“you’ve become confused by all you’ve adopted. SNP 4.9:7.4From this you’ve not glimpsed the slightest idea,SNP 4.9:7.5which is why you consider the teaching confused.

SNP 4.9:8.1If you think that ‘I’m equal, SNP 4.9:8.2special, or worse’, you’ll get into arguments. SNP 4.9:8.3Unwavering in the face of the three discriminations, SNP 4.9:8.4you’ll have no thought ‘I’m equal or special’.

SNP 4.9:9.1Why would that brahmin say, ‘It’s true’,SNP 4.9:9.2or with whom would they argue, ‘It’s false’? SNP 4.9:9.3There is no equal or unequal in them,SNP 4.9:9.4so who would they take on in debate?

  • SNP 4.10:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.10:0.2Before the Breakup

SNP 4.10:1.1“Seeing how, behaving how,SNP 4.10:1.2is one said to be at peace? SNP 4.10:1.3When asked, Gotama, please tell meSNP 4.10:1.4about the ultimate person.”

SNP 4.10:10.1I declare them to be at peace,SNP 4.10:10.2unconcerned for sensual pleasures. SNP 4.10:10.3No ties are found in them,SNP 4.10:10.4they have crossed over clinging.

SNP 4.10:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 168They have no sons or cattle, SNP 4.10:11.2nor possess fields or lands.SNP 4.10:11.3No picking up or putting down SNP 4.10:11.4is to be found in them.

SNP 4.10:12.1BJ 25.272That by which one might describe SNP 4.10:12.2an ordinary person or ascetics and brahminsSNP 4.10:12.3has no importance to them, SNP 4.10:12.4which is why they’re unaffected by words.

SNP 4.10:13.1Freed of greed, not stingy,SNP 4.10:13.2a sage doesn’t speak of themselves as being SNP 4.10:13.3among superiors, inferiors, or equals.SNP 4.10:13.4One not prone to creation does not return to creation.

SNP 4.10:14.1They who have nothing in the world of their own SNP 4.10:14.2do not grieve for that which is not,SNP 4.10:14.3or drift among the teachings; SNP 4.10:14.4that’s who is said to be at peace.”

SNP 4.10:2.1“Rid of craving before the breakup,”SNP 4.10:2.2said the Buddha, SNP 4.10:2.3“not dependent on the past,SNP 4.10:2.4unfathomable in the middle, SNP 4.10:2.5they are not governed by anything.

SNP 4.10:3.1BJ 25.270PTS-VP-PLI 167Unangry, unafraid, SNP 4.10:3.2not boastful or regretful,SNP 4.10:3.3thoughtful in counsel, and stable— SNP 4.10:3.4truly that sage is controlled in speech.

SNP 4.10:4.1Rid of attachment to the future,SNP 4.10:4.2they don’t grieve for the past. SNP 4.10:4.3A seer of seclusion in the midst of contactsSNP 4.10:4.4is not led astray among views.

SNP 4.10:5.1Withdrawn, free of deceit,SNP 4.10:5.2they’re not envious or stingy, SNP 4.10:5.3nor rude or disgusting,SNP 4.10:5.4or given to slander.

SNP 4.10:6.1Not swept up in pleasures,SNP 4.10:6.2or given to arrogance, SNP 4.10:6.3they’re gentle and articulate, SNP 4.10:6.4neither hungering nor growing dispassionate.

SNP 4.10:7.1They don’t train out of desire for profit, SNP 4.10:7.2nor get annoyed at lack of profit.SNP 4.10:7.3Not hostile due to craving, SNP 4.10:7.4nor greedy for flavors,

SNP 4.10:8.1they are equanimous, ever mindful.SNP 4.10:8.2They never conceive themselves in the world SNP 4.10:8.3as equal, special, or less than;SNP 4.10:8.4for them there is no pride.

SNP 4.10:9.1They have no dependencies,SNP 4.10:9.2understanding the teaching, they are independent. SNP 4.10:9.3No craving is found in themSNP 4.10:9.4to continue existence or to end it.

  • SNP 4.11:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.11:0.2Quarrels and Disputes

SNP 4.11:1.1“Where do quarrels and disputes come from? SNP 4.11:1.2And lamentation and sorrow, and stinginess?SNP 4.11:1.3What of conceit and arrogance, and slander too— SNP 4.11:1.4tell me please, where do they come from?”

SNP 4.11:10.1BJ 25.276“So where does contact in the world spring from? SNP 4.11:10.2And possessions, too, where do they come from?SNP 4.11:10.3When what is absent is there no possessiveness? SNP 4.11:10.4When what disappears do contacts not strike?”

SNP 4.11:11.1“Name and form cause contact; SNP 4.11:11.2possessions spring from wishing;SNP 4.11:11.3when wishing is absent there is no possessiveness; SNP 4.11:11.4when form disappears, contacts don’t strike.”

SNP 4.11:12.1“How to proceed so that form disappears? SNP 4.11:12.2And how do happiness and suffering disappear?SNP 4.11:12.3Tell me how they disappear; SNP 4.11:12.4I think we ought to know these things.”

SNP 4.11:13.1“Without normal perception or distorted perception; SNP 4.11:13.2not lacking perception, nor perceiving what has disappeared. SNP 4.11:13.3That’s how to proceed so that form disappears: SNP 4.11:13.4for concepts of identity due to proliferation spring from perception.”

SNP 4.11:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 171“Whatever I asked you have explained to me. SNP 4.11:14.2I ask you once more, please tell me this:SNP 4.11:14.3Do some astute folk here say that this is the extent SNP 4.11:14.4of purification of the spirit?SNP 4.11:14.5Or do they say it is something else?”

SNP 4.11:15.1“Some astute folk do say that this is the highest extent SNP 4.11:15.2of purification of the spirit.SNP 4.11:15.3But some of them, claiming to be experts, SNP 4.11:15.4speak of a time when nothing remains.

SNP 4.11:16.1Knowing that these states are dependent, SNP 4.11:16.2and knowing what they depend on, the inquiring sage, SNP 4.11:16.3having understood, is freed, and does not dispute. SNP 4.11:16.4The wise do not go on into life after life.”

SNP 4.11:2.1“Quarrels and disputes come from what we hold dear, SNP 4.11:2.2as do lamentation and sorrow, stinginess,SNP 4.11:2.3conceit and arrogance. SNP 4.11:2.4Quarrels and disputes are linked to stinginess,SNP 4.11:2.5and when disputes have arisen there is slander.”

SNP 4.11:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 169“So where do what we hold dear in the world spring from? SNP 4.11:3.2And the lusts that are loose in the world?SNP 4.11:3.3Where spring the hopes and aims SNP 4.11:3.4a man has for the next life?”

SNP 4.11:4.1BJ 25.274“What we hold dear in the world spring from desire, SNP 4.11:4.2as do the lusts that are loose in the world.SNP 4.11:4.3From there spring the hopes and aims SNP 4.11:4.4a man has for the next life.”

SNP 4.11:5.1“So where does desire in the world spring from? SNP 4.11:5.2And judgments, too, where do they come from?SNP 4.11:5.3And anger, lies, and doubt, SNP 4.11:5.4and other things spoken of by the Ascetic?”

SNP 4.11:6.1“What they call pleasure and pain in the world— SNP 4.11:6.2based on that, desire comes about.SNP 4.11:6.3Seeing the appearance and disappearance of forms, SNP 4.11:6.4a person forms judgments in the world.

SNP 4.11:7.1Anger, lies, and doubt—SNP 4.11:7.2these things are, too, when that pair is present. SNP 4.11:7.3One who has doubts should train in the path of knowledge; SNP 4.11:7.4it is from knowledge that the Ascetic speaks of these things.”

SNP 4.11:8.1“Where do pleasure and pain spring from? SNP 4.11:8.2When what is absent do these things not occur?SNP 4.11:8.3And also, on the topic of appearance and disappearance— SNP 4.11:8.4tell me where they spring from.”

SNP 4.11:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 170“Pleasure and pain spring from contact; SNP 4.11:9.2when contact is absent they do not occur.SNP 4.11:9.3And on the topic of appearance and disappearance— SNP 4.11:9.4I tell you they spring from there.”

  • SNP 4.12:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.12:0.2The Shorter Discourse on Arrayed For Battle

SNP 4.12:1.1BJ 25.278“Each maintaining their own view, SNP 4.12:1.2the experts disagree, arguing:SNP 4.12:1.3‘Whoever sees it this way has understood the teaching; SNP 4.12:1.4those who reject this are inadequate.’

SNP 4.12:10.1The seen, heard, or thought, or precepts or vows— SNP 4.12:10.2based on these they show disdain.SNP 4.12:10.3Standing in judgment, they scoff, SNP 4.12:10.4saying, ‘The other is a fool, an amateur!’

SNP 4.12:11.1They take the other as a fool on the same grounds SNP 4.12:11.2that they speak of themselves as an expert.SNP 4.12:11.3Claiming to be an expert on their own authority, SNP 4.12:11.4they disdain the other while saying the same thing.

SNP 4.12:12.1They are perfect, according to their own extreme view; SNP 4.12:12.2drunk on conceit, imagining themselves proficient. SNP 4.12:12.3They have anointed themselves in their own mind, SNP 4.12:12.4for such is the view they have embraced.

SNP 4.12:13.1If the word of your opponent makes you deficient, SNP 4.12:13.2then they too are lacking wisdom.SNP 4.12:13.3But if on your own authority you’re a knowledge master, a wise person, SNP 4.12:13.4then there are no fools among the ascetics.

SNP 4.12:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 174‘Those who proclaim a teaching other than this SNP 4.12:14.2have fallen short of purity, and are inadequate’: SNP 4.12:14.3so say each one of the sectarians,SNP 4.12:14.4for they are deeply attached to their own view.

SNP 4.12:15.1BJ 25.282‘Here alone is purity,’ they say, SNP 4.12:15.2denying that there is purification in other teachings. SNP 4.12:15.3Thus each one of the sectarians, being dogmatic, SNP 4.12:15.4speaks forcefully within the context of their own journey.

SNP 4.12:16.1But in that case, so long as they are speaking forcefully of their own journey, SNP 4.12:16.2how can they take the other as a fool?SNP 4.12:16.3They are the ones who provoke conflict SNP 4.12:16.4when they call the other a fool with an impure teaching.

SNP 4.12:17.1Standing in judgment, measuring by their own standard, SNP 4.12:17.2they keep getting into disputes with the world. SNP 4.12:17.3But a person who has given up all judgments SNP 4.12:17.4creates no conflict in the world.”

SNP 4.12:2.1So arguing, they quarrel,SNP 4.12:2.2saying, ‘The other is a fool, an amateur!’ SNP 4.12:2.3Which one of these speaks true,SNP 4.12:2.4for they all claim to be an expert?”

SNP 4.12:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 172“If not accepting another’s teaching SNP 4.12:3.2makes you a useless fool lacking wisdom,SNP 4.12:3.3then they’re all fools lacking wisdom, SNP 4.12:3.4for they all maintain their own view.

SNP 4.12:4.1But if having your own view is what makes you pristine— SNP 4.12:4.2pure in wisdom, expert and intelligent—SNP 4.12:4.3then none of them lack wisdom, SNP 4.12:4.4for such is the view they have all embraced.

SNP 4.12:5.1I do not say that it is correct SNP 4.12:5.2when they call each other fools.SNP 4.12:5.3Each has built up their own view to be the truth, SNP 4.12:5.4which is why they take the other as a fool.”

SNP 4.12:6.1“What some say is true and correct, SNP 4.12:6.2others say is hollow and false.SNP 4.12:6.3So arguing, they quarrel; SNP 4.12:6.4why don’t ascetics say the same thing?”

SNP 4.12:7.1“The truth is one, there is no second; SNP 4.12:7.2wise folk would not argue about this.SNP 4.12:7.3But those ascetics each boast of different truths; SNP 4.12:7.4that’s why they don’t say the same thing.”

SNP 4.12:8.1BJ 25.280PTS-VP-PLI 173“But why do they speak of different truths, SNP 4.12:8.2these proponents who claim to be experts?SNP 4.12:8.3Are there really so many different truths, SNP 4.12:8.4or do they just follow their own lines of reasoning?”

SNP 4.12:9.1“No, there are not many different truths SNP 4.12:9.2that, apart from perception, are lasting in the world. SNP 4.12:9.3Having formed their reasoning regarding different views, SNP 4.12:9.4they say there are two things: true and false.

  • SNP 4.13:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.13:0.2The Longer Discourse on Arrayed for Battle

SNP 4.13:1.1“Regarding those who maintain their own view, SNP 4.13:1.2arguing that, ‘This is the only truth’:SNP 4.13:1.3are all of them subject only to criticism, SNP 4.13:1.4or do some also win praise for that?”

SNP 4.13:10.1“They say their own teaching is perfect, SNP 4.13:10.2while the teaching of others is inferior. SNP 4.13:10.3So arguing, they quarrel,SNP 4.13:10.4each saying their own convictions are the truth.

SNP 4.13:11.1BJ 25.286If you became inferior because someone else disparaged you, SNP 4.13:11.2no-one in any teaching would be distinguished. SNP 4.13:11.3For each of them says the other’s teaching is lacking, SNP 4.13:11.4while forcefully advocating their own.

SNP 4.13:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 177But if they honor their own teachings SNP 4.13:12.2just as they praise their own journeys,SNP 4.13:12.3then all doctrines would be equally valid, SNP 4.13:12.4and purity for them would be an individual matter.

SNP 4.13:13.1After judging among the teachings, a brahmin has adopted nothing SNP 4.13:13.2that requires interpretation by another. SNP 4.13:13.3That’s why they’ve gotten over disputes, SNP 4.13:13.4for they see no other doctrine as best.

SNP 4.13:14.1Saying, ‘I know, I see, that’s how it is’, SNP 4.13:14.2some believe that purity comes from view. SNP 4.13:14.3But if they’ve really seen, what use is that view to them?SNP 4.13:14.4Overlooking what matters, they say purity comes from another.

SNP 4.13:15.1When a person sees, they see name and form, SNP 4.13:15.2and having seen, they will know just these things. SNP 4.13:15.3Gladly let them see much or little,SNP 4.13:15.4for experts say this is no way to purity.

SNP 4.13:16.1It’s not easy to educate someone who is dogmatic, SNP 4.13:16.2promoting a view they have formulated.SNP 4.13:16.3Speaking of the beauty in that which they depend on, SNP 4.13:16.4they talk of purity in accord with what they saw there.

SNP 4.13:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 178The brahmin does not get involved with formulating and calculating; SNP 4.13:17.2they’re not followers of views, nor kinsmen of notions. SNP 4.13:17.3Having understood the many different convictions, SNP 4.13:17.4they look on when others grasp.

SNP 4.13:18.1BJ 25.288Having untied the knots here in the world, SNP 4.13:18.2the sage takes no side among factions.SNP 4.13:18.3Peaceful among the peaceless, equanimous, SNP 4.13:18.4they don’t grasp when others grasp.

SNP 4.13:19.1Having given up former defilements, and not making new ones, SNP 4.13:19.2not swayed by preference, nor a proponent of dogma, SNP 4.13:19.3that wise one is released from views, SNP 4.13:19.4not clinging to the world, nor reproaching themselves.

SNP 4.13:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 175“That is a small thing, insufficient for peace, SNP 4.13:2.2these two fruits of conflict, I say.SNP 4.13:2.3Seeing this, one ought not get into arguments, SNP 4.13:2.4looking for sanctuary in the land of no conflict.

SNP 4.13:20.1They are remote from all things SNP 4.13:20.2seen, heard, or thought.SNP 4.13:20.3With burden put down, the sage is released: SNP 4.13:20.4not formulating, not abstaining, not longing.”

SNP 4.13:3.1One who knows does not get involved SNP 4.13:3.2with any of the many different convictions.SNP 4.13:3.3Why would the uninvolved get involved, SNP 4.13:3.4since they do not believe based on the seen or the heard?

SNP 4.13:4.1BJ 25.284Those who champion ethics speak of purity through self-control; SNP 4.13:4.2having undertaken a vow, they stick to it:SNP 4.13:4.3‘Let us train right here, then we will be pure.’ SNP 4.13:4.4Claiming to be experts, they are led on to future lives.

SNP 4.13:5.1If they fall away from their precepts and vows, SNP 4.13:5.2they tremble, having failed in their task.SNP 4.13:5.3They pray and long for purity, SNP 4.13:5.4like one who has lost their caravan while journeying far from home.

SNP 4.13:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 176But having given up all precepts and vows, SNP 4.13:6.2and these deeds blameworthy or blameless;SNP 4.13:6.3not longing for ‘purity’ or ‘impurity’, SNP 4.13:6.4live detached, fostering peace.

SNP 4.13:7.1Relying on mortification in disgust at sin, SNP 4.13:7.2or else on what is seen, heard, or thought,SNP 4.13:7.3they moan that purification comes through heading upstream, SNP 4.13:7.4not rid of craving for life after life.

SNP 4.13:8.1For one who longs there are prayers, SNP 4.13:8.2and trembling too over ideas they have formed. SNP 4.13:8.3But one here for whom there is no passing away or reappearing: SNP 4.13:8.4why would they tremble? For what would they pray?”

SNP 4.13:9.1“The very same teaching that some say is ‘ultimate’, SNP 4.13:9.2others say is inferior.SNP 4.13:9.3Which of these doctrines is true, SNP 4.13:9.4for they all claim to be an expert?”

  • SNP 4.14:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.14:0.2Speedy

SNP 4.14:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 179“Great hermit, I ask you, the Kinsman of the Sun, SNP 4.14:1.2about seclusion and the state of peace. SNP 4.14:1.3How, having seen, is a mendicant quenched, SNP 4.14:1.4not grasping anything in this world?”

SNP 4.14:10.1When they receive food and drink, SNP 4.14:10.2edibles and clothes,SNP 4.14:10.3they wouldn’t store them up, SNP 4.14:10.4nor worry about not getting them.

SNP 4.14:11.1Meditative, not footloose, SNP 4.14:11.2they’d avoid remorse and not be negligent. SNP 4.14:11.3Then a mendicant would stay SNP 4.14:11.4in quiet places to sit and rest.

SNP 4.14:12.1BJ 25.292PTS-VP-PLI 181They wouldn’t take much sleep, SNP 4.14:12.2but, being keen, would apply themselves to wakefulness. SNP 4.14:12.3They’d give up sloth, illusion, mirth, and play, SNP 4.14:12.4and sex and ornamentation.

SNP 4.14:13.1They wouldn’t cast Artharvaṇa spells, interpret dreams SNP 4.14:13.2or omens, or practice astrology.SNP 4.14:13.3My followers would not decipher animal cries, practice healing, SNP 4.14:13.4or cast pregnancy spells.

SNP 4.14:14.1Not shaken by criticism, SNP 4.14:14.2a mendicant would not pride themselves when praised. SNP 4.14:14.3They’d reject greed and stinginess, SNP 4.14:14.4anger, and slander.

SNP 4.14:15.1They’d not stand for buying and selling; SNP 4.14:15.2a mendicant would not speak ill at all. SNP 4.14:15.3They wouldn’t linger in the village, SNP 4.14:15.4nor cajole people from desire for profit.

SNP 4.14:16.1A mendicant would be no boaster, SNP 4.14:16.2nor would they speak suggestively.SNP 4.14:16.3They wouldn’t train in impudence, SNP 4.14:16.4nor speak argumentatively.

SNP 4.14:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 182They wouldn’t be led into lying, SNP 4.14:17.2nor be deliberately devious.SNP 4.14:17.3And they’d never look down on another SNP 4.14:17.4because of livelihood, wisdom, or precepts and vows.

SNP 4.14:18.1Though provoked from hearing much talk SNP 4.14:18.2from ascetics saying all different things, SNP 4.14:18.3they wouldn’t react harshly,SNP 4.14:18.4for the virtuous do not retaliate.

SNP 4.14:19.1BJ 25.294Having understood this teaching, SNP 4.14:19.2inquiring, a mendicant would always train mindfully. SNP 4.14:19.3Knowing extinguishment as peace, SNP 4.14:19.4they’d not be negligent in Gotama’s bidding.

SNP 4.14:2.1“They would cut off the idea, ‘I am the thinker,” SNP 4.14:2.2said the Buddha,SNP 4.14:2.3“which is the root of all concepts of identity due to proliferation. SNP 4.14:2.4Ever mindful, they would train to remove SNP 4.14:2.5any internal cravings.

SNP 4.14:20.1For he is the undefeated, the champion, SNP 4.14:20.2seer of the truth as witness, not by hearsay— SNP 4.14:20.3that’s why, being diligent, they would always respectfully train SNP 4.14:20.4in the Buddha’s teaching.”

SNP 4.14:3.1Regardless of what things they know, SNP 4.14:3.2whether internal or external,SNP 4.14:3.3they wouldn’t be proud because of that, SNP 4.14:3.4for that is not extinguishment, say the good.

SNP 4.14:4.1BJ 25.290They wouldn’t let that make them conceited, SNP 4.14:4.2thinking themselves better or worse or alike. SNP 4.14:4.3When questioned in many ways,SNP 4.14:4.4they wouldn’t keep justifying themselves.

SNP 4.14:5.1A mendicant would find peace inside themselves, SNP 4.14:5.2and not seek peace from another.SNP 4.14:5.3For one at peace inside themselves, SNP 4.14:5.4there’s no picking up, whence putting down?
