SNP 4.14:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 180Just as, in the mid-ocean deeps SNP 4.14:6.2no waves arise, it stays still;SNP 4.14:6.3so too one unstirred is still— SNP 4.14:6.4a mendicant would nurse no pride at all.”

SNP 4.14:7.1“He whose eyes are open has explained SNP 4.14:7.2the truth he witnessed, where adversities are removed. SNP 4.14:7.3Please now speak of the practice, sir, SNP 4.14:7.4the monastic code and immersion in samādhi.”

SNP 4.14:8.1“With eyes not wanton, SNP 4.14:8.2they’d turn their ears from village gossip. SNP 4.14:8.3They wouldn’t be greedy for flavors,SNP 4.14:8.4nor possessive about anything in the world.

SNP 4.14:9.1Though struck by contacts, SNP 4.14:9.2a mendicant would not lament at all.SNP 4.14:9.3They wouldn’t pray for another life, SNP 4.14:9.4nor tremble in the face of dangers.

  • SNP 4.15:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.15:0.2Taking Up Arms

SNP 4.15:1.1Peril stems from those who take up arms— SNP 4.15:1.2just look at people in conflict!SNP 4.15:1.3I shall extol how I came to be SNP 4.15:1.4stirred with a sense of urgency.

SNP 4.15:10.1Don’t relish the old, SNP 4.15:10.2or welcome the new.SNP 4.15:10.3Don’t grieve for what is running out, SNP 4.15:10.4or get attached to things that pull you in.

SNP 4.15:11.1Greed, I say, is the great flood, SNP 4.15:11.2and longing is the current—SNP 4.15:11.3the basis, the compulsion, SNP 4.15:11.4the swamp of sensuality so hard to get past.

SNP 4.15:12.1The sage never strays from the truth; SNP 4.15:12.2the brahman stands firm on the shore. SNP 4.15:12.3Having given up everything,SNP 4.15:12.4they are said to be at peace.

SNP 4.15:13.1They have truly known, they’re a knowledge master, SNP 4.15:13.2understanding the teaching, they are independent. SNP 4.15:13.3They rightly proceed in the world, SNP 4.15:13.4not coveting anything here.

SNP 4.15:14.1BJ 25.298One who has crossed over sensuality here, SNP 4.15:14.2the snare in the world so hard to get past, SNP 4.15:14.3grieves not, nor hopes;SNP 4.15:14.4they’ve cut the strings, they’re no longer bound.

SNP 4.15:15.1What came before, let wither away, SNP 4.15:15.2and after, let there be nothing. SNP 4.15:15.3If you don’t grasp at the middle, SNP 4.15:15.4you will live at peace.

SNP 4.15:16.1One who has no sense of ownership SNP 4.15:16.2in the whole realm of name and form, SNP 4.15:16.3does not grieve for that which is not, SNP 4.15:16.4they suffer no loss in the world.

SNP 4.15:17.1If you don’t think of anything SNP 4.15:17.2as belonging to yourself or others, SNP 4.15:17.3not finding anything to be ‘mine’, SNP 4.15:17.4you won’t grieve, thinking ‘I don’t have it’.

SNP 4.15:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 185Not bitter, not fawning, SNP 4.15:18.2unstirred, everywhere even;SNP 4.15:18.3when asked about one who is unshakable, SNP 4.15:18.4I declare that that is the benefit.

SNP 4.15:19.1For the unstirred who understand, SNP 4.15:19.2there’s no performance of deeds. SNP 4.15:19.3Desisting from instigation,SNP 4.15:19.4they see sanctuary everywhere.

SNP 4.15:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 183I saw this population flounder, SNP 4.15:2.2like a fish in a little puddle.SNP 4.15:2.3Seeing them fight each other, SNP 4.15:2.4fear came upon me.

SNP 4.15:20.1A sage doesn’t speak of themselves as being SNP 4.15:20.2among superiors, inferiors, or equals. SNP 4.15:20.3peaceful, rid of stinginess, SNP 4.15:20.4they neither take nor reject.

SNP 4.15:3.1The world around was hollow, SNP 4.15:3.2all directions were in turmoil.SNP 4.15:3.3Wanting a home for myself, SNP 4.15:3.4I saw nowhere unsettled.

SNP 4.15:4.1But even in their settlement they fight— SNP 4.15:4.2seeing that, I grew uneasy.SNP 4.15:4.3Then I saw a dart there, SNP 4.15:4.4so hard to see, stuck in the heart.

SNP 4.15:5.1When struck by that dart, SNP 4.15:5.2you run about in all directions.SNP 4.15:5.3But when that same dart has been plucked out, SNP 4.15:5.4you neither run about nor sink down.

SNP 4.15:6.1BJ 25.296(On that topic, the trainings are recited.) SNP 4.15:6.2Whatever attachments there are in the world, SNP 4.15:6.3don’t pursue them.SNP 4.15:6.4Having pierced through sensual pleasures in every way, SNP 4.15:6.5train yourself for quenching.

SNP 4.15:7.1Be truthful, not rude, SNP 4.15:7.2free of deceit, and rid of slander;SNP 4.15:7.3without anger, a sage would cross over SNP 4.15:7.4the evils of greed and avarice.

SNP 4.15:8.1Prevail over sleepiness, sloth, and drowsiness, SNP 4.15:8.2don’t abide in negligence,SNP 4.15:8.3A person intent on quenching SNP 4.15:8.4would not stand for arrogance.

SNP 4.15:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 184Don’t be led into lying, SNP 4.15:9.2or get caught up in fondness for form. SNP 4.15:9.3Completely understand conceit,SNP 4.15:9.4and desist from hasty conduct.

  • SNP 4.16:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 4.16:0.2With Sāriputta

SNP 4.16:1.1BJ 25.300“Never before have I seen,” SNP 4.16:1.2said Venerable Sāriputta, SNP 4.16:1.3“or heard from anyone SNP 4.16:1.4about a teacher of such graceful speech, SNP 4.16:1.5come from Tusita heaven to lead a community.

SNP 4.16:10.1A wise one, a mindful mendicant living on the periphery SNP 4.16:10.2should not be afraid of five perils: SNP 4.16:10.3flies, mosquitoes, snakes, SNP 4.16:10.4human contact, or four-legged creatures.

SNP 4.16:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 187Nor should they fear followers of other teachings, SNP 4.16:11.2even having seen the threats they pose. SNP 4.16:11.3And then one seeking the good SNP 4.16:11.4should overcome any other adversities.

SNP 4.16:12.1Afflicted by illness and hunger, SNP 4.16:12.2they should endure cold and excessive heat. SNP 4.16:12.3Though afflicted by many such things, the homeless oneSNP 4.16:12.4should exert energy, firmly striving.

SNP 4.16:13.1They must not steal or lie; SNP 4.16:13.2and should touch creatures firm or frail with love.SNP 4.16:13.3If they notice any clouding of the mind, SNP 4.16:13.4they should dispel it as Māra’s ally.

SNP 4.16:14.1They must not fall under the sway of anger or arrogance; SNP 4.16:14.2having dug them out by the root, they would stand firm.SNP 4.16:14.3Then, withstanding likes and dislikes, SNP 4.16:14.4they would overcome.

SNP 4.16:15.1BJ 25.304Putting wisdom in the foremost place, rejoicing in goodness, SNP 4.16:15.2they would put an end to those adversities. SNP 4.16:15.3They’d vanquish discontent in their remote lodging.SNP 4.16:15.4And they’d vanquish the four lamentations:

SNP 4.16:16.1‘What will I eat? Where will I eat? SNP 4.16:16.2Oh, I slept badly! Where will I sleep?’ SNP 4.16:16.3The trainee, the homeless migrant, SNP 4.16:16.4would dispel these lamentable thoughts.

SNP 4.16:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 188Receiving food and clothes in due season, SNP 4.16:17.2they would know moderation for the sake of contentment.SNP 4.16:17.3Guarded in these things, walking restrained in the village, SNP 4.16:17.4they wouldn’t speak harshly even when provoked.

SNP 4.16:18.1Eyes downcast, not footloose, SNP 4.16:18.2devoted to absorption, they’d be very wakeful. SNP 4.16:18.3Grounded in equanimity, serene, SNP 4.16:18.4they should cut off worrisome habits of thought.

SNP 4.16:19.1A mindful one should welcome repoach, SNP 4.16:19.2breaking up hard-heartedness towards their spiritual companions.SNP 4.16:19.3They may utter skillful speech, but not for too long, SNP 4.16:19.4and they shouldn’t provoke people to blame.

SNP 4.16:2.1To all the world with its gods SNP 4.16:2.2he appears as a seerSNP 4.16:2.3who has dispelled all darkness, SNP 4.16:2.4and alone attained to bliss.

SNP 4.16:20.1And there are five more taints in the world, SNP 4.16:20.2for the removal of which the mindful one should train,SNP 4.16:20.3vanquishing desire for sights, SNP 4.16:20.4sounds, flavors, smells, and touches.

SNP 4.16:21.1PTS-VP-PLI 189Having removed desire for these things, SNP 4.16:21.2a mindful mendicant, their heart well freed, SNP 4.16:21.3rightly investigating the Dhamma in good time,SNP 4.16:21.4unified, would shatter the darkness.”

SNP 4.16:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 186On behalf of the many here still bound, SNP 4.16:3.2I have come in need with a question SNP 4.16:3.3to that Buddha, unattached and impartial, SNP 4.16:3.4free of deceit, come to lead a community.

SNP 4.16:4.1Suppose a mendicant who loathes attachment SNP 4.16:4.2frequents a lonely lodging—SNP 4.16:4.3the root of a tree, a charnel ground, SNP 4.16:4.4on mountains, or in caves.

SNP 4.16:5.1In these many different lodgings, SNP 4.16:5.2how many dangers are thereSNP 4.16:5.3at which a mendicant in their silent lodging SNP 4.16:5.4ought not tremble?

SNP 4.16:6.1On their journey to the untrodden place, SNP 4.16:6.2how many adversities are there in the world SNP 4.16:6.3that must they overcomeSNP 4.16:6.4in their remote lodging?

SNP 4.16:7.1What ways of speech should they have? SNP 4.16:7.2Where should they go for alms?SNP 4.16:7.3What precepts and vows SNP 4.16:7.4should a resolute mendicant uphold?

SNP 4.16:8.1BJ 25.302Having undertaken what training, SNP 4.16:8.2unified, alert, and mindful,SNP 4.16:8.3would they purge their own stains, SNP 4.16:8.4like a smith smelting silver?”

SNP 4.16:9.1“If one who loathes attachment frequents a lonely lodging,” SNP 4.16:9.2said the Buddha to Sāriputta,SNP 4.16:9.3“in their search for awakening—as accords with the teaching— SNP 4.16:9.4I shall tell you, as I understand it, SNP 4.16:9.5what is comfortable for them.

  • SNP 5.1:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.1:0.2Introductory Verses

SNP 5.1:1.1BJ 25.306PTS-VP-PLI 190From the fair city of the Kosalans SNP 5.1:1.2to the southern regionSNP 5.1:1.3came a brahmin expert in hymns, SNP 5.1:1.4aspiring to nothingness.

SNP 5.1:10.1Not eating, he grew emaciated, SNP 5.1:10.2stricken by the dart of sorrow. SNP 5.1:10.3And in such a state of mind, SNP 5.1:10.4he could not enjoy absorption.

SNP 5.1:11.1Seeing him anxious and distraught, SNP 5.1:11.2a goddess wishing to help, SNP 5.1:11.3approached BāvariSNP 5.1:11.4and said the following.

SNP 5.1:12.1BJ 25.308“That charlatan understands nothing SNP 5.1:12.2about the head, he only wants money. SNP 5.1:12.3When it comes to heads or head-splitting, SNP 5.1:12.4he has no knowledge at all.”

SNP 5.1:13.1“Madam, surely you must know— SNP 5.1:13.2please answer my question. SNP 5.1:13.3Let me hear what you say SNP 5.1:13.4about heads and head-splitting.”

SNP 5.1:14.1“I too do not know that, SNP 5.1:14.2I have no knowledge in that matter. SNP 5.1:14.3When it comes to heads or head-splitting, SNP 5.1:14.4it is the Victors who have vision.”

SNP 5.1:15.1“Then, in all this vast territory, SNP 5.1:15.2who exactly does knowSNP 5.1:15.3about heads and head-splitting? SNP 5.1:15.4Please tell me, goddess.”

SNP 5.1:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 192“From the city of Kapilavatthu SNP 5.1:16.2the World Leader has gone forth. SNP 5.1:16.3He is a scion of King Okkāka, SNP 5.1:16.4a Sakyan, and a beacon.

SNP 5.1:17.1For he, brahmin, is the Awakened One! SNP 5.1:17.2He has gone beyond all things; SNP 5.1:17.3he has attained to all knowledge and power;SNP 5.1:17.4he is the seer into all things, SNP 5.1:17.5he has attained the end of all deeds;SNP 5.1:17.6he is freed with the ending of attachments.

SNP 5.1:18.1That Buddha, the Blessed One in the world, SNP 5.1:18.2the Seer, teaches Dhamma.SNP 5.1:18.3Go to him and ask— SNP 5.1:18.4he will answer you.”

SNP 5.1:19.1When he heard the word “Buddha”, SNP 5.1:19.2Bāvari was elated.SNP 5.1:19.3His sorrow faded, SNP 5.1:19.4and he was filled abundant joy.

SNP 5.1:2.1In the domain of Assaka, SNP 5.1:2.2close by Aḷaka,SNP 5.1:2.3he lived on the bank of the Godhāvarī River, SNP 5.1:2.4getting by on gleanings and fruit.

SNP 5.1:20.1Uplifted, elated, and inspired, SNP 5.1:20.2Bāvari questioned that goddess: SNP 5.1:20.3“But in what village or town, SNP 5.1:20.4or in what land is the protector of the world,SNP 5.1:20.5where we may go and pay respects SNP 5.1:20.6to the Awakened One, best of men?”

SNP 5.1:21.1“Near Sāvatthī, the home of the Kosalans, is the Victor SNP 5.1:21.2abounding in wisdom, vast in intelligence. SNP 5.1:21.3That Sakyan is indefatigable, free of defilements, a bull among men: SNP 5.1:21.4he understands head-splitting.

SNP 5.1:22.1Therefore he addressed his pupils, SNP 5.1:22.2brahmins who had mastered the hymns: SNP 5.1:22.3“Come, students, I shall speak. SNP 5.1:22.4Listen to what I say.

SNP 5.1:23.1BJ 25.310PTS-VP-PLI 193Today has arisen in the world SNP 5.1:23.2one whose appearance in the world SNP 5.1:23.3is hard to find again— SNP 5.1:23.4he is renowned as the Awakened One. SNP 5.1:23.5Quickly go to Sāvatthī SNP 5.1:23.6and see the best of men.”

SNP 5.1:24.1“Brahmin, how exactly are we to know SNP 5.1:24.2the Buddha when we see him? SNP 5.1:24.3We don’t know, please tell us, SNP 5.1:24.4so that we can recognize him.”

SNP 5.1:25.1“The marks of a great man SNP 5.1:25.2have been handed down in our hymns. SNP 5.1:25.3Thirty-two have been have been described, SNP 5.1:25.4complete and in order.

SNP 5.1:26.1One upon whose body is found SNP 5.1:26.2these marks of a great man SNP 5.1:26.3has two possible destinies, SNP 5.1:26.4there is no third.

SNP 5.1:27.1If he stays at home, SNP 5.1:27.2having conquered this land SNP 5.1:27.3without rod or sword,SNP 5.1:27.4he shall govern by principle.

SNP 5.1:28.1But if he goes forth SNP 5.1:28.2from the lay life to homelessness, SNP 5.1:28.3he becomes an Awakened One, a perfected one,SNP 5.1:28.4with veil drawn back, supreme.

SNP 5.1:29.1Ask him about my birth, clan, and marks, SNP 5.1:29.2my hymns and students; and further, SNP 5.1:29.3about heads and head-splitting— SNP 5.1:29.4but do so only in your mind!

SNP 5.1:3.1He was supported SNP 5.1:3.2by a prosperous village nearby. SNP 5.1:3.3With the revenue earned from there SNP 5.1:3.4he performed a great sacrifice.

SNP 5.1:30.1If he is the Buddha SNP 5.1:30.2of unobstructed vision,SNP 5.1:30.3he will answer with his voice SNP 5.1:30.4the questions in your mind.”

SNP 5.1:31.1Sixteen brahmin pupils SNP 5.1:31.2heard what Bāvari said:SNP 5.1:31.3Ajita, Tissametteyya, SNP 5.1:31.4Puṇṇaka and Mettagū,

SNP 5.1:32.1PTS-VP-PLI 194Dhotaka and Upasiva, SNP 5.1:32.2Nanda and then Hemaka,SNP 5.1:32.3both Todeyya and Kappa, SNP 5.1:32.4and Jatukaṇṇī the astute,

SNP 5.1:33.1Bhadrāvudha and Udaya, SNP 5.1:33.2and the brahmin Posala,SNP 5.1:33.3Mogharājā the intelligent, SNP 5.1:33.4and Piṅgiya the great hermit.

SNP 5.1:34.1Each of them had their own following, SNP 5.1:34.2they were renowned the whole world over. SNP 5.1:34.3Those wise ones, meditators who love absorption,SNP 5.1:34.4were redolent with the potential of their past deeds.

SNP 5.1:35.1Having bowed to Bāvari, SNP 5.1:35.2and circled him to his right, SNP 5.1:35.3they set out for the north, SNP 5.1:35.4with their dreadlocks and hides.

SNP 5.1:36.1BJ 25.312First to Patiṭṭhāna of Aḷaka, SNP 5.1:36.2then on to the city of Mahissati; SNP 5.1:36.3to Ujjenī and Gonaddhā, SNP 5.1:36.4and Vedisa, and Vanasa.

SNP 5.1:37.1Then to Kosambi and Sāketa, SNP 5.1:37.2and the supreme city of Sāvatthī; SNP 5.1:37.3on they went to Setavyā and Kapilavatthu, SNP 5.1:37.4and the homestead at Kusinārā.

SNP 5.1:38.1To Pāvā they went, and Bhoganagara, SNP 5.1:38.2and on to Vesālī and the Magadhan city. SNP 5.1:38.3Finally they reached the Pāsāṇaka shrine, SNP 5.1:38.4fair and delightful.

SNP 5.1:39.1PTS-VP-PLI 195Like a thirsty person to cool water, SNP 5.1:39.2like a merchant to great profit, SNP 5.1:39.3like a heat-struck person to shade, SNP 5.1:39.4they quickly climbed the mountain.

SNP 5.1:4.1When he had completed the great sacrifice, SNP 5.1:4.2he returned to his hermitage once more. SNP 5.1:4.3Upon his return,SNP 5.1:4.4another brahmin arrived.

SNP 5.1:40.1At that time the Buddha SNP 5.1:40.2at the fore of the mendicant Saṅgha, SNP 5.1:40.3was teaching the mendicants the Dhamma, SNP 5.1:40.4like a lion roaring in the jungle.

SNP 5.1:41.1Ajita saw the Buddha, SNP 5.1:41.2like the sun shining with a hundred rays, SNP 5.1:41.3like the moon on the fifteenth day SNP 5.1:41.4when it has come into its fullness.

SNP 5.1:42.1Then he saw his body, SNP 5.1:42.2complete in all features.SNP 5.1:42.3Thrilled, he stood to one side SNP 5.1:42.4and asked this question in his mind.

SNP 5.1:43.1“Speak about the brahmin’s birth; SNP 5.1:43.2of his clan; and his own marks; SNP 5.1:43.3what hymns is he proficient in; SNP 5.1:43.4and how many he teaches.”

SNP 5.1:44.1“His age is a hundred and twenty. SNP 5.1:44.2By clan he is a Bāvari.SNP 5.1:44.3There are three marks on his body. SNP 5.1:44.4He is a master of the three Vedas,

SNP 5.1:45.1the teachings on the marks, the testaments, SNP 5.1:45.2the vocabularies, and the rituals. SNP 5.1:45.3He teaches five hundred, SNP 5.1:45.4and has reached proficiency in his own teaching.”

SNP 5.1:46.1PTS-VP-PLI 196“O supreme person, cutter of craving, SNP 5.1:46.2please reveal in detailSNP 5.1:46.3Bāvari’s marks— SNP 5.1:46.4let us doubt no longer!”

SNP 5.1:47.1BJ 25.314“He can cover his face with his tongue; SNP 5.1:47.2there is a tuft of hair between his eyebrows; SNP 5.1:47.3his private parts are concealed in a foreskin:SNP 5.1:47.4know them as this, young man.”

SNP 5.1:48.1Hearing the answers SNP 5.1:48.2without having heard any questions, SNP 5.1:48.3all the people, inspired, SNP 5.1:48.4with joined palms, wondered:

SNP 5.1:49.1“Who is it that asked a question with their mind? SNP 5.1:49.2Was it a god or Brahmā?SNP 5.1:49.3Or Indra, Sujā’s husband? SNP 5.1:49.4To whom does the Buddha reply?”

SNP 5.1:5.1Foot-sore and thirsty, SNP 5.1:5.2with grotty teeth and dusty head, SNP 5.1:5.3he approached the otherSNP 5.1:5.4and asked for five hundred coins.

SNP 5.1:50.1“Bāvari asks SNP 5.1:50.2about heads and head-splitting. SNP 5.1:50.3May the Buddha please answer, SNP 5.1:50.4and so, O hermit, dispel our doubt.”

SNP 5.1:51.1“Know ignorance as the head, SNP 5.1:51.2and knowledge as the head-splitter, SNP 5.1:51.3when joined with faith, mindfulness, and immersion,SNP 5.1:51.4and enthusiasm and energy.”

SNP 5.1:52.1At that, the brahmin student, SNP 5.1:52.2full of inspiration,SNP 5.1:52.3arranged his antelope-skin cloak over one shoulder, SNP 5.1:52.4and fell with his head to the Buddha’s feet.

SNP 5.1:53.1“Good sir, the brahmin Bāvari SNP 5.1:53.2together with his pupils,SNP 5.1:53.3elated and happy, SNP 5.1:53.4bows to your feet, O seer!”

SNP 5.1:54.1PTS-VP-PLI 197“May the brahmin Bāvari be happy, SNP 5.1:54.2together with his pupils.SNP 5.1:54.3And may you, too, be happy! SNP 5.1:54.4May you live long, young man.

SNP 5.1:55.1To Bāvari and you all SNP 5.1:55.2I grant the opportunity to clear up all doubt.SNP 5.1:55.3Please ask SNP 5.1:55.4whatever you want.”

SNP 5.1:56.1Granted the opportunity by the Buddha, SNP 5.1:56.2they sat down with joined palms. SNP 5.1:56.3Ajita asked the Realized One SNP 5.1:56.4the first question right there.

SNP 5.1:56.5The introductory verses are finished.

SNP 5.1:6.1When Bāvari saw him, SNP 5.1:6.2he invited him to sit down,SNP 5.1:6.3asked of his happiness and well-being, SNP 5.1:6.4and said the following.

SNP 5.1:7.1“Whatever I had available to give, SNP 5.1:7.2I have already distributed.SNP 5.1:7.3Believe me, brahmin, SNP 5.1:7.4I don’t have five hundred coins.”

SNP 5.1:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 191“If, good sir, you do not SNP 5.1:8.2give me what I ask,SNP 5.1:8.3then on the seventh day, SNP 5.1:8.4let your head explode in seven!”

SNP 5.1:9.1After performing a ritual, SNP 5.1:9.2that charlatan uttered his dreadful curse. SNP 5.1:9.3When he heard these words,SNP 5.1:9.4Bāvari became distressed.

  • SNP 5.2:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.2:0.2The Questions of Ajita

SNP 5.2:1.1BJ 25.316“By what is the world shrouded?” SNP 5.2:1.2said Venerable Ajita.SNP 5.2:1.3“Why does it not shine? SNP 5.2:1.4Tell me, what is its tar pit? SNP 5.2:1.5What is its greatest fear?”

SNP 5.2:2.1“The world is shrouded in ignorance.” SNP 5.2:2.2replied the Buddha.SNP 5.2:2.3“Avarice and negligence make it not shine. SNP 5.2:2.4Prayer is its tar pit.SNP 5.2:2.5Suffering is its greatest fear.”

SNP 5.2:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 198“The streams flow everywhere,” SNP 5.2:3.2said Venerable Ajita.SNP 5.2:3.3“What is there to block them? SNP 5.2:3.4And tell me the restraint of streams— SNP 5.2:3.5by what are they locked out?”

SNP 5.2:4.1“The streams in the world,” SNP 5.2:4.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.2:4.3“are blocked by mindfulness. SNP 5.2:4.4I tell you the restraint of streams— SNP 5.2:4.5they are locked out by wisdom.”

SNP 5.2:5.1“That wisdom and mindfulness,” SNP 5.2:5.2said Venerable Ajita,SNP 5.2:5.3“and that which is name and form, good sir; SNP 5.2:5.4when questioned, please tell me of this: SNP 5.2:5.5where does this all cease?”

SNP 5.2:6.1“This question which you have asked, SNP 5.2:6.2I shall answer you, Ajita.SNP 5.2:6.3Where name and form SNP 5.2:6.4cease with nothing left over— SNP 5.2:6.5with the cessation of consciousness, SNP 5.2:6.6that’s where they cease.”

SNP 5.2:7.1“There are those who have assessed the teaching, SNP 5.2:7.2and many kinds of trainees here. SNP 5.2:7.3Tell me about their behavior, good sir, SNP 5.2:7.4when asked, for you are alert.”

SNP 5.2:8.1“Not greedy for sensual pleasures, SNP 5.2:8.2their mind would be unclouded. SNP 5.2:8.3Skilled in all things,SNP 5.2:8.4a mendicant would wander mindful.”

  • SNP 5.3:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.3:0.2The Questions of Tissametteyya

SNP 5.3:1.1BJ 25.318PTS-VP-PLI 199“Who is content here in the world?” SNP 5.3:1.2said Venerable Tissametteyya. SNP 5.3:1.3“Who has no disturbances? SNP 5.3:1.4Who, having known both ends, SNP 5.3:1.5is not stuck in the middle? SNP 5.3:1.6Who do they say is a great man?SNP 5.3:1.7Who here has escaped the seamstress?”

SNP 5.3:2.1“Leading the spiritual life among sensual pleasures,” SNP 5.3:2.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.3:2.3“rid of craving, ever mindful; SNP 5.3:2.4a mendicant who, after assessing, is quenched:SNP 5.3:2.5that’s who has no disturbances.

SNP 5.3:3.1That’s who, having known both ends, SNP 5.3:3.2is not stuck in the middle. SNP 5.3:3.3He is a great man, I declare, SNP 5.3:3.4he has escaped the seamstress here.”

  • SNP 5.4:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.4:0.2The Questions of Puṇṇaka

SNP 5.4:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 200“To the imperturbable, the seer of the root,” SNP 5.4:1.2said Venerable Puṇṇaka, SNP 5.4:1.3“I have come in need with a question. SNP 5.4:1.4On what grounds have hermits and men,SNP 5.4:1.5aristocrats and brahmins here in the world SNP 5.4:1.6performed so many different sacrifices to the gods?SNP 5.4:1.7I ask you, Blessed One; please tell me this.”

SNP 5.4:2.1“Whatever hermits and men,” SNP 5.4:2.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.4:2.3“aristocrats and brahmins here in the world SNP 5.4:2.4have performed so many different sacrifices to the gods:SNP 5.4:2.5all performed sacrifices bound to old age, SNP 5.4:2.6hoping for some state of existence.”

SNP 5.4:3.1BJ 25.320“As to those hermits and men,” SNP 5.4:3.2said Venerable Puṇṇaka, SNP 5.4:3.3“and aristocrats and brahmins here in the worldSNP 5.4:3.4who have performed so many different sacrifices to the gods: SNP 5.4:3.5being diligent in the methods of sacrifice,SNP 5.4:3.6have they crossed over rebirth and old age, good sir? SNP 5.4:3.7I ask you, Blessed One; please tell me this.”

SNP 5.4:4.1“Hoping, invoking, praying, and worshiping,” SNP 5.4:4.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.4:4.3“they pray for pleasure derived from profit. SNP 5.4:4.4Devoted to sacrifice, besotted by rebirth,SNP 5.4:4.5they’ve not crossed over rebirth and old age, I declare.”

SNP 5.4:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 201“If those devoted to sacrifice,” SNP 5.4:5.2said Venerable Puṇṇaka, SNP 5.4:5.3“have not, by sacrificing, crossed over rebirth and old age,SNP 5.4:5.4then who exactly in the world of gods and humans SNP 5.4:5.5has crossed over rebirth and old age, good sir?SNP 5.4:5.6I ask you, Blessed One; please tell me this.”

SNP 5.4:6.1“Having assessed the world high and low,” SNP 5.4:6.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.4:6.3“there is nothing in the world that disturbs them. SNP 5.4:6.4Peaceful, unclouded, untroubled, with no need for hope—SNP 5.4:6.5they’ve crossed over rebirth and old age, I declare.”

  • SNP 5.5:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.5:0.2The Questions of Mettagū

SNP 5.5:1.1“I ask you, Blessed One; please tell me this,” SNP 5.5:1.2said Venerable Mettagū, SNP 5.5:1.3“for I think you are a knowledge master, evolved.SNP 5.5:1.4Where do all these sufferings come from, SNP 5.5:1.5in all their countless forms in the world?”

SNP 5.5:10.1Surely those you’d regularly instruct SNP 5.5:10.2would also give up suffering. SNP 5.5:10.3Therefore, having met, I bow to you, O spiritual giant;SNP 5.5:10.4hopefully the Buddha may regularly instruct me.”

SNP 5.5:11.1“Any brahmin recognized as a knowledge master, SNP 5.5:11.2who has nothing, unattached to sensual life,SNP 5.5:11.3clearly has crossed this flood, SNP 5.5:11.4crossed to the far shore, kind, wishless.

SNP 5.5:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 204And a wise person here, a knowledge master, SNP 5.5:12.2having untied the bond to live after life,SNP 5.5:12.3free of craving, untroubled, with no need for hope, SNP 5.5:12.4has crossed over rebirth and old age, I declare.”

SNP 5.5:2.1BJ 25.322PTS-VP-PLI 202“You have rightly asked me of the origin of suffering,” SNP 5.5:2.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.5:2.3“I shall tell you as I understand it. SNP 5.5:2.4Attachment is the source of suffering SNP 5.5:2.5in all its countless forms in the world.

SNP 5.5:3.1When an ignorant person builds up attachments, SNP 5.5:3.2that idiot returns to suffering again and again.SNP 5.5:3.3So let one who understands not build up attachments, SNP 5.5:3.4contemplating the birth and origin of suffering.”

SNP 5.5:4.1“Whatever I asked you have explained to me. SNP 5.5:4.2I ask you once more, please tell me this:SNP 5.5:4.3How do the wise cross the flood SNP 5.5:4.4of rebirth, old age, sorrow, and lamenting?SNP 5.5:4.5Please, sage, answer me clearly, SNP 5.5:4.6for truly you understand this matter.”

SNP 5.5:5.1“I shall extol a teaching to you,” SNP 5.5:5.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.5:5.3“that is apparent in the present, not relying on tradition. SNP 5.5:5.4Having understood it, one who lives mindfullySNP 5.5:5.5may cross over clinging in the world.”

SNP 5.5:6.1“And I rejoice, great hermit, SNP 5.5:6.2in that supreme teaching, SNP 5.5:6.3having understood which, one who lives mindfullySNP 5.5:6.4may cross over clinging in the world.”

SNP 5.5:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 203“Once you’ve expelled relishing and dogmatism,” SNP 5.5:7.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.5:7.3“regarding everything you are aware of— SNP 5.5:7.4above, below, all round, between— SNP 5.5:7.5don’t plant consciousness in a new life.

SNP 5.5:8.1A mendicant who wanders meditating like this, SNP 5.5:8.2diligent and mindful, calling nothing their own,SNP 5.5:8.3would, being wise, give up the suffering SNP 5.5:8.4of rebirth, old age, sorrow and lamenting right here.”

SNP 5.5:9.1BJ 25.324“I rejoice in the words of the great hermit! SNP 5.5:9.2You have expounded non-attachment well, Gotama.SNP 5.5:9.3Clearly the Buddha has given up suffering, SNP 5.5:9.4for truly you understand this matter.

  • SNP 5.6:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.6:0.2The Questions of Dhotaka

SNP 5.6:1.1“I ask you, Blessed One; please tell me this,” SNP 5.6:1.2said Venerable Dhotaka, SNP 5.6:1.3“I long for your voice, great hermit.SNP 5.6:1.4After hearing your message, SNP 5.6:1.5I shall train myself for quenching.”

SNP 5.6:2.1“Well then, be keen, alert,” SNP 5.6:2.2replied the Buddha, SNP 5.6:2.3“and mindful right here. SNP 5.6:2.4After hearing this message, go onSNP 5.6:2.5and train yourself for quenching.”

SNP 5.6:3.1BJ 25.326“I see in the world of gods and humans SNP 5.6:3.2a brahmin travelling with nothing.SNP 5.6:3.3Therefore I bow to you, all-seer: SNP 5.6:3.4release me, Sakyan, from my doubts.”

SNP 5.6:4.1“I am not able to release anyone SNP 5.6:4.2in the world who has doubts, Dhotaka.SNP 5.6:4.3But when you understand the best of teachings, SNP 5.6:4.4you shall cross this flood.”

SNP 5.6:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 205“Teach me, brahmin, out of compassion, SNP 5.6:5.2the principle of seclusion so that I may understand.SNP 5.6:5.3I wish to practice right here, peaceful, independent, SNP 5.6:5.4as unimpeded as space.”

SNP 5.6:6.1“I shall extol that peace for you,” SNP 5.6:6.2replied the Buddha, SNP 5.6:6.3“that is apparent in the present, not relying on tradition.SNP 5.6:6.4Having understood it, one who lives mindfully SNP 5.6:6.5may cross over clinging in the world.”

SNP 5.6:7.1“And I rejoice, great hermit, SNP 5.6:7.2in that supreme peace, SNP 5.6:7.3having understood which, one who lives mindfullySNP 5.6:7.4may cross over clinging in the world.”

SNP 5.6:8.1“Once you have understood that everything,” SNP 5.6:8.2replied the Buddha, SNP 5.6:8.3“you are aware of in the world—SNP 5.6:8.4above, below, all round, between— SNP 5.6:8.5is a snare, don’t crave for life after life.”

  • SNP 5.7:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.7:0.2The Questions of Upasiva

SNP 5.7:1.1BJ 25.328“Alone and independent, O Sakyan,” SNP 5.7:1.2said Venerable Upasiva, SNP 5.7:1.3“I am not able to cross the great flood.SNP 5.7:1.4Tell me a support, All-seer, SNP 5.7:1.5depending on which I may cross this flood.”

SNP 5.7:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 206“Mindfully contemplating nothingness,” SNP 5.7:2.2replied the Buddha, SNP 5.7:2.3depending on the perception ‘there is nothing’, cross the flood.SNP 5.7:2.4Giving up sensual pleasures, refraining from chatter, SNP 5.7:2.5watch day and night for the ending of craving.”

SNP 5.7:3.1“One who is free of sensual desire,” SNP 5.7:3.2said Venerable Upasiva, SNP 5.7:3.3“depending on nothingness, all else left behind,SNP 5.7:3.4freed in the ultimate liberation of perception: SNP 5.7:3.5would they remain there without travelling on?”

SNP 5.7:4.1“One free of sensual desire,” SNP 5.7:4.2replied the Buddha, SNP 5.7:4.3“depending on nothingness, all else left behind,SNP 5.7:4.4freed in the ultimate liberation of perception: SNP 5.7:4.5they would remain there without travelling on.”

SNP 5.7:5.1“If they were to remain there without travelling on, SNP 5.7:5.2even for many years, All-seer,SNP 5.7:5.3and, growing cool right there, were freed, SNP 5.7:5.4would the consciousness of such a one pass away?”

SNP 5.7:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 207“As a flame tossed by a gust of wind,” SNP 5.7:6.2replied the Buddha, SNP 5.7:6.3“comes to an end and no longer counts;SNP 5.7:6.4so too, a sage freed from mental phenomena SNP 5.7:6.5comes to an end and no longer counts.”

SNP 5.7:7.1BJ 25.330“One who has comes to an end—do they not exist? SNP 5.7:7.2Or are they eternally well?SNP 5.7:7.3Please, sage, answer me clearly, SNP 5.7:7.4for truly you understand this matter.”

SNP 5.7:8.1“One who’s come to an end cannot be measured,” SNP 5.7:8.2replied the Buddha. SNP 5.7:8.3“They have nothing by which one might describe them.SNP 5.7:8.4When all things have been eradicated, SNP 5.7:8.5eradicated, too, are all ways of speech.”

  • SNP 5.8:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.8:0.2The Questions of Nanda

SNP 5.8:1.1“People say there are sages in the world,” SNP 5.8:1.2said Venerable Nanda, SNP 5.8:1.3“but how is this the case?SNP 5.8:1.4Is someone called a sage because of their knowledge, SNP 5.8:1.5or because of their way of life?”

SNP 5.8:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 208“Experts do not speak of a sage in terms of SNP 5.8:2.2view, oral transmission, or notion.SNP 5.8:2.3Those who are sages live far from the crowd, I say, SNP 5.8:2.4untroubled, with no need for hope.”

SNP 5.8:3.1“As to those ascetics and brahmins,” SNP 5.8:3.2said Venerable Nanda, SNP 5.8:3.3“who speak of purity in terms of what is seen or heard,SNP 5.8:3.4or in terms of precepts and vows, SNP 5.8:3.5or in terms of countless different things.SNP 5.8:3.6Living self-controlled in that matter, SNP 5.8:3.7have they crossed over rebirth and old age, good sir? SNP 5.8:3.8I ask you, Blessed One; please tell me this.”

SNP 5.8:4.1BJ 25.332“As to those ascetics and brahmins,” SNP 5.8:4.2replied the Buddha, SNP 5.8:4.3“who speak of purity in terms of what is seen or heard,SNP 5.8:4.4or in terms of precepts and vows, SNP 5.8:4.5or in terms of countless different things.SNP 5.8:4.6Even though they live self-controlled in that matter, SNP 5.8:4.7they’ve not crossed over rebirth and old age, I declare.”

SNP 5.8:5.1“As to those ascetics and brahmins,” SNP 5.8:5.2said Venerable Nanda, SNP 5.8:5.3“who speak of purity in terms of what is seen or heard,SNP 5.8:5.4or in terms of precepts and vows, SNP 5.8:5.5or in terms of countless different things.SNP 5.8:5.6PTS-VP-PLI 209You say they have not crossed the flood, sage. SNP 5.8:5.7Then who exactly in the world of gods and humans SNP 5.8:5.8has crossed over rebirth and old age, good sir? SNP 5.8:5.9I ask you, Blessed One; please tell me this.”

SNP 5.8:6.1“I don’t say that all ascetics and brahmins,” SNP 5.8:6.2replied the Buddha, SNP 5.8:6.3“are shrouded by rebirth and old age.SNP 5.8:6.4There are those here who have given up all SNP 5.8:6.5that is seen, heard, and thought, and precepts and vows, SNP 5.8:6.6who have given up all the countless different things. SNP 5.8:6.7Fully understanding craving, free of defilements, SNP 5.8:6.8those people, I say, have crossed the flood.”

SNP 5.8:7.1“I rejoice in the words of the great hermit! SNP 5.8:7.2You have expounded non-attachment well, Gotama.SNP 5.8:7.3There are those here who have given up all SNP 5.8:7.4that is seen, heard, and thought, and precepts and vows,SNP 5.8:7.5who have given up all the countless different things. SNP 5.8:7.6Fully understanding craving, free of defilements,SNP 5.8:7.7those people, I agree, have crossed the flood.”

  • SNP 5.9:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.9:0.2The Questions of Hemaka

SNP 5.9:1.1BJ 25.334PTS-VP-PLI 210“Those who have previously answered me,” SNP 5.9:1.2said Venerable Hemaka,SNP 5.9:1.3“before I encountered Gotama’s teaching, SNP 5.9:1.4said ‘thus it was’ or ‘so it shall be’.SNP 5.9:1.5All that was just the testament of hearsay; SNP 5.9:1.6all that just fostered speculation:SNP 5.9:1.7I found no delight in that.

SNP 5.9:2.1But you, sage, explain to me SNP 5.9:2.2the teaching that destroys craving.SNP 5.9:2.3Having understood it, one who lives mindfully SNP 5.9:2.4may cross over clinging in the world.”

SNP 5.9:3.1“The removal of desire and lust, Hemaka, SNP 5.9:3.2for what is seen, heard, thought, or cognized here;SNP 5.9:3.3for anything liked or disliked, SNP 5.9:3.4is extinguishment, the imperishable state.

SNP 5.9:4.1Those who have fully understood this, mindful, SNP 5.9:4.2are extinguished in this very life. SNP 5.9:4.3Always at peace, SNP 5.9:4.4they’ve crossed over clinging to the world.”

  • SNP 5.10:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.10:0.2The Questions of Todeyya

SNP 5.10:1.1“In whom sensual pleasures do not dwell,” SNP 5.10:1.2said Venerable Todeyya,SNP 5.10:1.3“and for whom there is no craving, SNP 5.10:1.4and who has crossed over doubts—SNP 5.10:1.5of what kind is their liberation?”

SNP 5.10:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 211“In whom sensual pleasures do not dwell,” SNP 5.10:2.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.10:2.3“and for whom there is no craving, SNP 5.10:2.4and who has crossed over doubts—SNP 5.10:2.5their liberation is none other than this.”

SNP 5.10:3.1BJ 25.336“Are they free of hope, or are they still in need of hope? SNP 5.10:3.2Do they possess wisdom, or are they still forming wisdom? SNP 5.10:3.3O Sakyan, elucidate the sage to me,SNP 5.10:3.4so that I may understand, All-seer.”

SNP 5.10:4.1“They are free of hope, they are not in need of hope. SNP 5.10:4.2They possess wisdom, they are not still forming wisdom. SNP 5.10:4.3That, Todeyya, is how to understand a sage,SNP 5.10:4.4one who has nothing, unattached to sensual life.”

  • SNP 5.11:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.11:0.2The Questions of Kappa

SNP 5.11:1.1“For those overwhelmed by old age and death,” SNP 5.11:1.2said Venerable Kappa,SNP 5.11:1.3“stuck mid-stream SNP 5.11:1.4as the terrifying flood arises,SNP 5.11:1.5tell me an island, good sir. SNP 5.11:1.6Explain to me an islandSNP 5.11:1.7so that this may not occur again.”

SNP 5.11:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 212“For those overwhelmed by old age and death,” SNP 5.11:2.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.11:2.3“stuck mid-stream SNP 5.11:2.4as the terrifying flood arises,SNP 5.11:2.5I shall tell you an island, Kappa.

SNP 5.11:3.1Having nothing, taking nothing: SNP 5.11:3.2this is the isle of no return.SNP 5.11:3.3I call it extinguishment, SNP 5.11:3.4the ending of old age and death.

SNP 5.11:4.1Those who have fully understood this, mindful, SNP 5.11:4.2are extinguished in this very life. SNP 5.11:4.3They don’t fall under Māra’s sway, SNP 5.11:4.4nor are they his lackies.”

  • SNP 5.12:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.12:0.2The Questions of Jatukaṇṇī

SNP 5.12:1.1BJ 25.338“Hearing of the hero with no desire for sensual pleasures,” SNP 5.12:1.2said Venerable Jatukaṇṇī,SNP 5.12:1.3“who has passed over the flood, I’ve come with a question for that desireless one. SNP 5.12:1.4Tell me the state of peace, O natural visionary. SNP 5.12:1.5Tell me this, Blessed One, as it really is.

SNP 5.12:2.1For, having mastered sensual desires, the Blessed One proceeds, SNP 5.12:2.2as the blazing sun shines on the earth. SNP 5.12:2.3May you of vast wisdom explain the teaching SNP 5.12:2.4to me of little wisdom so that I may understand SNP 5.12:2.5the giving up of rebirth and old age here.”

SNP 5.12:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 213“With sensual desire dispelled,” SNP 5.12:3.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.12:3.3“seeing renunciation as sanctuary, SNP 5.12:3.4don’t be taking up or putting downSNP 5.12:3.5anything at all.

SNP 5.12:4.1What came before, let wither away, SNP 5.12:4.2and after, let there be nothing.SNP 5.12:4.3If you don’t grasp at the middle, SNP 5.12:4.4you will live at peace.

SNP 5.12:5.1One rid of greed, brahmin, SNP 5.12:5.2for the whole realm of name and form,SNP 5.12:5.3has no defilements by which SNP 5.12:5.4they might fall under the sway of Death.”

  • SNP 5.13:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.13:0.2The Questions of Bhadrāvudha

SNP 5.13:1.1“I have a request for you, the shelter-leaver, the craving-cutter, the imperturbable,” SNP 5.13:1.2said Venerable Bhadrāvudha,SNP 5.13:1.3“the delight-leaver, the flood-crosser, the freed, SNP 5.13:1.4the formulation-leaver, the intelligent. SNP 5.13:1.5Many people have gathered from different lands

SNP 5.13:2.1BJ 25.340wishing to hear your word, O hero. SNP 5.13:2.2After hearing the spiritual giant they will depart from here.SNP 5.13:2.3Please, sage, answer them clearly, SNP 5.13:2.4for truly you understand this matter.”

SNP 5.13:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 214“Dispel all acquisitive craving,” SNP 5.13:3.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.13:3.3“above, below, all round, between. SNP 5.13:3.4For Māra pursues a personSNP 5.13:3.5using whatever they grasp in the world.

SNP 5.13:4.1So let a mindful mendicant who understands SNP 5.13:4.2not grasp anything in all the world, SNP 5.13:4.3observing that these people who cling to the domain of deathSNP 5.13:4.4are clinging to attachment.”

  • SNP 5.14:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.14:0.2The Questions of Udaya

SNP 5.14:1.1“To the meditator, rid of hopes,” SNP 5.14:1.2said Venerable Udaya,SNP 5.14:1.3“who has completed the task, is free of defilements, SNP 5.14:1.4and has gone beyond all things, SNP 5.14:1.5I have come in need with a question. SNP 5.14:1.6Tell me the liberation by enlightenment, SNP 5.14:1.7the smashing of ignorance.”

SNP 5.14:2.1“The giving up of both ,” SNP 5.14:2.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.14:2.3sensual desires and aversion; SNP 5.14:2.4the dispelling of dullness, SNP 5.14:2.5and the cessation of remorse.

SNP 5.14:3.1Pure equanimity and mindfulness, SNP 5.14:3.2preceded by investigation of principles— SNP 5.14:3.3this, I declare, is liberation by enlightenment, SNP 5.14:3.4the smashing of ignorance.”

SNP 5.14:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 215“What fetters the world? SNP 5.14:4.2What explores it? SNP 5.14:4.3With the giving up of what SNP 5.14:4.4is extinguishment spoken of?”

SNP 5.14:5.1BJ 25.342“Delight fetters the world. SNP 5.14:5.2Thought explores it. SNP 5.14:5.3With the giving up of craving SNP 5.14:5.4extinguishment is spoken of.”

SNP 5.14:6.1“For one living mindfully, SNP 5.14:6.2how does consciousness cease?SNP 5.14:6.3We’ve come to ask the Buddha; SNP 5.14:6.4let us hear what you say.”

SNP 5.14:7.1“Not taking pleasure in feeling SNP 5.14:7.2internally and externally—SNP 5.14:7.3for one living mindfully, SNP 5.14:7.4that’s how consciousness ceases.”

  • SNP 5.15:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.15:0.2The Question of Posala

SNP 5.15:1.1“To the one who reveals the past,” SNP 5.15:1.2said Venerable Posala,SNP 5.15:1.3who is imperturbable, with doubts cut off, SNP 5.15:1.4and who has gone beyond all things, SNP 5.15:1.5I have come in need with a question.

SNP 5.15:2.1Consider one who perceives the disappearance of form, SNP 5.15:2.2who has entirely given up the body, SNP 5.15:2.3and who sees nothing at all SNP 5.15:2.4internally and externally. SNP 5.15:2.5I ask the Sakyan about knowledge for them;SNP 5.15:2.6how should one like that be guided?”

SNP 5.15:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 216“The Realized One directly knows,” SNP 5.15:3.2said the Buddha,SNP 5.15:3.3“all the planes of consciousness. SNP 5.15:3.4And he knows this one who remains, SNP 5.15:3.5committed to that as their final goal.

SNP 5.15:4.1Understanding that desire for rebirth SNP 5.15:4.2in the dimension of nothingness is a fetter, SNP 5.15:4.3and directly knowing what this really means,SNP 5.15:4.4one then sees that matter clearly. SNP 5.15:4.5That is the knowledge of reality for them,SNP 5.15:4.6the brahmin who has lived the life.”

  • SNP 5.16:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.16:0.2The Questions of Mogharājā

SNP 5.16:1.1BJ 25.344“Twice I have asked the Sakyan,” SNP 5.16:1.2said Venerable Mogharājā, SNP 5.16:1.3“but you haven’t answered me, O Seer.SNP 5.16:1.4I have heard that the divine hermit SNP 5.16:1.5answers when questioned a third time.

SNP 5.16:2.1Regarding this world, the other world, SNP 5.16:2.2and the realm of Brahmā with its gods, SNP 5.16:2.3I’m not familiar with the view SNP 5.16:2.4of the renowned Gotama.

SNP 5.16:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 217So I’ve come in need with a question SNP 5.16:3.2to the one of excellent vision. SNP 5.16:3.3How to look upon the world SNP 5.16:3.4so the King of Death won’t see you?”

SNP 5.16:4.1“Look upon the world as empty, SNP 5.16:4.2Mogharājā, ever mindful.SNP 5.16:4.3Having uprooted the view of self, SNP 5.16:4.4you may thus cross over death. SNP 5.16:4.5That’s how to look upon the world SNP 5.16:4.6so the King of Death won’t see you.”

  • SNP 5.17:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.17:0.2The Questions of Piṅgiya

SNP 5.17:1.1“I am old, feeble, and pallid,” SNP 5.17:1.2said Venerable Piṅgiya, SNP 5.17:1.3“my eyes unclear, my hearing faint.SNP 5.17:1.4Don’t let stupid me perish meanwhile; SNP 5.17:1.5explain the teaching so that I may understand SNP 5.17:1.6the giving up of rebirth and old age here.”

SNP 5.17:2.1“Having seen those stricken by forms,” SNP 5.17:2.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.17:2.3“negligent people afflicted by forms; SNP 5.17:2.4therefore, Piṅgiya, being diligent, SNP 5.17:2.5give up form so as not to be reborn.”

SNP 5.17:3.1BJ 25.346PTS-VP-PLI 218“The four directions, the intermediate directions, SNP 5.17:3.2below, and above: in these ten directions SNP 5.17:3.3there’s nothing at all in the world SNP 5.17:3.4that you’ve not seen, heard, thought, or cognized. SNP 5.17:3.5Explain the teaching so that I may understand SNP 5.17:3.6the giving up of rebirth and old age here.”

SNP 5.17:4.1“Observing people sunk in craving,” SNP 5.17:4.2replied the Buddha,SNP 5.17:4.3“tormented, mired in old age; SNP 5.17:4.4therefore, Piṅgiya, being diligent, SNP 5.17:4.5give up craving so as not to be reborn.”

  • SNP 5.18:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.18:0.2Homage to the Way to the Beyond

SNP 5.18:1.1This was said by the Buddha while staying in the land of the Magadhans at the Pāsāṇake shrine. SNP 5.18:1.2When requested by the sixteen brahmin devotees, he answered their questions one by one. SNP 5.18:1.3If you understand the meaning and the teaching of each of these questions, and practice accordingly, you may go right to the far shore of old age and death.SNP 5.18:1.4These teachings are said to lead to the far shore, which is why the name of this exposition of the teaching is “The Way to the Beyond”.

SNP 5.18:2.1Ajita, Tissametteyya, SNP 5.18:2.2Puṇṇaka and Mettagū, SNP 5.18:2.3Dhotaka and Upasiva, SNP 5.18:2.4Nanda and then Hemaka,

SNP 5.18:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 219both Todeyya and Kappa, SNP 5.18:3.2and Jatukaṇṇī the astute, SNP 5.18:3.3Bhadrāvudha and Udaya, SNP 5.18:3.4and the brahmin Posala, SNP 5.18:3.5Mogharājā the intelligent, SNP 5.18:3.6and Piṅgiya the great hermit:

SNP 5.18:4.1they approached the Buddha, SNP 5.18:4.2the hermit of consummate conduct. SNP 5.18:4.3Asking their subtle questions, SNP 5.18:4.4they came to the most excellent Buddha.

SNP 5.18:5.1BJ 25.348The Buddha answered their questions SNP 5.18:5.2in accordance with truth. SNP 5.18:5.3The sage satisfied the brahmins SNP 5.18:5.4with his answers to their questions.

SNP 5.18:6.1Those who were satisfied by the all-seer, SNP 5.18:6.2the Buddha, Kinsman of the Sun,SNP 5.18:6.3led the spiritual life in his presence, SNP 5.18:6.4the one of such splendid wisdom.

SNP 5.18:7.1If you practice in accordance SNP 5.18:7.2with each of these questions SNP 5.18:7.3as taught by the Buddha, SNP 5.18:7.4you’ll go from the near shore to the far.

SNP 5.18:8.1Developing the supreme path, SNP 5.18:8.2you’ll go from the near shore to the far. SNP 5.18:8.3This path is for going to the far shore; SNP 5.18:8.4that’s why it’s called “The Way to the Beyond”.

  • SNP 5.19:0.1Anthology of Discourses

SNP 5.19:0.2Preserving the Way to the Beyond

SNP 5.19:1.1“I shall keep reciting the Way to the Beyond,” SNP 5.19:1.2said Venerable Piṅgiya, SNP 5.19:1.3“which was taught as it was seenSNP 5.19:1.4by the immaculate one of vast intelligence. SNP 5.19:1.5He is desireless, unentangled, a spiritual giant: SNP 5.19:1.6why would he speak falsely?

SNP 5.19:10.1“I never dwell apart from him, SNP 5.19:10.2not even for an hour, brahmin. SNP 5.19:10.3From Gotama, vast in wisdom, SNP 5.19:10.4from Gotama, vast in intelligence.

SNP 5.19:11.1He is the one who taught me Dhamma, SNP 5.19:11.2visible in this very life, immediately effective, SNP 5.19:11.3the untroubled, the end of craving, SNP 5.19:11.4to which there is no compare.

SNP 5.19:12.1Being diligent, I see him SNP 5.19:12.2in my mind’s eye day and night. SNP 5.19:12.3I spend the name in homage to him, SNP 5.19:12.4hence I think I dwell with him.

SNP 5.19:13.1My faith and joy and intent and mindfulness SNP 5.19:13.2never stray from Gotama’s teaching. SNP 5.19:13.3I bow to whatever direction SNP 5.19:13.4the one of vast wisdom heads.

SNP 5.19:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 222I’m old and feeble, SNP 5.19:14.2so my body cannot go there, SNP 5.19:14.3but I always travel in my thoughts, SNP 5.19:14.4for my mind, brahmin, is bound to him.

SNP 5.19:15.1Lying floundering in the mud, SNP 5.19:15.2I drifted from island to island.SNP 5.19:15.3Then I saw the Buddha, SNP 5.19:15.4the undefiled one who has crossed the flood.”

SNP 5.19:16.1BJ 25.352“Just as Vakkali was committed to faith— SNP 5.19:16.2Bhadrāvudha and Gotama of Āḷavī too— SNP 5.19:16.3so too you should commit to faith. SNP 5.19:16.4You will go, Piṅgiya, beyond the domain of death.”

SNP 5.19:17.1“My confidence grew SNP 5.19:17.2when I heard the word of the sage,SNP 5.19:17.3the Buddha with veil drawn back, SNP 5.19:17.4so kind and eloquent.

SNP 5.19:18.1Having directly known all about the gods, SNP 5.19:18.2he understands all top to bottom,SNP 5.19:18.3the teacher who settles all questions SNP 5.19:18.4for those who admit their doubts.

SNP 5.19:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 223Unfaltering, unshakable; SNP 5.19:19.2that to which there is no compare. SNP 5.19:19.3For sure I will go there, I have no doubt of that.SNP 5.19:19.4Remember me as one whose mind is made up.”

SNP 5.19:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 220Come, let me extol SNP 5.19:2.2in sweet words of praise SNP 5.19:2.3the one who’s given up stains and delusions, SNP 5.19:2.4conceit and contempt.

SNP 5.19:3.1The Buddha, all-seer, dispeler of darkness, SNP 5.19:3.2has gone to world’s end, beyond all rebirths;SNP 5.19:3.3he is free of defilements, and has given up all pain, SNP 5.19:3.4the rightly-named one, brahmin, is revered by me.

SNP 5.19:4.1Like a bird that flees a little copse, SNP 5.19:4.2to roost in a forest abounding in fruit,SNP 5.19:4.3I’ve left the near-sighted behind, SNP 5.19:4.4like a swan come to a great river.

SNP 5.19:40.5The Anthology of Discourses is completed.

SNP 5.19:5.1Those who explained to me previously, SNP 5.19:5.2before I encountered Gotama’s teaching, SNP 5.19:5.3said ‘thus it was’ or ‘so it shall be’.SNP 5.19:5.4All that was just the testament of hearsay; SNP 5.19:5.5all that just fostered speculation.

SNP 5.19:6.1BJ 25.350Alone, the dispeler of darkness SNP 5.19:6.2is splendid, a beacon: SNP 5.19:6.3Gotama, vast in wisdom, SNP 5.19:6.4Gotama, vast in intelligence.

SNP 5.19:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 221He is the one who taught me Dhamma, SNP 5.19:7.2visible in this very life, immediately effective,SNP 5.19:7.3the untroubled, the end of craving, SNP 5.19:7.4to which there is no compare.”

SNP 5.19:8.1“Why would you dwell apart from him SNP 5.19:8.2even for an hour, Piṅgiya? SNP 5.19:8.3From Gotama, vast in wisdom, SNP 5.19:8.4from Gotama, vast in intelligence?

SNP 5.19:9.1He is the one who taught you Dhamma, SNP 5.19:9.2visible in this very life, immediately effective,SNP 5.19:9.3the untroubled, the end of craving, SNP 5.19:9.4to which there is no compare.”
